output: Mr. President, dear colleagues, I apologize once again for my delay.
This year marks the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue.
The involvement of all and the perception that education, knowledge and the intertwining of different cultures with each other is crucial is already a given fact.
For this very reason, multiple initiatives associated with this year have been carried out by the different areas of action and intervention.
In this context, the Erasmus Mundus program also plays its role and, in this new perspective, the new regulation is already present.

The Erasmus Mundus program is an important contribution to the creation of centers of excellence in the EU, which will, in a way, allow the brain drain out of the European Union to be sustained, as well as represents a remarkable role in the creation of the European Union.

in promoting European values among nationals of third countries who come here to study and who find in the old continent an uneven cultural and linguistic diversity that works as an attractive and distinct pole of models existing in the rest of the world.
However, dialogue and interculturality have suffered a lot to survive.

The problem of Erasmus students'visums in the world and the frequent difficulties in obtaining and renewing them often lead to a situation of semi-clandestinity in the European Union, because they are often mastered, but with tourist visas and sometimes expired.
I consider it of the utmost relevance and urgency to seek a solution that allows for solidity, transparency and effectiveness in the issuance of visas for these students.
Also, knowledge of the language that allows cultural perception and mutual conviviality beyond the strictly academic domain is crucial, so we can guarantee this premise in absolute terms.
Finally, a word of thanks to the deputy Dessarné for the way she conducted the whole process and for the balanced report she produced.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, the authorization for granting state aid for the modernization and renewal of fishing fleets in the outermost regions should only be possible until the end of 2009 or should be valid indefinitely.
The particularities of fishing activity in these regions justify that these aids can be granted beyond 2009 without the marine environment being minimally harmed.
State aid for the modernization and renewal of fleets in the outermost regions for an indefinite period does not mean permanent and eternal aid.
They would be immediately interrupted if the studies and evaluation of the Scientific Council and the Regional Advisory Councils highlighted this need.
This is the solution that would best fit the very specific reality of fishing in the outermost regions.

The same reasons that justify an exclusive fishing reserve for fishermen from each Outermost Region up to 100 miles also justify a differentiated treatment with regard to aid for the modernization and renewal of the fleet.
Fortunately, the Fisheries Commission has found the best solutions that can address the particularities of fishing in the outermost regions. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner Almunia, Mr. President of the Eurogroup, I would like to congratulate not only the rapporteurs, but also the Commission for the initiative to have made this text, the balance of the 10 years of the Economic and Monetary Union.
It is a strategic text and this analysis was fundamental.
The euro, as was said here today, is an undeniable success.

From Lisbon to Helsinki, from Dublin to Bratislava, the euro has shown resistance and solidity even during the serious turmoil we are witnessing and it is clearly important that the borders of this club are extended.
But the times we live in put the solidity of the European project to the test on a daily basis in many other dimensions.
As I said, the euro is a central instrument of the functioning of the financial system.

However, the text, the Commission's own text, clearly points to the fundamental conclusion that neither the growth of the real economy, nor convergence, in terms of both social and spatial terms, accompanied this success.
On the contrary, the Commission clearly concludes that disparities have worsened violently during the decade of the single currency.
This divergence affects regions of my country, particularly northern Portugal, but also other regions of member countries.
The impacts of the single monetary policy, particularly the very high exchange rate, will affect more the regions that are most exposed to international competition and the most exporting regions.
Today, the crisis resulting from the deregulation of financial markets is violently affecting the real economy and further aggravating the situation of many citizens and many regions.

These regions, those exposed to international competition, those that depend on small and medium-sized enterprises, those where access to credit is more important, are today being victims of this process and even threaten depression.
Mr. Commissioner, Mr. President of the Eurogroup, the success of the euro depends on the confidence that European citizens have in it.
The most powerful European countries have already started processes of relaunching the national economy.
We have the case, in particular, of initiatives that concern the automotive industry.
But Europe is more than that.
It has to be much more than the more or less coordinated sum of national policies.
It is time to turn the euro into a central tool of Europe, to support a robust currency, but also a robust real economy, and to monitor the functioning of the euro.
of mechanisms that guarantee the central objective of achieving social and regional convergence, because it is at the heart of the European project.
The debate on the coordination of economic policies in the euro area has today a reinforced and unquestionable impact and relevance.
But coordinating national policies is not enough.
More is needed.

Having a Lisbon strategy that is a sum of national initiatives and a Stability and Growth Pact that tightens the different countries it uses and that it must be subject to are limitations to which the limited budget we have is added.
Crises generate opportunities.
The Monetary Union can only be sustained by a convergence of the well-being of the member countries that integrate it, regardless of their citizens, regardless of where they were born.
What other way would we have to mobilize citizens for the single currency?

The Commission must be up to its own diagnosis and that is why we are eagerly awaiting the concrete proposals that the Commission will bring to this plenary on November 26th and will present to European citizens.

It is essential that, from this crisis, a new phase of the Union is launched in which the consolidation and strength of the financial system are accompanied by effective prosperity made of cohesion and also economic citizenship.

Thank you, Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. This oral question, presented to the European Commission by Gerardo Galiotta, on behalf of the Regional Development Committee of this Parliament, has all the justification and relevance.

In fact, it is necessary to make clear the reasons that lead the Council to block the reform of the Solidarity Fund, insofar as it is not able to reach an agreement on a common position that allows the legislative process to continue.
It is difficult to determine the reasons that may be underlying the Council's position, except perhaps petty financial reasons.
Does the Council not want a more agile and immediate response to natural disasters that occur?
I do not want the Council to give this kind of famous response to other types of disasters, such as serious industrial accidents, terrorist attacks or serious situations in terms of public health.

It is important that these issues have a clear answer, just as it is also important to clarify what the European Commission thinks about this situation and if it intends to take any measures to unblock the legislative process.
The solidarity value must also be fully implemented in this area.
Citizens wouldn't understand at all if we weren't like that.
I want to say that I wanted to protest against the statement made by Mrs. Luling, who wants to condition the vote of the deputies in this House, and this conditioning does not make sense.

The interpretation you are making is one that we do not share and it is only in this sense that I would like to ask my colleagues who know what they are dealing with, who know that we are defending other interests, which are the interests of public health and the interests of citizens and the interests of countries, to vote in favor of the report. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Commissioner, for two months the political and media agenda has been dominated by the financial and economic crisis.
The referendum in Ireland or the difficulties in the Czech Republic regarding the Treaty of Lisbon have almost no expression in the media.

Don't you think that now the Commission's information and communication strategy should be reinforced with the need and urgency of the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon also as a political response to face and overcome the crisis we are living in?
Mr. President in office, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the world powers currently have the international financial system in their hands.
They were looking for a German detail and it was no longer without time.
And therefore, maybe it is time to solve another problem that we have heard about for decades.
We have heard this song of the ignoble plundering of resources for decades, how many times, as now again in Congo, about the blood of the populations.

I believe it is also time to pursue these companies, to pursue this ignobile trade, to freeze the accounts through which the shameful profits of this mineral resource exploitation circulate and deposit at the expense of the blood and suffering of the populations.
I don't understand why these companies are not listed under the same title as we already make a blacklist of terrorist organizations.
And I don't understand why the international community is not able to pursue these businessmen, who are not businessmen, they are real bandits who question regional security and world security.
I encourage the French presidency and the Commission to take an international initiative in this direction. Thank you very much.
We have heard several times today that a crisis usually generates an opportunity, and that is true.
And if we want to take advantage of the opportunity that is open to us, the agenda is easy to know.
First of all, we know, at the level of the European Union, the need to introduce mechanisms of transparency, regulation, and supervision in the financial markets.
And it is not necessary for Commissioner Macrivi to launch more consultations, nor is it necessary for the Presidency to analyze and invoke more studies.
More proposals. Just look at the proposals that were made in a timely manner by the socialists and many of them were eventually taken up by this Parliament.
Secondly, internationally, Europe cannot be in the international space in a passive way.

She has to be an active agent in the construction of the new international order. She has to be the defender of a new architecture that does not leave black holes in the system, as are currently tax havens.
Thirdly, we heard the President of the Commission say today that there is a reluctance to coordinate strategies at the level of the different States.
It is true that if we had not heard from many members of the Commission for so long that the markets self-regulate, that the State should stay out,
that the financial markets do not have an impact on growth or employment, perhaps there was a more active and more active spirit of solidarity at the level of the different countries.
But today, the proposal we have in our hands is a proposal that is no more than a first step. If we compare it with the program of China and the United States, on the other hand, it.
It does not define clearly enough what the goal is, and the goal must be employment, and thirdly, because a European program cannot be a sum of national agendas.
Today is the time for us to show the citizens of Europe that Europe is a network of rights, including economic ones, that protects them in times of crisis, in terms of.
solidarity, growth program and support for small and medium-sized enterprises that are not currently receiving the results of the interventions made at the banking level.
The real economy is exactly that and we are here as Europeans to show citizens that Europe is here too and, above all, because of them. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, it is with particular satisfaction that I present myself before you to expose the work done together with everyone in this initiative report.
For me and for all those who collaborated in the development of this process, we can say that we did our job.

To all, particularly to the shadow rapporteurs of the different political groups, who have made a great effort to reach commitments for the future, to the staff of regional development, always available, namely to Miguel Tel Cremades and Elisa da Farra.

To the PSE staff, to Lila and to Petros, to the European Commission, which, always being represented by the many different directorates-general that such a comprehensive report requires, has permanently and closely followed the work and has been very committed to ensuring that it reaches a successful conclusion.
To my office and, in particular, to Joana Benzinho, my sincere thanks to everyone, on behalf of a more harmonious and structured development for coastal regions and tourism in the European Union.
The 27 member states of the European Union add up more than 89,000 km of coastal areas.

This presents a variety of very particular characteristics that, according to its location, stand out either by cosmopolitanism, if we talk about cities like Lisbon, Copenhagen or Stockholm, or by the city of Lisbon.

due to the difficulties of being in peripheral or ultra-peripheral regions, with problems of connections to large cities or with accelerated desertification contexts, such as Algarve, Liguria, the Canary Islands or Madeira.
In one way or another, everyone identifies with the notion of coast and coastal area and lives daily the advantages and disadvantages associated with it.
According to available data, by 2010, about 75% of humanity will live in coastal areas.
According to the circuits and relationships between them, we define them as the 50 km in a straight line that go from the coastline to the inland areas.
Yes, regions and not maritime stripes disconnected from an integrated vision that these matters so desperately lack and that our ancestors would also subscribe to.
Here, the entire population will be concentrated in search of opportunities and economic synergies, and in many cases, it will only be expected that they will revolve around tourism.
Thus, the evident need for a pragmatic and integrated vision of the impact of tourism on coastal areas took over our minds and led us to get to work.

In the current context of financial crisis, where the impact on the real economy is becoming increasingly insurmountable, tourism appears as a sector with a huge potential to be directly or indirectly affected in a brutal way.

Regions that are overwhelmingly or totally dependent on this for their development see their activity threatened and look to the future with suspicion. Above all, because tourism is not currently a competence of the European Union.
However, articulated measures can and should be taken and the spirit in which the Treaty of Lisbon was imbued reflects this same trend.
However, waiting until the treaty comes into force to start acting is waiting for the phase when we will cry over the spilled milk.
The present political and tourist activity and the fragile reality of the regions that depend on it require urgent and effective action from us.

The fact that these are structurally dependent areas on tourism, as a promoter of employment, despite often being seasonal employment, this intensive labor activity cannot be hidden in a context of pressure on urban areas and unemployment.

For this very reason, this report that we are bringing to you now, which was already of the greatest opportunity and urgency when the Regional Development Committee of this House decided to promote it, now assumes that it should be seen as a priority for the European Commission and the European Council.

Priority, yes, to the numerous initiatives that it incorporates, as well as I think it assumes its express support and that have already been conveyed by other institutions, along with the measures taken in the emergency plan.

from the Commission, from which I highlight the revision of the Globalization Adjustment Fund, in which the issues associated with this sector and the shock to which it is subject at the moment must obviously be covered.

It is crucial to ensure the development of new segments of the economy of these coastal areas, ensuring their social and environmental sustainability and promoting the real integration of different sectoral policies such as the maritime sector, transportation, and.

energy, the cohesion instruments already on the ground. The new quality product policy that the CAP review incorporates with the announcement of the Else-Schek report and the new tourist products in these coastal areas, taking into account their crucial contribution to the European economy.
The implementation of an adequate and holistic vision for this policy should be a reality in the European Union soon.

And to conclude, Mr. President, only with a clear articulation of these instruments and a quick and effective action involving all the partners and stakeholders on the ground, can we ensure that we have a sustainable and future-oriented coastal tourism sector in the European Union. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Commissioner and Minister, E-Justice is an important step in access to the law, justice and courts.
I want to congratulate the initiative and congratulate the rapporteur and the French Presidency.

E-Justice was one of the projects under discussion and it is up to Portugal, during its presidency, to lead the development and implementation of the pilot project that will allow all citizens to access services from other member states in a simpler, cheaper, more comfortable way and in their own language.
This multilingual portal should be designed to serve citizens and companies seeking basic legal support and advice on legal and cross-border issues.
E-Justice should be coordinated and managed by a responsible unit, which will also coordinate the contributions of the various member states and their articulation with that responsible unit.
E-Justice will serve the citizen and strengthen our democracy.
I welcome the launch of the portal in December 2009. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Mr. Barro, colleagues, I congratulate the work of Carlos Coelho, the former Martin Rurri and the other former colleagues.
In December 2004, the Council adopted the Regulation establishing standards for security devices and biometric data of passports and travel documents issued by member states.
Now we needed to take new steps to combat child abduction and trafficking.
The use of passports by children, according to the principle of one person, one passport, can be a fundamental means of winning this difficult and important fight.
In my country, Portugal, collecting fingerprints from children from the age of 6 is already a practice with a long tradition that perhaps therefore does not cause me any objection.
As a defender of the European cause, I believe that harmonization is important in this matter.
I am reassured to know that member states like Portugal, which have long defined the minimum age for fingerprint collection as six years, will not have to change national legislation.
I must stress that the security of passports, which is being reinforced today, does not exhaust itself with the existence of a passport.

The passport alone corresponds to an increase in the level of security, ranging from the presentation of the necessary documents for the issuance of passports, followed by the collection of biometric data, to verification and matching at cross-border control stations.
This report is another step to affirm the rights of the person and guarantee their safety.
Mr. President, first of all I would like to greet the rapporteur Alexander Lambsdorff and the Shadow rapporteurs, with particular emphasis on Bárbara Weiler.
Dear colleagues, I believe it is essential that we move towards the integration of national defense markets and even the strategic coordination of their production.

We must effectively move forward with the necessary specificities and precautions in the sense of applying the essential rules of the internal market to defense industries, increasing transparency in the competitions that are organized and in the contracts that are signed involving the member states of the European Union.
But, at the same time, we have to help in the development of conditions that allow greater competitiveness of European equipment and products in the world markets.

Commissioner Macrifi. It seems important to me that this directive can guarantee progress in the legal framework related to public contracts in the fields of defense and security, advancing the construction of the market.

Internally, obviously respecting the interests and rights of the member states, especially in the field of security, and in particular those who manufacture weapons, ammunition and security equipment, such as my own country.

Mr. President, I would also like to highlight the provisions that allow small and medium-sized enterprises to have easier access to this market, particularly through the improvement of subcontracting rules and the prospect of thus advancing with greater impact and depth in the fabric.

Industrial for the creation of a true European market in defense industries, which could also contribute to strengthening research and development, not only in defense industries, but in a set of European industries that drink from the development of defense industries.
Finally, I think we can refer to the obvious articulation between the defense industry and the Union's foreign policies.
But I would like to quote a recent intervention, translating a classic Roman saying: If you want peace, prepare for war.

The European Union, as it is almost a peaceful superpower, we call these industries defense industries and not war industries, because we want peace and not war, and that is why we also need defense industries.
Mr. Vice President Barro, I agree with you, I agree with you about the dissatisfaction.
In fact, we have to be dissatisfied with the set of measures, which are vast.
The truth is that irregular immigration continues to come to Europe, human trafficking continues, there are areas where there is a lot of.
Notably, in the Mediterranean, towards Italy. France has advanced with a set of important bilateral cooperations, but other member states have not done so.
The Commission must continue to be enthusiastic about this policy of cooperation and assistance to the Member States.
Mr. President, Commissioner, I will try to ask the questions in a very concise way.
First point, the issue of the European Union's special monitoring mechanism for tests, which ended, as was said here, on December 31, 2008.
Madam Commissioner, the timely and routine publication of statistical data on imports, exports and prices is necessary, similar to what happens in the United States.
Without these data, the European Union is unable to react against possible unfair practices and the Commission itself is unable to define its strategy.
I asked him to pay attention to this, just like other colleagues have already done.
Secondly, producing within the European Union increasingly requires compliance with safety, social and environmental standards.
For example, RITS is a recent initiative that creates even more conditions for us.
It is important that the Commission has a clear strategy that is perceptible and can be monitored so that imported products have identical requirements.
How are these aspects being properly taken into account in the ongoing free trade agreements?
And as for Maidin, can Maidin really help to solve this issue?
Third point: the European Union launched an economic recovery plan to combat the current crisis.
What role will trade policy have in this context?

At the moment, what is the Commission preparing to do when a series of other countries, such as China, start to proliferate the launch of increasingly non-tariff barriers so that our European imports do not access the Chinese markets?

What proposal do you have regarding the update or adjustment of the Globalization Fund, as well as the available support within the structural funds framework to improve the immediate situation of the European textile industry?
Last question, finally, will the crisis we are going through finally make the Commission sensitive to the devastating impact on the European economy of an overvalued euro?

How can the Commissioner raise awareness, I will finish now, raise awareness among her colleagues and the entities that deal with European monetary policy in order to rebalance it? Thank you very much.
For us, it is clear that we should applaud the Obama decision, the decision to close Guantanamo, to prohibit the torture of illegal interrogations and to suspend military trials.
However, dear colleague, who is no longer present, Portugal and the Portuguese socialist government have no sense of guilt.
The Portuguese socialist government did not collaborate with the Bush administration, quite the opposite.

It was precisely now with the Portuguese administration, with the Portuguese government, with the initiative of Minister Luís Amado, that the possibility and duty of the European Union and democratic countries was triggered to welcome and receive the detainees without guilt in Guantanamo.

This is what is truly important, this is what should be highlighted as an example to follow for the other member states of the European Union. How important it is that tomorrow the resolution is approved by all the parties that make up this House so that, in unity, the decision can have more strength.
Mr. President, thank you very much to my colleague Napolitano for the excellent report.

Fourteen years after Barcelona and five years after the first Euro-Mediterranean Parliamentary Assembly, we have the Union for the Mediterranean, with economic power, parliamentary power, civil society, and heads of government deciding together.
Everyone wants to do more and better in a territory where 720 million citizens represent a potential for development and peace for the world.
Setting them only on the economic and business side is a clear mistake.

Of course, responding to growth crises requires a political response, but responding to humanitarian crises, emergency situations and military crises, such as the one experienced at the end of 2008 and the beginning of 2009, is crucial.
Politicians and citizens have to give answers to the problems of the world.
The world asked for answers and months later we, citizens and politicians, especially on a platform like the Union for the Mediterranean, are still late in reacting.

I hope that, at the very least, this moment has served to learn and move forward, because only those who make mistakes learn, but moving forward in the acceleration of the reaction is absolutely crucial.
The interest of the approval of this proposed directive lies essentially in how it can contribute to boosting economic activity at the local level and support actions at the social level.

This application of a reduced rate is of great importance in the field of housing, both in construction and renovation, allowing the member states to adopt it to reduce their respective costs for the end user.

The provision of local services, particularly by small businesses, can also be benefited by this reduction in VAT, securing and generating more and better employment through the promotion of the consumption of goods and services, thus stimulating the economy itself.
The restoration activity, which is fundamental for the proper functioning of local economies and the increase in tourism itself, can gain a lot at the local level with this reduction in VAT taxation.
These services, dear colleagues, should not circulate in the European internal market, which will help reduce the reservations of some member states already verified in the Council's plan.
Therefore, I cannot agree with the extension of this reduced rate to equipment, whatever the protest.

The prudent way this proposal should be treated in the European Parliament should not give governments that have some reservations about the European Commission's proposal a pretext to use in practice the right of veto that European legislation still has in tax matters.
And so here we must prudently reject meaningless changes that only make it difficult to accept the text.
As already mentioned here, not only is the great the enemy of the good, but also whoever wants everything loses everything.
This proposed directive is important not only for strengthening local economies, but also corresponds to the ambitions repeatedly expressed by several member states.
We therefore support the Commission's proposal as it was presented. This was, in fact, the sense of the vote, as agreed, of the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee.

I welcome the work of the rapporteurs and call for the approval of this proposal in the exact terms in which it came from the Commission and was voted in the Parliamentary Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Thank you very much.
I disagree with my colleague Edith Estrela, and that is what motivated me to speak. When she caricatured the intentions of the Czech Presidency.
Nobody wants to send women home. The problem is that there are women who want or would like to stay at home.
There are even associations that try to defend them, women who are ignored, despised, discriminated against, because they want to dedicate themselves to the family and we do not listen to them.
And this is a matter of freedom, it is a matter of freedom of choice, which the left so much likes to evoke, but which it forgets here.
It is about respecting or not respecting the freedom of orientation of couples.
It is about being able to provide those who want to do it with more quality of life, more paternity and more quality maternity.
This is what our society also needs to do.
We won't go there, we won't solve the problems of birth rate and happiness of people with prejudices.
We solve it with policies adjusted to the reality and spontaneous desires of the people.
We are not going there with an obsession with the State and the market.
Let's go there with a fair look at the family.
Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, the difficult situation in Quimonda was aggravated by the emergence of the financial and economic crisis.
The Portuguese government has done everything it deems appropriate and useful to help resolve the situation.
And we would like the Bavarian government to also know how to act with a great sense of responsibility in this area.
Saving the facilities in Munich will have a decisive impact on the units of Vila do Conde and Dresden.

Portuguese Minister Manuel Pinho himself stated his great interest in making this company, which is so important for Portugal and Europe, viable, stating that Quimonda can be a competitive company worldwide.
Mr. President, will the Portuguese government continue its efforts towards a solution that guarantees the viability of the company?
We hope that the German governments, at the federal and state level, will effectively commit to solving this problem.
As for me, I would like to emphasize again the strategic importance of maintaining this type of industry in European territory.
that no national or state executive makes the mistake of letting this company close facilities and liquidate jobs in the territory of the Union.
Dear colleagues, we understand the need to help restructure large car industry groups, but the Union funds and the energies of the European Commission cannot be exhausted in these aids.

Dear Commissioner, committing the Commission to support Aquimonda, overcoming possible communication failures, is the appeal we make to Commissioner Vladimir Spidla, to whom we are linked by work ties and political solidarity, and to President Barroso, who will never forget that he is our compatriot and a significant part of Aquimonda's workers.

We should emphasize, before finishing, that Portuguese President Cavaco Silva, in Germany, recently stated that there was a new hope regarding Quimonda. And it is also worth mentioning the importance, as has already been done by colleagues, of the economic sector in which Quimonda operates.
We take into account, therefore, that the Portuguese government is available to support Quimonda with whatever is necessary, taking into account the economic dimension of the country.
Ladies and gentlemen, let us help save Kimonda, time is pressing.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, we have been talking about the Lisbon Strategy for years and the times we live in are perhaps not the right ones to talk about the Lisbon Strategy, but we certainly need a strategy.
in a strategy that responds to the difficulties and challenges that the present crisis poses to us.
And that is what we also expect from the Commission.

It is essential that the Commission does not deviate from this issue and, instead, has the ability to coordinate actions with the governments of Portugal and the governments of Germany and the German Länder.

It is essential to keep in mind that this is an industry, as has already been said here, that interests Europe for its quality and value, for the research it develops, for the environmental quality associated with it, and it is essential that the Commission does not move away.
I agree with the invitation made by my colleague Pineda for the Commissioner and the Commission to travel to Portugal.

It is essential that the Commission beares in mind that, at this time, Europeans are looking to Europe and expect answers from the European authorities. They need to feel that the European authorities are close.

European citizens do not understand a Europe that washes its hands. Rather, they want a Europe that has the audacity to get its hands dirty and get to work, helping them overcome difficulties. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, thank you very much. I also join my words in the tributes to Jamonet, but I asked for the floor to greet the President for the statement he made about the European Day in Memory of the Victims of Terrorism.
It was on my proposal that we adopted this guideline five years ago, which the Council consecrated at a meeting on March 25, following the tragic attacks in Madrid.
But I am intervening in the Euro-Mediterranean.
The Parliament has always been faithful to the celebration of this date, but unfortunately, this date has not yet had the projection it should have had in all European institutions and member states.
I believe that the celebration of this date is one of the most important instruments we have to pay tribute to the victims, as the President did, but also to raise the level of public awareness.
I know there are some celebrations in Madrid today, but not much more.
And therefore, the appeal I make to the Commission, to the Czech Presidency, is that all Member States celebrate this date with dignity in the future. Thank you very much.
Ladies and gentlemen, my dear colleagues, the crisis is deeper than we expected and unemployment will be higher than we predict.
There are good reasons to assume that the planned European stimulus is not enough, but it is already clear that it is taking too long to reach the citizens.
The position of the Parliament is strong and clear. It has been and I hope it will continue to be so.
Our goal is to maintain employment and create new jobs, with cohesion, with solidarity, both territorial and social.
And at this moment of crisis, citizens cannot be satisfied with a Europe that does not give them an answer, with a Europe that is powerless in the face of the problems they are going through.
What will Parliament ask the Commission?

Naturally, through these reports, it asks you to coordinate national interventions. It asks you to use all the means at your disposal at this time to intervene and to give you all the conditions as a budgetary entity for this to happen.

He asks you to launch a clear European initiative for employment and tells you that it is important to have an agenda with a timetable to implement the measures of regulation of the financial market, as well as to reach the real economy with credit.
But what does the Council expect?
The Council is asked, above all, to regain the political will that is at the heart of the construction of the European project.
The European Union is competition, but it is also cohesion and solidarity.
And there can be no single market without this guarantee of solidarity and cohesion.
That is why we all delegated, at the European level, the national autonomies we had before joining this project. Thank you very much.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, anyone who visits sub-Saharan Africa easily recognizes, in the generality of countries, the enormous weakness of their health systems and the extremely negative impact that this weakness has on the lives and health of the populations that those services should serve.
The indicators continually disseminated at the international level never cease to confirm this.
And, to that extent, it is absolutely disturbing to think that simple gestures and practices, not even very elaborate, nor particularly expensive, could be enough to save many lives.

European financial support can be crucial in this regard and we cannot fail to always keep in mind how cooperation in the area of health is truly strategic and directly affects not only one of the Millennium Goals, but many of the Millennium Goals.

Now, the Court of Auditors considered that, and I quote, Community funding for the health sector has not increased since 2000 in the proportion of its total development aid, despite the commitments made by the Commission regarding the Millennium Goals and the health crisis in sub-Saharan Africa.
Finally, it is.

And he recognized, and I quote again, that the Commission contributed significantly, through its funding, to the establishment of the World Fund for the Fight against AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, but did not pay the same attention to the strengthening of health systems, which was expected to be one of its priorities.
I am a citizen.

According to the Court, this will have happened, I quote again, because the Commission did not have enough experience in health matters to ensure that the funding of the aid granted to this sector was used in the best way.
I'm going to do it.
This is, therefore, a strong challenge that the Court of Auditors is directly launching to the European Commission and that I am following.
For our part, I want to reiterate this same challenge, now sustained in the objectivity of these data and this assessment.
Health services are already part of it, but they should increasingly be part of our development aid priorities, and deserve an increase in their funding.

Optimizing the way aid is provided, bearing in mind the seemingly antagonistic needs of coordination in its management and proximity to the beneficiary populations, is providing a service that can save many lives.
The European Commission cannot fail to respond positively to this challenge and it is in this sense that I urge it.
Colleague Bowis made a touching speech here just now and was able to put human faces in the dry coldness of these numbers from the Court of Auditors.
The challenge for us, Commissioner, is that our cooperation is able to put a look of joy and hope on these same faces.
And for this, Commissioner, it is essential that the numbers in the area of health are different in our cooperation.
Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, once again, for sad reasons, we are discussing here the situation in Guinea-Bissau, which is a truly painful situation.
It is a country that has been experiencing chronic instability for many years, which tried a path to democracy in the early 1990s.

Nothing has gone well, there was a coup, a small internal war and it lives in great political and military instability, tensions, deep rivalries and now recently also the very worrying presence, increasingly evident for all observers of the interest of drug trafficking.
We strongly condemn these attacks, the bombing of the chief of staff, Tagume Naué, and also the murder, in particularly barbaric, not to say savage, of President Nineveh.
Regardless of their past, we express our solidarity with their families, the people of Guinea-Bissau and we regret, we strongly condemn these attacks.
We wish you a return to normalcy and the lesson I draw and that I would like to emphasize in the resolution is that impunity is not a remedy.
In the past, regarding the murder of Asuman Mané and the journalist Verissim Siabra, how did you close your eyes to the fact that the guilty were not found and brought to justice?
obviously, it is not a resource.

And, therefore, we have to make it clear to the State of Guinea-Bissau that those responsible have to be found, the guilty have to be brought to justice and we have to provide all the help that is necessary.

I would also like to draw attention, to conclude, to the concern we have heard about the presence of drug trafficking throughout the region, the risk that this also represents for the European Union and the shocking presence, by its evident nature, in Guinea-Bissau.
I would also like to appeal to us to address the relationship with Cape Verde in this context.

We have established a special partnership with Cape Verde. Cape Verde has very close relations with Guinea, a great knowledge, but it is also very vulnerable and this is also essential for our own European security.
Therefore, intensifying the special partnership with Cape Verde is also very important in this context. Thank you very much.
Madam President, dear colleagues, I would like to thank everyone for the work done.

The three lines defined in the green book, concentration, interconnection and cooperation, can provide solutions to some obstacles to the harmonious development of the Union, namely the negative effects associated with.

The concentration of economic activity, inequalities in terms of access to markets and services resulting from distance, and divisions imposed, both by borders between member states, especially those most disadvantaged, but also between regions.
We should thus promote the improvement of synergies between these policies with effective evaluation methods of their territorial impact.

For this very reason, I have always advocated the definition of supplementary qualitative indicators with the aim of improving the design and implementation of corresponding policies on the ground, taking into account the different territorial specificities.
For now, GDP remains the only eligibility criterion for receiving support from the structural funds.

However, this definition of supplementary indicators and the carrying out of territorial assessments should not be the source of more bureaucracy or more delays, but rather the simplification in the application of new policies and actions to support territorial cohesion.

The fifth interim report, and to conclude, Mr. President, makes a specific reference to the transition regions, situated between the convergence regions and the competitiveness and employment regions.
It is necessary to pay attention to the fact that these regions need to have a clearer status, with more security and stability for their development. Thank you very much.

Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, in the context of this great debate on territorial cohesion and the future of economic and social cohesion policy, I could not fail to mention the very specific problem of the outermost regions.

Regions that, due to the combination and permanence of a series of geographical factors, reveal a great economic and social vulnerability, particularly felt in a context of serious international crisis such as the one we are experiencing today.
I would like to appeal to the European Commission and, in particular, to Commissioner Hübner to pay particular attention to the effects of the current crisis in the outermost regions.

An assessment of these effects in each of the outermost regions, particularly in tourism, construction and increasing unemployment, would be important to allow a specific European response for these regions.

I therefore challenge the European Commission to prepare a European response to the crisis for the outermost regions that goes beyond the measures already announced in the framework of the economic and social cohesion policy for the generality of European regions.
a specific European response to the crisis for the outermost regions.

Mr. President, dear colleagues, in response to the global financial crisis, the European economic recovery plan states that the cohesion policy contributes significantly to public investment by member states and regions, and should act as a way to recover from the current crisis.
It specifically suggests the adoption of actions in priority areas of the Lisbon Strategy, in order to achieve growth and employment.
All the instruments activated seek to achieve this purpose and accelerate the achievement of results.

In this sense, the extension of the scope of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund and the speeding up of the European Social Fund have a particular responsibility to respond to the multiple situations of social and economic emergency that need support.
I am certain, today as in the past, that your action will be all the more effective as its actions and scopes are more complementary.

However, as the availability of new funds or new lines of action on the ground was not foreseen, it is particularly important that the European Social Fund is used to its full potential in the fight against unemployment and the rapid increase in the pressure of competitiveness in the European economy, resulting from the current financial crisis and economic slowdown.

I would like to emphasize that the Regional Commission has repeatedly identified simplification as essential for improving the management and implementation of structural funds, as the European Commission is now proposing.

We were asked to be urgent, however, on this matter. And in the adoption of this regulation package, we took it into account. And this cause never prevented us from assuming our political responsibilities.

Therefore, despite the many serious views that the particularity of the moment raises, in addition to the guarantees of the speed of the process and the real benefit for citizens that the proposal intends, we have refrained from presenting new proposals and amendments for now.
However, we warn of the need to start, right now, an evaluation process of this fund with a view to a complementary review to be carried out as soon as possible. Thank you very much.
Madam President, the crisis, among other aspects, has allowed to highlight the strong imbalances between the eurozone countries, perhaps the main one.
The conclusion of the Economic and Monetary Union report 10, but above all the extreme vulnerability of countries that, belonging to the European Union, do not belong to the Eurozone.

Therefore, the reinforcement of the available means at European level to support balance of payments crisis situations is absolutely indispensable, and therefore we welcome the transition from 12 to 25 and from there to 50 million euros of necessary means.
However, it is more important to attack the root causes of the problems and not just their most evident manifestations.
Today, the enlarged Europe and the Eurozone must reinterpret the meaning of European solidarity and the objectives of cohesion and real convergence.
It is necessary to see in this light what the capacity of European horizontal policies is, but it is also necessary to revisit new financing instruments, such as Eurobonds.
Financial assistance to the balance of payments is necessary, but it is far from being enough to guarantee the sustainability of the European project and the single European currency.
Mr. President of the Commission, Mr. President-in-Office, we are in an unprecedented crisis.

It was not, in fact, the time to discuss internally how we should organize ourselves. Therefore, my wishes are that the Treaty of Lisbon is ratified quickly so that we can face the world scene united and supportive as Europeans.
As for the economic crisis, in the report I wrote and which this Parliament approved by a majority, it was admitted that the recovery plan, however, presented by the Commission, was not enough.
Today we are sure that it is not enough.
A crisis that began as a financial one extends to the real economy, then to employment and then to social issues.
And it is not enough and is blurred.

Every crisis closes an opportunity. This is the opportunity for the Commission to respond to the real problems of Europeans, through serious financial regulation and not the lighter and more partial one that is.
How is it possible? How is it going? Not made of individualist national plans, but of a true European initiative. Not through scattered means, but focusing on the real challenge that is employment.

In every crisis there is an opportunity. This is the opportunity for the Commission and Europe to respond to the real problems of European citizens. And I hope that this will happen through a new approach to the recovery plan. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, dear colleagues, I would just like to express, not only on behalf of the EPP, as has already been done by many deputies, but in particular on behalf of the Portuguese deputies of the EPP, the great satisfaction with the result of the referendum in Ireland.
We believe that this clearly reinforces the development and return perspectives of the European Union, which creates conditions for a new stage.

We would naturally like to congratulate all those who contributed to the Treaty of Lisbon, in particular the Commission and the Vice-President Commissioner present here, and also, naturally, the Portuguese Presidency of the European Union.

It played a very important role here and that is why we also want to say that we are pleased to see that despite all these vicissitudes and still waiting with expectation for the position of the Czech Republic, it will be with great joy that the Portuguese will see the name of their capital linked.

This is a decisive step in the evolution of the European Union and I would like to say that we can also count on another flag, which will also always be the flag of the Portuguese MEPs of the EPP, which is the flag of the National Parliaments.
We believe that the Treaty of Lisbon takes a decisive step towards incorporating the presence of the National Parliaments into European democracy.

And that is why we believe that this dimension, which is the most important dimension of democracy, which is the representative dimension, and not, as we sometimes hear in this House, the referendum dimension, what is.

The fundamental and essential thing about democracy is representation, not direct voting. The Treaty of Lisbon is also a big step towards increasing the participation of national representative democracies in the European process.
Therefore, we are very pleased with this decision of the Irish people.

Mr. President, Minister, Commissioner, dear colleagues. A brief intervention to welcome the historic and broad result of the referendum in Ireland and to highlight the decisive role that Fan Gale and his leader and next Irish Prime Minister, Enda Kenney, played in taking the lead in this process.
A process in which the need to bring the European Union closer to its citizens was clearly evident.
They are, we are all, the main recipients of all the Union's actions.
It is essential that everyone is aware of the impact and benefits that Europe has on our lives on a daily basis.
Europe is our vital space.
What is good for Europe is good for each member state, it is good for its citizens.
This is certainly the case with the Treaty of Lisbon.
With this treaty, it becomes much more evident that one can be, at the same time, a proud and committed national citizen and a fervent defender of the European project.

And the European Union, having closed a too long debate about its organization and functioning, could focus much more and with new, much more effective instruments, on the real problems that Europeans face, competitiveness, growth and employment.
Mr. President, Minister, I conclude with a proposal aimed at future generations.

Considering the lack of information about the values, skills, objectives and functioning of the European Union, the European Parliament should propose, at the end of compulsory education in each member state, a new discipline of compulsory European studies.
In an objective, true and concrete way, young Europeans will effectively know our principles, who we are, what we do and where we want to go.

It is through the knowledge of these young people that they will understand throughout their lives the potential and enormous usefulness of the European identity of this unique project of voluntary sharing of sovereignty on a continental scale.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President of the Commission, I would like to start by congratulating you in this first debate on what this new instrument of political control means for the advancement and development of parliamentary democracy in Europe.
It is the European citizens, through their representatives, who benefit.

Taking into account the latest developments, the Irish referendum, ratification by Poland and the latest statements by the President of the Czech Republic, I ask what your assessment is of the process of the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon.
have there been diligences on the part of the President of the Commission
and what is the forecast you make for a possible date of entry into force of the Treaty and, on the other hand, to know if, at this moment and based on that forecast, the Commission
Have you already made some transitional efforts from the Treaty of Nice to the Treaty of Lisbon, or are you still in a phase of expectation, therefore in a phase of waiting to see?

Mr. President of the Commission, having heard this, I would like to know the following. At this stage, when everyone is waiting for the formation of the Commission, what is the perspective that Mr. President has?
It is whether we will now have, until the final ratification by the Czech Republic, a management commission or if they will move forward with the procedures for appointing the new commissioners.

Thank you, Mr. President. It is essential that the primary objective of the creation of the European External Action Service is the effort of the European institutions. To ensure the creation of an effective service, capable of articulating, formulating and implementing a European response to the international challenges of the present.
It should still represent more than the parts that make it up. It should be an added value in relation to the current efforts of the member states and the European Union.
In this sense, it seems essential to me that what makes the specificity of the Union be at the center of this new reality. And this specificity is the community method.
That is why I fully support the Brok report, which defends and safeguards close cooperation between the Commission and the future service.

I would like to highlight two aspects in this regard: the importance of close coordination between the President of the Commission and the High Representative, also Vice-President of the Commission, to ensure effectiveness and proper functioning.
Finally, the need for an alliance between the Parliament and the Commission to combat the announced intergovernmental drift that can compromise the effective functioning of the Service.
The Parliament must therefore be vigilant and ensure that the European External Action Service will be a center of excellence representative of the best skills in foreign policy.
Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, Commissioner. First of all, I want to reinforce the importance of this issue raised by Mr. Golarensky, because it is a matter of the most basic justice.

We all know perfectly well that in a situation of flu pandemic, it will be the countries of the South that will suffer the most from this problem and the consequences of the proliferation of the virus, not the countries of the North.

And every year we witness with total passivity the death of millions of citizens as a result of pandemics that have already been eradicated or are being treated in the countries of the North. A huge list, malaria, dengue, yellow fever, tuberculosis.
We have no limits for this list and we are passively watching this problem.

We use the countries of the South effectively as free suppliers of samples of new virus strains so that we can improve treatment in the countries of the North, but we still have no effective response to these problems. And therefore, to the questions that were raised, I would just like to add a few more.
We want to effectively treat this problem as a public health problem or as a business.
Because, if it is a public health problem, we have to guarantee equal access to treatment in all regions of the world and, for this, the efforts have to be more effective.
On the other hand, I would like to ask, and I hope it is not the case, if we are waiting for the vaccine stocks in Europe to be so overcrowded.
That the side effects are so negative in this plan, then we have an act of generosity and suddenly we start sending the necessary vaccines to the countries of the South.

And, finally, I just wanted to ask if the European Union, if we Europeans, if the Commission feels comfortable with a system or a model where the countries of the North treat pandemics through a prevention model and in the countries of the South they treat them as palliatives or just with the leftovers.

Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, I want to express my full support for the issue raised by Mr. Royal and, above all, highlight the fundamental issue, the fundamental political issue that is here in this matter, which has to do precisely with the joint programming of research.

What happened in terms of joint programming on neurodegenerative diseases, and in particular on Alzheimer's, was that in the middle of the process the rules changed, we stopped having a report, we started having a resolution, so our ability to co-decide on this matter was eliminated, we stopped being deputies, we started being consultants.
And therefore, I would like to know if at least what we recommend will be taken into consideration or not.
The programming of research activities, regardless of the subject matter, is a political choice, not a technical one. In this sense, the role of Parliament should be valued and strengthened.
It seems to me that defining priorities that are political means that they must be scrutinized, that they must be transparent, that they must be democratic.
What happened with the process regarding the joint decision and joint programming of research on Alzheimer's is a process that should not be repeated.
Please repeat, let them know in time. I hope that the last thing that can happen to us is that the decisions and recommendations that the Parliament has presented on this matter are not considered.
In the last month, the regions of Europe have been particularly evident.
The European Week dedicated to regions and cities has consolidated the position of regions as a fundamental part of the solution in the European response to global challenges.
So they concluded it, leaving no room for doubt, President Durão Barroso, Commissioner Sameski and the hundreds of debates that took place.

Also, at a more specific level, the holding of the important meeting of the Conference of Presidents of the European outermost regions, which for the first time had the participation of Members of the European Parliament, constitutes a milestone in regional policy for the benefit of European construction.
Global challenges and European responses are a great opportunity for a new strategy for the Outermost Regions.

These regions, such as the Azores, in addition to the constraints that everyone is used to hearing about, present a set of potentialities that provide clear opportunities to achieve our progress and give Europe a clear advantage in new areas essential to responding to global challenges.

And that is why the President of the Commission must put a clear end to the Palacean coup that the Commission's no-paper indicates, which was being prepared, while we, MEPs and European citizens, were advocating for the ratification of the Treaty of Lisbon and its importance in defending the cohesion of the European territory.

First of all, I would like to greet the rapporteurs, namely Mr. Martin and also Mr. Corbett, and say that, as a member of the EPP, I basically agree with the proposed amendments to the Rules of Procedure.
I would like to highlight the point that seems important to me here and that has not been brought up here tonight, which is the point of the National Parliaments.

The democratic reinforcement of the European Parliament undoubtedly results from this Rules of Procedure and the Treaty of Lisbon, but European democracy also results from the link to the National Parliaments.
And what this Regulation or this proposal is now going to do is precisely to create these two democratic legitimacy, to strengthen democracy.

On the one hand, democracy resulting from the European Parliament's own instruments, its control instruments, its legislative capacity, and, on the other hand, the democratic collaboration of the National Parliaments through different instruments.
And that is why I am, let us say, totally in tune with the proposals made.
I do not agree with my colleague Duff when he says that we should leave the introduction of relationship mechanisms with the National Parliaments for later.
I think we can do it right now, in light of the Treaty of Lisbon, and that is very important.
I would also like to say that I support the proposal of my colleagues Sayer and Brock regarding representation in COSAC and, finally, I am.
I fully agree with the observations made here by my colleague Brock and other colleagues on the primacy of Parliament and the Members of Parliament over Parliament's services.
Thank you very much, Madam President, Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. I congratulate the fellow rapporteur for the work done on this report and for her intervention just now.
This new microfinance instrument will allow microcredit to be granted to small businesses and people who have lost their jobs and want to create their own business and their own job.
This is very important at a time when it is expected that the economic crisis will result in the loss of three and a half million jobs in the European Union alone.
As a result of the economic slowdown, banks have stopped granting loans for job creation and businesses, and access to credit is more difficult at a time when it should be more accessible.
Now, this new microfinance method will counter this current trend of restricting access to credit, facilitating the obtaining of funds necessary for the launch of new companies and new jobs.
The European Commission's proposal aims to reallocate 100 million euros from the Progress program budget for this financing instrument.
we cannot agree with this proposal.
The financial and economic crisis is also a social crisis.
Therefore, the reallocation of resources from Progress, which targets the most vulnerable groups, is not at all the most appropriate solution.
For this reason, the creation of a separate budget line to finance this instrument is supported, as well as an increase in the appropriation to 150 million euros.

We also agree with the need to clarify in the legislation itself that the target group are vulnerable groups that have difficulty entering or re-entering the labor market and that face the threat of social exclusion.
Therefore, the reference to specific groups should be removed.
Finally, we stress that it is essential that people who receive financial support also receive adequate training. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to start by congratulating the Swedish Presidency and, in particular, Prime Minister Reinfeldt, both on behalf of the EPP and on behalf of the Portuguese EPP Delegation.
Our balance of the Swedish Presidency is a practically absolute success, essentially in four fundamental areas.
The first in the institutional area, the contribution of the Swedish Presidency to the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, to the very successful election of the President of the Commission.
In particular, all the ratification issues associated with ratification were extremely professional and were at the level of what is expected, the best practices of the European Union.
Naturally, for a country like Portugal, which played a decisive role in the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon, this contribution of the Swedish Presidency is invaluable.
A second point is the climate agenda, where, naturally, the Commission's work was also very important.
We must say that, from my point of view and from the point of view of many MEPs from the EPP, it is in the area of climate change that the European Union has been most successful.
It is at the forefront of the global fight, and this is due to the efforts of both the Swedish Presidency and, in particular, the Commission Presidency.
considers this balance to be very positive.

A third point is the point of financial regulation, which, especially with this last Council, has taken a step that we consider decisive and that can have a very big impact on getting out of the crisis.
And therefore, I would also like to congratulate you on the fact that an agreement was reached in this area.
And, finally, I would like to say a word about an area that personally tells me a lot, which is the Stockholm Programme and, therefore, the area of security, justice, and freedom.

I believe that I, who followed both the Tempere process and, in particular, the The Hague process, consider this Stockholm program absolutely essential and I would like to congratulate the Swedish Presidency and Prime Minister Reinfeldt for that.

Thank you, Mr. President. As is known, 15 directives have been consolidated in a single legislative act for the recognition of professional qualifications, which has caused various practical problems in the application in the different member states.

The difficulties are known and the Commission should inventory the critical points and make an analysis of the problematic areas that arise in the application of this important internal market device.
Protectionism that manifests itself at various levels constitutes an obstacle not only to the free movement of people, but also to the internal market.
We should try to identify the blurred points so that the effectiveness of the directive is not distorted by distrust.
The Union is not asked to do what the member states should do, but there is an effort to facilitate that helps to bring down professional corporatism.
Improving the application of this directive should involve the dissemination of the recognition of qualifications in the Solvit network and the EURES network, by encouraging.
common platforms, the implementation of effective contact points and, no less important, it should provide an articulation of this directive with the services directive. Thank you.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. It is urgent that a debate is promoted about the community budget and how it can contribute to its sustainability and transparency in the future.

The post-2013 financial framework must be built on the basis of solidarity and territorial cohesion, which are crucial values for regions such as Madeira, which face permanent difficulties and therefore need permanent support.
I would like to share with you some ideas that I believe should always be present when thinking and building cohesion policy.

The Commission has been referring on several occasions to some aspects that seem essential to me, such as the need for greater flexibility, simplicity, efficiency and more guidance to achieve results in the definition and implementation of this policy.
But there are issues that raise some concern for me, especially considering the needs of the outermost regions.
In this matter, allow me three brief notes. Firstly, the current approach in terms of regions should prevail over alternative guidelines, such as, for example, value-added sectors.

A reorientation like this could jeopardize Objective 2, which currently benefits about two-thirds of European regions, and could potentially be counterproductive in regions with very specific economic profiles and competitive advantages. Secondly, it seems to me that maintaining the criterion of proximity in the cohesion policy is vital.

It should continue to be a privilege to allocate and manage structural funds from a regional and not national perspective, or even centralized at the European level. Third and last but not least, I would like to recall and emphasize article 349
Article 349 of the Treaty of Lisbon provides for special treatment of the outermost regions in terms of access to structural funds, precisely due to their economic and social situation.

Aggravated by unique conditionalities and characteristics of a perennial nature, which manifest themselves in such constant difficulties and that therefore require the permanent aid claimed. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. In the face of urgency, what we saw in Copenhagen was several steps backward.

It is true that Copenhagen mobilized more heads of state than others, but it also created more divisions. And as a result, what happened was that we started to have a situation where each one for themselves, where each state can define what its goals are and, on top of that, in a volunteer regime.
To say that we have a two-degree Celsius target or funding targets without any clarification can also not serve as a consolation for us.
And therefore, what I think is that we have to act in terms of the future. And acting in terms of the future is to stop moving from rhetoric to action.
The European Union has always wanted to be a leader, it has always stated so.
But when we arrived in Copenhagen, he ended up hesitating, not defining, nor defending the goals that he said were his goals and that he would not apply.

And therefore, what I ask is if in the future we will not be more just, if we will continue to allow, at the expense of this failure and the decisions of some over others, the poorest to continue to pay the heaviest bill.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to denounce here what is happening in Portugal at the moment, where it is clear that the media
A government plan to control newspapers, television stations, and radio stations has come to light, which calls into question freedom of expression.
This week, a well-known journalist, Mário Crespo, saw a chronicle of his censored, also at the suggestion or apparent suggestion of the Prime Minister.
In view of this, Prime Minister José Sócrates must give substantial explanations to the country, he must explain that he is not dominating, curtailing, censoring freedom of expression in Portugal.

The way we are walking, Portugal is no longer a state of law, it is a formal state of law, where the Prime Minister limits himself to formalities, procedures, formalisms and does not want to give substantial explanations.
For Portugal, we want a material rule of law.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. The Green Paper on the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy, whose rapporteur is my colleague from the Azores, Maria Dussé Patrão Neves, is a unique opportunity for a debate on a sector that is of great importance in the balance of the local development of the outermost regions.

Madara is following the ongoing discussion with particular interest and considers it imperative that the differentiation between artisanal and industrial fleets, which should benefit from different fishing regimes, be proposed.
It is essential to defend a positive discrimination principle when it comes to limiting access to territorial waters within the exclusive economic zone only to local artisanal fleets.
In Madeira, support for the modernization of vessels is a priority, as well as management that guarantees the conservation of a comprehensive group of species in the long term.
Only in this way will we be able to avoid unsustainable situations for economic, environmental and social balance.
Finally, we will strive to ensure that fisheries in the outermost regions receive permanent and not outdated support.
This report on the ERDF aims to extend the eligibility of interventions in the housing sector in favor of marginalized communities in our member states.
Until now, this support was only applied to marginalized communities living in urban areas of the new member states.
In other words, since the vast majority of these communities live in rural areas and shelters, these communities could not benefit from support to replace poor quality housing.
It is, in essence, about filling a gap and giving member states and their regions greater possibilities in the policy of mitigating the specific difficulties of these communities.
I also welcome equal treatment for all member states, as marginalized communities with needs for support and integration deserve our concern, regardless of the member state they belong to.

By concluding this important report in the fight against poverty and for human dignity at first reading, it is also possible to quickly implement it within the economic recovery plan, responding famously to the crisis that affects us.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, let me start by highlighting the role of the rapporteur, Mr. Van Nistelrooy, for his work in seeking consensus on this matter and also for the willingness he has always shown to incorporate other contributions into his report.
Tomorrow we will vote on modifications to the ERDF Regulation that are of particular importance for the so-called old member states and also for Portugal.
These changes will allow the use of the ERDF in the housing sector to be extended to marginalized communities, since currently this fund can only be allocated to urban development operations.

The amendments I proposed, together with other colleagues, and which were approved by a large majority in the Regional Development Committee, will allow the old member states, and not just the new ones, as the original proposal foresaw, to also benefit from this funding possibility.
With this, I tried to avoid setting a precedent that I consider dangerous and that would exclude all the old member states from this and probably from other additional uses of community aid.
This wouldn't make any sense, since housing problems, especially among marginalized communities, exist in both the new and old member states.
I would like to reiterate that the age of accession to the European Union should not be a criterion for the allocation of structural funds and that this criterion should be abandoned in its entirety.

The negotiation of the post-2013 cohesion policy should be based on solidarity, aiming at territorial cohesion, and should be oriented towards rewarding, rather than punishing, the regions that have shown themselves to be exemplary in the use of community aid.
I would like to emphasize to the Commission and the President of the Commission the way they have worked with this Parliament during these months of investiture.
There is no body in the world with executive and legislative initiative capacity that is subject to the presentation by its President of a program before Parliament, to the hearing with all groups.

Parliamentarians, to a vote by an absolute and expressive majority, to bring here all the commissioners to be heard one by one with their own program, with 3 to 4 hours of direct questions, of questions with answers.
Someone who agreed to negotiate with the Parliament a framework agreement in which he agreed, first of all, to justify and expand the powers of the Parliament within the legislative initiative.

which accepted the principle of full access to information, whether in legislative and political action or in international negotiations, which accepted to take into account the opinion of the Parliament on the commissioners, on the remodeling of the commissioners.
This means, once and for all, and from my point of view, that the Commission has shown, from July until now, that it is willing to have a close connection with Parliament.

To do so, it demonstrated in a clear, evident and unequivocal way that the strategic alliance of the Lisbon Treaty for the community method that colleague Sariusz Wolski spoke of is the alliance between the Parliament and the Commission.
And, therefore, the Commission and the Framework Agreement deserve the full support of the EPP.
Mr. President, five years after the Orange Revolution, Ukrainians seem to look at this period as a lost opportunity.
And the fault is not only of their political elites.
It is true that these were consumed too much in power and influence wars.
Many reforms have not been fulfilled, many have not been passed from paper.
It is inconceivable that in any democracy electoral laws are changed between the two rounds of an election.
It does not mean who proposed them, who voted for them or who promulgated them.
and translates the little praiseworthy and recommendable intentions into its agenda.
And much needs to change about the lack of independence of the Judiciary, which is subject to too much influence not only from the political power but also from economic agents.
Without a free and independent justice system, there is no rule of law, human rights are not guaranteed, there is no foreign investment, there is no progress.
But the blame for this disillusionment also lies largely in this Parliament and, essentially, in many Member States.
I would like us to put ourselves in the shoes of a citizen of a European country that, due to the vicissitudes of history, is not yet a member of the European Union.
What would we expect from the Union?
solidarity.

But many chancelleries, with the exclusive concern of not bothering and displeasing Moscow, used and abused the permanent internal struggles in Kiev to avoid stating unequivocally that Ukraine is an independent and sovereign country.
As such, if this is the majority will freely expressed by its people and as long as they meet the established criteria, Ukraine can aspire to be a member of the European Union in the future.
