I would like to point out that in island regions, air transport is sometimes the only possibility of access and that operating conditions are conditioned by the size of their passenger and cargo flows.

If there are island regions where the abundance of these flows is predictable for many air operators, attracting competition and low transportation prices, thus improving accessibility, others exist, such as the Azores, where these flows are still reduced, not being attractive to the interest of operators.

As a result, air tickets are higher, constitute an obstacle to the mobility of the population and a hindrance in attracting tourists that allow this enormous potential for development and diversification of its economic base to flourish and consolidate.
This framework is particularly penalizing in times of crisis like the one we are going through.

Therefore, temporary support is essential to encourage the increase in flows so that the market can start working, also sharing these regions with high tourist potential of the objectives of the trans-European networks in the approach of the peripheries of Europe.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I am speaking today in this House with the voice of those who have lived and personally witnessed the tragedy that plagued Madeira last Saturday.

My words are, of course, to associate myself with the feeling of pain and grief that has affected the families of the fatal victims, who are currently 42, to whom I pay my tribute and respect for their losses.

The true extent of this catastrophe is yet to be revealed, since the search and rescue teams, which have been working tirelessly since Saturday in a Herculean effort that they welcome, are only now beginning to reach the most isolated populations.
And we fear that the number of victims may increase.
The scenario is large-scale destruction, with high material damage to access roads, roads and completely destroyed points, and essential services such as water and electricity supply.
There are about 600 people who have been evicted, who have lost their homes and their personal belongings.
The economic and social impact of this catastrophe prevents people from resuming a normal course of life.
But it is necessary to have a rolling in front.
It is also necessary to give a message of solidarity, hope and trust to the people.
We need to help. And it is in this chapter that the European Union and the Parliament in particular have a say. They are fundamental in the process of mobilizing the Solidarity Fund.
And when we are called to intervene, we have to do it quickly, because we cannot ask people to wait, especially when they need us the most.

I appeal here to the Commission and its President, Dr. Barroso, especially to the Commissioner for Regional Development and to Hannes Hahn, and I welcome his initiative to visit Madeira in the shortest possible time.
I ask him to also be a bearer of this message of hope, of help and support for reconstruction. Because now it is time to rebuild what nature, unfortunately, once again, has taken away from us.
But I am sure we will do it, because, as the Madeira Indian taught me, the Madeira people are humble, stoic and brave.
It is the people who, among the rocks, led the earth, the hero of work on Mount Agreste.
For the wood, he will honor his history and on the path of work he will fight and achieve his well-being and glory.
We are starting this plenary session today with a minute of silence.

And it was a minute of silence with two meanings, one of solidarity for the victims of this catastrophe that struck Madeira and their families, and a sense of tribute to all the workers who have been tirelessly helping these victims.
But a minute of silence should make us reflect and should also lead us to a reflection that goes beyond what we are doing here.
What we saw in Madeira is a phenomenon that will tend to repeat itself more and more.
Climate change makes extreme phenomena repeat themselves and we have to have answers to them.
We cannot avoid natural disasters, but we should not be condemned to have always such dramatic effects on people's lives.
That is why we must fight for planning and organization policies that are oriented towards the public good.

But I want to end, Mr. President, with what is most important and what brought us here, which is that the European Commission, the European Parliament, the European institutions must have the ability to respond urgently to an emergency situation. And for this, the necessary financial resources are needed and the necessary speed is needed.
A tribute of solidarity to the families and friends of the victims of the tragic events of Saturday on the island of Madeira.

As an Assyrian, as a Portuguese and as a European, I cannot help but appeal to the Parliament and the Union to show their active solidarity in favor of the Autonomous Region of Madeira and its populations.
It is in the regions that the presence of the Union needs to be felt and it is precisely at these times when its solidarity is most necessary that it is also more important that it is felt.

Mr. President, I also want to express my solidarity with the pain of the Madeirais and insistently ask the European institutions and, in particular, the Commission to unlock all available means, all means at their disposal, to carry out this aid.
I would also like to emphasize that when there is a misfortune of this kind, it is much more difficult to attack its consequences when it occurs in poor countries and in poor regions.

But, in the case of Madeira, we also have to take into account that the economic base of Madeira is directly affected by the fact that, depending on tourism, it has a double consequence when its natural beauty, its access, its quality of life is completely destroyed.

Therefore, there is indeed a different situation when we have problems of this gravity in poor countries and in poor regions, and in particular in mountainous and tourist regions, as is the case in Madeira.
Therefore, it is absolutely essential that all the adaptations that were planned and requested and that were mentioned here regarding the Solidarity Fund do not wait any longer.

that they immediately take office, because, due to climate change, these processes will unfortunately be repeated, especially in the poorest regions of Europe, which are those that live in torrential regimes in terms of water and extreme drought during the summer. Thank you once again, Mr. President.
Commissioner and Council, we are talking about the reinvention of the energy system for the European scale through investment in low-carbon technologies.
I think it is one of the very important challenges, as mentioned in the communication that is made.
And it is one of the challenges that we have to face in a central way. But there is no clarification here and hence the importance of raising these questions and asking for clarification.
It seems that not only the clarification of financing is lacking, but also the political clarification.
There is talk of energy efficiency, carbon capture, nuclear energy, biofuels, solar energy, and there is even talk of energy efficiency as the cheapest way to reduce emissions.
I am surprised that there are other much cheaper ways to reduce carbon emissions that are not even included in this communication, such as, for example, the reduction of consumption.
energy, micro-generation, distribution and different forms of distribution and different projects that do not have to go through only large structures and access to energy.
I think that would certainly contribute to more financial clarification to make the plan cheaper.

And therefore, within this political clarification and within this financial clarification, we still need to talk about what seems to me to be an absolutely important point, which is the emphasis that is constantly placed on public-private partnerships as if they were the solution to everything.
When asked where the money comes from, the Commission tells us that it comes from where it is.
I confess that I am no longer enlightened by being told that the money will come from where it is, without being told exactly where it is.

And, therefore, this bet on public-private partnerships, which is systematically made when we talk about low-carbon technologies, we are certainly sure. It is that, not knowing where the money comes from and knowing that they are public-private partnerships, we know from the start who will pay.
Who will pay? It is the taxpayers at the beginning, it is the consumers who, by chance, are also taxpayers at the end.

And we know that, from the start, it is the institutions and private organizations that pay less, which are the ones that make the investment, are paid for it, but, in the end, they end up monopolizing the profits.
And without this clarification, what seems to me is that, once again, we are systematically passing on the bill for the change of the European energy model to future generations.

Thank you, Mr. President. The European Union recently signed an agreement with Latin American countries within the World Trade Organization, in which it committed to substantially and progressively reducing tariffs on banana imports from these countries.

I would like to draw your attention to the fact that this agreement has directly negative effects on European banana producers, particularly on Madeira banana producers in Portugal, but also, and even more intensely, on the Canary Islands in Spain.

I would like to remind you that the situation of the producers in these regions is already seriously difficult due to the physical and orographic characteristics of the islands and the size of their farms, which leads them to face permanent difficulties that penalize their development.

It is therefore urgent to take measures in defense of banana, wood and Canary Islands producers, taking into account the serious and immediate impact that the new Geneva agreement will have on the European import market and, consequently, on the production and marketing of bananas from these outermost regions.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, as rapporteur of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I would like to start by.
I would like to congratulate Deputy Kirillov, even in his forced absence, and highlight the way he was able to prepare this important report, making the main objective easier.
I would also like to congratulate Ms. Creel for the presentation she made to us.

This main objective is, without further ado, to make procedures simpler and to speed up the implementation of programs financed by the Cohesion Fund, the Structural Funds and the Regional Development Fund.
In the context of the current financial, economic and social crisis, the pressure on national financial resources has been increasing.
This pressure will decrease with better use of community funding, with the faster arrival of these resources to the beneficiaries most affected by the economic collapse.
More than twenty million Europeans are unemployed, that is, more than four million than a year ago, and, unfortunately, the trend is to increase.

This situation requires ensuring the proper implementation of cohesion programs, as they represent the most powerful and relevant lever for helping the real economy, particularly in small and medium-sized enterprises and employment.
SMEs are the engine of the European economy and the actors of sustainable growth and job creation in quantity and quality.

The continuation of the simplification and clarification of the rules governing the cohesion policy will undoubtedly have a positive impact on the pace of execution of the programs, particularly because it will be.

National, regional and local authorities, the possibility of resorting to clearer and less bureaucratic rules that will allow more flexibility in adapting programs to new challenges. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Of course, this crisis was an unforeseen one and, of course, the precautionary principle had to have priority.
But there are lessons that need to be learned, and the first is that for five days, a strong enough and politically responsible European voice was not heard.
And this voice was missing in terms of defending the interests of passengers, clarifying their rights, seeking alternative transportation and coordinating solutions.

A second conclusion is that the exit from the crisis cannot seem, in the eyes of the common citizen, to be a game of forces between those who want to avoid losses and those who want to defend the precautionary principle.
There must be clear transparency and objectivity about the conditions under which one leaves a situation of total closure of the European space.
And, therefore, the improvement of scientific tests and coordination also at the level.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would also like to start by congratulating my colleague Tikal on her work and perseverance on this very important dossier and on the work she has done to improve the energy performance of buildings and to make Europe more sustainable.
As we know, energy spending in the European Union is far above what is acceptable, and that is why it is so important to move forward with proposals of this nature.
It is more than time for us to have an ambitious policy in European terms and to add complementary measures to this ambitious policy, especially in the crisis situation we are living in.
The construction sector is considered one of the sectors, one of the markets with the greatest potential in terms of energy economy, but it is not just that.
And that is not all, and that is why it is the sector par excellence for the affirmation of public policies. And it is in this sense that I would like to conclude, Mr. President.
We must, therefore, take advantage of this opportunity to invest in improving the energy efficiency of buildings and their potential for creating millions of jobs in the coming years.
And it is not only about new buildings, but also about the rehabilitation and recovery of existing, degraded or unsuitable buildings.

Let us take advantage of this legislation as a fundamental contribution to the revival of the European economy and we cannot continue to waste investment that can and should be strategic for recovery against the crisis and let us hope that there will be investment from the Commission and that the Member States will know how to take advantage of this investment. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I would like to start by congratulating my colleague Manders for the work done on this report, as well as thanking the colleagues who collaborated with him on this dossier.

In fact, the mere fact that this proposal simplifies and improves the current regulatory framework, bringing together in a single regulation all the existing legislation, three basic directives, on the designation and labelling of textile products, is an important fact in itself.

But, beyond that, this proposal will have a positive impact on private agents and public authorities and will also allow the framework of new developed fibers, thus encouraging innovation in the textile and clothing sector.
This revision will also increase the transparency of the process of adding new fibers to the list of harmonized fibre denominations.
There seems to be no doubt that the agents involved will have advantages with this regulation.
Let's see, the textile industry will benefit from an economy of administrative costs and the possibility of marketing new fibers earlier.
For their part, the authorities of the member states will not need to transpose the changes to national legislation, which will enable a cost saving that is relevant to these member states.
And consumers will have the guarantee that the fibers mentioned meet specific characteristics, also benefiting from the fact that the new fibers arrive on the market earlier.
For the European industry, the introduction of these new fibers is important as a way to promote innovation, also increasing the level of information provided to consumers.
In the current context of a globalized world, emerging economies with increasingly expanded markets, in which millions of products produced by millions of companies circulate,
Investing in innovation and the speed with which this innovation reaches consumers is absolutely crucial for companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises.
that the application of this regulation could increase its competitiveness.
These small and medium-sized enterprises will surely gain market share with this new regulation and, in this way, will contribute to the increase of employment in Europe.
Thank you, Madam President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner. The shortage of organs for transplantation is a major problem.

It has been mentioned here several times and it is a bigger problem that raises questions for us, both of public health and associated issues such as the reinforcement of the parallel market and organ trafficking, which in no way enlarges our health systems and our citizens.

And therefore, we have to fight this crime and fight it through legislation and proposals like the ones we are discussing here. It is a way, it seems to me, more than important and more than relevant and that is why I want to focus on the dimensions and the most important issues raised by these two proposals.
Because the system we have so far, without these two proposals, is a system of enormous inequalities.
Inequalities between member states, inequalities between existing systems, inequalities in access to organs, inequalities between citizens that it seems to me that we cannot bear.
Therefore, it is important to reinforce that these inequalities are reduced. These proposals aim to combat precisely this.
I think that a European system that maintains some specificities of some of the countries so that they are not forced to have more restrictive systems is the answer to this problem.
And the work done by the rapporteurs, Mr. Mikolasik and Mr. Pereiro Rodrigues, is of the utmost importance and contributes to this problem we are facing.
If we are talking about proposals that have as a basis and as a support issues such as donation, volunteering, I apologize, free, confidentiality, data protection,

Traceability, responsibility, and here I think it is important, on the side of Parliament, that it goes all the way to the recovery of the patient and not just to donation and cooperation between member states, I think we are on the right track.
However, I must mention, and in relation to the notions between living things, I am pleased with the inclusion and enlargement, this enlargement made with rights.

Obviously, to guarantee all rights and all conditions, but it is very important that we have gone beyond the restricted cycle of the conventional family, because otherwise it would be another way to have other forms of equality.

Therefore, promoting data as the main point of transplants and protecting patients'data and safety seem to me to be more than enough reasons for us to be together tomorrow and vote in favor of these two proposals of extreme importance for the Union.

Mr. President, Minister and Commissioner, the ability to replace deteriorated human organs with organs of another person, preventing their rejection, is one of the great successes of contemporary medicine.

European benchmarking reveals differences, it reveals that medium-sized countries, such as Portugal, qualify very well in such comparisons and larger countries, such as Spain, are today recognized as organizational leaders and good practices.
some principles and practices to safeguard.

First, the reinforcement of scientific knowledge and information that lead more and more donors to live donation and to the generalization of post-mortem donation. Second, the prohibition of the commercialization of.

Donation, not only in the member states, but also outside of them, preventing transplant tourism and combating organ trafficking. Thirdly, proactive promotion of donation in hospitals as a way to overcome scarcity.

Finally, Madam President, ensuring equal access to transplantation for all those who need it and qualify for it according to harmonized clinical criteria, obeying the principle of universal access to health, a paradigm of social Europe that we are proud of.
I congratulate the rapporteurs for the work done.
I would like to emphasize that it is with great satisfaction that the European People's Party and the Portuguese deputies of the European People's Party.
The European Parliament is starting this process of accession, of the European Union's accession to the European Convention on Human Rights.

However, I would like to draw attention to the fact that we consider it very important that the European Parliament follows the entire negotiation of the European Union's accession to the European Convention on Human Rights.

We consider this aspect to be fundamental from a technical, legal and political point of view, because the Parliament is also a House of Human Rights and a House where human rights are of great importance. And I would now like to make the note that we consider very important.

For us, members of the European Parliament, who are in contact with many states outside the European Union, it is very important, it is a very good sign that we give to the members of the Council of Europe, the entry of the European Union, to the members of the Council of Europe who are not members of the European Union.
For these members of the Council of Europe, this is a sign of reinforcement of the European Union's commitment to its situation and to the levels of democracy and respect for fundamental rights.
Madam President and Commissioner, social housing is an economic service of general interest with an important role in the market, creating positive externalities for the benefit of the whole society.
According to Protocol 26, annexed to the Treaty of Lisbon, it is up to national, regional and local authorities to execute and organize this type of service.
Therefore, this restriction of the target audience to families with incomes below thirty-three zero euros is not very understandable.
This is a poverty measurement that is done in absolute and purely financial terms, which does not take into account the diversity of the 27 member states, reducing to a simple solvency argument.
Now, social housing responds to cultural, social, workplace proximity, the important redefinition of the role of women in the market, and worker mobility in the European space.
The struggle that the European Union is waging to get out of the current crisis is through economic growth, which drags on an increase in immigration and ethnic minorities.
Economic and cultural, and the need for their integration, even with the risks of ghettoization associated with it, which we must fight with a fair balance.
Is the Commission not entering the field of competence of the Member States?

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, allow me, Madam President, to point out that we are debating the first report of the Committee on Agriculture, subject to the new ordinary legislative process provided for by the Treaty of Lisbon.

This is a historic moment that, by confirming to this House the sense of the vote I propose, will begin in the best way this new period of sharing competences in agricultural matters in the European Union.
I speak exactly as legislating on its outermost regions, in a practical demonstration of the will to build a Union that is strengthened by cohesion.
In the spirit of active solidarity, in respect of the specificities and differences of its parts, as the only viable path to building our common European project.
I also speak by introducing fundamental regulation for the feasibility of the already centenary sugar line in the Azores, a region I come from, so I am especially pleased, thus contributing to a.
Healthy agricultural diversification in a region where the milk line occupies, as we know, a unique dimension on a national scale, irreplaceable, which we must sustain and consolidate.
Madam President, I would like to thank Commissioner Ciolos and the high-ranking officials of the Commission with whom we worked and negotiated for the openness and flexibility shown.
The Spanish Presidency of the Council also made every effort to make our partisan desire to reach an agreement at first reading a reality.

This thanks is, of course, extended to the shadow deputies of the other political groups, as well as to the excellent employees of the Secretariat of the Agriculture Committee of this Parliament, whose collaboration allowed us to reach a result that I consider very positive.

I would also like to highlight the decisive contribution made by the Agricultural Federation of the Azores and the Regional and Republical Governments in the way they were involved and committed to finding a solution for Azores sugar.

The presentation of the Council's proposal for a regulation on October 2 in the Agriculture Committee was made at a time when there were no prospects for the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, which was still pending ratification by all member states.
In this context, the initial idea of the Commission and the Council was that the proposal would be approved in a simplified process, without any changes, to produce effects from January 1, 2010.

With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, and despite the dominant opinion of other political groups, as well as the Council and the Commission, for the proposal to continue in a simplified process, because they understood that.

The proposal did not need any changes and should come into force quickly, although we are of the opinion that the Socialist and Democratic Group and I believe that Parliament should already have made a statement within the framework of the Treaty of Lisbon, assuming its role as co-legislator.

We did it at the right time, because from there new possibilities opened up, first with the contribution of the Regional Development Commission and the opinion of colleague Nuntacheira, who I take advantage of, by the way.

I would like to congratulate and thank you for the cooperation always provided throughout this process and then with my report introducing new possibilities for sugar in the Azores, as well as with the contribution and support of my colleagues from the Agriculture Commission.

I would like to say, finally, in this first intervention, that, as far as the amendments proposed by the Regional Commission and voted on in the Agri Commission and supported by me are concerned, we were not able to accept them in the compromise obtained in the trialogue.

It was essential to obtain a commitment at first reading, thus safeguarding the improvements already obtained and the need for entry into force so as not to commit to their retroactivity since January of this year.
However, as the Commission is already preparing a POSEI review document, we will certainly have the opportunity to discuss it again soon.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. We are facing an acceleration of a global change that has devastating consequences for our economic, political and social systems and, consequently, for all our citizens.
Today we are witnessing an unprecedented weakening of the response capacity of the States.
The European Union must therefore identify common causes and allies and act clearly and in unison on the world stage.
Extraordinary situations require lucidity in joint action.

If we do not take the necessary measures of rigor and collective accountability, Europe will be doomed to marginalization and impoverishment, and only a strong Europe, respecting its common rules, can respond adequately to the new times.
Weakened and indebted states are not able to protect their citizens.
Therefore, we need to be able to regain the trust of citizens, win the battles of stability, budgetary rigor, job creation, stability of the Monetary Union, globalization and strategic choices.
This is a pity that we have our future committed.
And you win the future by betting on social cohesion, ensuring peace, building a new model based on the values of freedom, social justice and responsibility.
Therefore, the 2020 Strategy and the integrated Europe 2020 guidelines are essential instruments for a new cycle of growth and employment in Europe.
For proper implementation and realization, quantifiable and clear objectives must be defined in employment, education and poverty reduction.

It is also crucial for the success of the strategy that everything is done to facilitate the transposition by the member states of their national objectives and to ensure the correct implementation of this strategy. Thank you very much.
When the Economic and Monetary Union was 10 years old, the Commission considered the euro to be the most successful project of the Union.
Today we would have difficulty affirming it without limitations, because the crisis has clearly shown that the Economic and Monetary Union is an unfinished project.
Minimum rescue measures were taken in an emergency climate, but let's not be fooled. The pressure conditions, the direct interests of the main ones.
Member countries. The painful nature of the decisions, their slowness, have weakened the image of the euro and the European Union in the eyes of citizens and the world.
We have to face the facts.
The European Union and the euro are a process of integration, not just cooperation between countries.
It is an unfinished process that is currently either reinforced or is at very serious risk of disappearing.
There are three topics that need to be addressed. First, it is important to consolidate the instruments that were launched in this emergency climate. A European Monetary Fund needs to be created.

We need to move forward with Eurobonds, we need to move forward with the European supervision and regulation architecture, and we need to move forward with a European dimension in the management of banking crises.
Second dimension. It is important to understand that there is no strong currency if the economy is weak. The 1% growth forecast for the European Union is unsustainable in terms of.
Whether in terms of its demographic composition or in terms of combating unemployment. The 2020 Strategy is nothing more than a set of good ideas that do not have the means to be implemented.

Third dimension, Commissioner Olliren, fiscal consolidation is important, but it cannot coexist with growing divergences between the member states that make up the Union. The convergence policy must be urgently revised. Thank you very much, Mr. President.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Several colleagues here from the EPP have already made a very complete picture of the situation.
I think that now it will be necessary to demand and make a reference to the role of the National States.
In fact, national governments also have a role here in imposing the requirements in their states
and the conditions for the strengthening of the single currency and the advancement of this monetary and economic integration project.
And here I would like to say that our party, the party linked to the EPP, which is the PSD in Portugal, is supporting the government in austerity measures, because we consider

that the mistakes that the socialist government has made in Portugal over these fifteen years and that today, unfortunately, are visible to everyone, need to be corrected and will have the support of the PSD to be corrected.

But if we are supporting austerity measures, we also criticize the Portuguese government and it is a good example for other similar cases because it is not reducing spending. And what is fundamental is not just.

Increasing taxes to reduce the deficit, but it is reducing spending, it is demanding that the government have the courage to take measures that reduce spending, that alleviate the deficit, that alleviate public debt.
This applies to Portugal and other states that are in a difficult situation today. And we, as European parliamentarians, have the responsibility to also do something in our countries.
of the necessary measures so that the euro is strengthened and so that this space of integration and this dream, which is a dream of the EPP and which is a dream of all of us, can be realized.
Therefore, we criticize those governments that do not have the courage to take the necessary measures in their states.

Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would like to start by saying that the report on the evaluation of the results of the 2006-2010 roadmap for equality between men and women, which aims to influence the strategy on this matter for the future, could, in our opinion, have been more assertive and less controversial.

In fact, the way to address several ethically sensitive issues, namely the issue of women's sexual and reproductive health, should have been different if the goal was really to obtain the greatest possible consensus.

That said, I would like to emphasize that in times of so-called normal economic growth, the concern for women's rights, particularly the disparity between the situation of men and women at work, in society, in the family, is great. But these problems are deeply aggravated by the economic and social crisis we are experiencing.
Therefore, a strengthened strategic commitment of the member states at the level of local and regional entities and community institutions with regard to the protection of

To say that, in line with what President Dole said and what colleague Werner Langen said, it is essential that there is an economic government of the Union, but that this economic government is centered on the Commission.
This is the first point I wanted to emphasize. And that said, I want to say that we should not just, as we did this morning, focus our debate on immediate issues, but.
Also in those that are in the 2020 Strategy. And I would particularly emphasize the issue of education and training of the youngest, the issue of innovation, research and development.

Because these are the niches that will allow Europe to be competitive in the global space. And today I must say that, unfortunately, the European educational model has failed, and it has failed because, when compared to the model of emerging countries,

Like India, like China, like Brazil, it is today a less demanding and less rigorous model. And that is why I also ask that in the audacity of this idea of innovation, development, research and education, there be rigor and demand in the context of European educational systems.
Only with this rigor and demand will we prepare our young people to compete in the global market.

We cannot just think about the crisis of this year or the next two or three years, we have to think about the strategy for Europe in the next 10 to 20 years and it depends on a rigorous and demanding education system.
Mr. Commissioner, the European project, built with so much effort over the last 50 years, has never been so threatened as it has been today.

The frustration of European citizens is enormous. The financial system that should have served them destroyed their savings, their pensions, their investment projects, their jobs, in short, their future.
As for the necessary reinforcement of the entire financial services, banking, insurance and securities market, the way forward is clear and lies in the architecture we are discussing here today.
We do need a strong European supervision architecture that covers all products and actors, which is equipped with methodologies and instruments.
Effective intervention and that it is able to respond to the reality of a market that, especially in the European context, does not recognize national borders.

Risk cannot and should not be eliminated from the financial market, but we need regulation that makes this risk more transparent and that avoids the accumulation of bubbles whose explosion affects the entire system and spreads to the real economy.

But if, despite these defenses, new crises occur in the future, it is crucial to have mechanisms that limit contagion, especially with regard to the banking system, because it is vital for the functioning of the economy and is the depository of citizens'savings.

Here, exactly in the powers and competences of the Banking Authority, lies the ability to implement a new strategy on cross-border crisis management in the banking sector, a topic that my report refers to.
It is not in our hands to prevent the bankruptcy of banks, but to ensure that their reorganization or eventual liquidation is done in a way that is fair.
In an orderly manner, limiting the side effects on the rest of the system and, above all, preventing the taxpayer from paying the costs of the crises they generate.

To do this, a set of new devices is necessary. It is necessary to adopt rules, definitions, methodologies, instruments and terminology common to all stakeholders in restructuring, reorganization or liquidation operations.
It is necessary to harmonize the relevant national legal frameworks for crisis management, namely bankruptcy and liquidation laws.
It is necessary to assign extended intervention powers to supervisors.
It is necessary to design clear criteria, not only quantitative but also qualitative, that allow interventions to be initiated in an institution in difficulty.
it is necessary to prepare contingency plans.
This whole process requires time for 27 member states.
Meanwhile, about 50 banks out of the 12,000 operating in Europe represent 70% of the assets.
Now, this means a huge concentration of risk, but also an opportunity to intervene on them as a priority.

There are conditions for us to propose a special and urgent process of finding banks that, being cross-border, due to their size and relationships with other banks, have a possible systemic impact on the financial system.
Now, for these banks, it is possible to anticipate special supervision by the new European banking authority, although operating in the National Supervisors'College.
It is possible and urgent that they, due to the risk they generate, start making contributions to a fund that finances possible interventions.
that they are necessary and it is important that the banking authority creates a specialized unit that coordinates interventions in case of difficulty in these banks.
Overall, the proposed elements ensure that interventions in transnational systemic banks are consistent and coherent and between the
Different countries and, above all, that a principle so expensive in Europe is fulfilled, that the costs of pollution caused by these banks are borne by the polluter himself.
This proposal fits perfectly into what we are discussing, especially with regard to the competences of the Banking Authority. I would even say that it is the most evident test of its effectiveness.
In the case of the vote in the Economic and Monetary Committee, there was a very large majority in support of this proposal, 87% of the votes.
We also count on the massive vote of this institution here in the plenary, in the sense of massively supporting this proposal, which is visionary, which is realistic, but which is pragmatic.
Let us take an urgent and necessary action to revive the hope of Europeans in Europe, in its financial system and, in particular, in the banking system. Thank you very much.

Deforestation, as we know, is one of the main environmental and social problems of the planet and every year we lose 13 million hectares of forest, thus contributing to 20% of the global carbon emissions and posing a huge threat to biodiversity.

The contribution of deforestation to climate change is undeniable and, as such, is largely responsible for the occurrence of extreme weather events and floods, or even for the desertification of vast areas of the planet.
Forest loss puts all of humanity at risk, but this risk and impact is not shared equally by all of us.
The communities with fewer resources and the communities that depend the most on forests and nature to survive are the most affected.
Deforestation concerns our collective existence, the scarcity of natural resources, their distribution, the rights of local and indigenous communities, and social justice.
The main cause of deforestation is the illegal exploitation of wood, which represents 20% to 40% of the world's industrial wood production.
Therefore, we are also talking about the transfer of wealth from the producing countries to the consuming countries of the same wood.
This illegal practice puts the sustainable exploitation of wood and the companies that do it at risk.
Not enough words are beautiful.
This Parliament must adopt strong and consistent measures in this fight.
This report takes a very significant step in this direction by defining the prohibition of the timber trade.
It is not enough to have good intentions either.
Effective means are needed, namely sanctions that in this case could be of three types.

First, fines that actually take away the economic benefit from the illegal practice, aggravated with recurrence. Second, confiscation of the wood of the products in question. And third, immediate suspension of the authorization to exercise a commercial activity.

And so it is because whoever exploits or markets a natural resource must be socially responsible. And so it is also because whoever puts wood or wood products for the first time in the European Union must be required to diligence to ensure that it is legally exploited wood.
That is why all subsequent operators must provide basic information about this wood, namely its origin and destination.
The population should still have the right, and I will end here, Mr. President, the right to access information about who complies and who does not. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the objective of territorial cohesion, now enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon, materializes the value of European solidarity and the commitment of the Member States and the Union to reduce the disparities between the various regions.
However, it is not enough to express the objectives to be achieved in the text of the treaties.
There are regions of the Union that have permanent constraints that strongly condition their economic and social development.

Therefore, it is necessary to implement specific programs that allow these regions to effectively and realistically overcome the delay by promoting an adaptation of their development model to their potentialities and resources and contributing to achieving the objectives of the EU 2020 Strategy.

This incentive for these regions should result not only from the means of regional policy, through its structural adjustment instruments, such as the Cohesion Fund and the four structural funds, but also from the structural funds.
also a different use of the various sectoral policies that have a relevant territorial impact in each region and can therefore have a dynamizing effect on their economies.
To determine European assistance to these regions, it is certain that we must maintain GDP as the main eligibility indicator.

However, and taking into account its natural disadvantages, it becomes relevant to resort to other measurable criteria capable of providing a more real picture of its level of development, such as the unemployment rate, population density or level of education.
Only in this way will it be possible to have a more complete picture of the complex reality of the most disadvantaged regions.

I would like to remind you of the case of the outermost regions, whose status is recognized by the new treaty and which are a group of regions of the European Union that have specific characteristics and also deserve special treatment.
The outermost regions, united by their particular characteristics, also diverge in their levels of development.

In this regard, complementary GDP indicators should also be used, which can provide a more complete description of their specific reality and thus contribute to a more accurate determination of their level of development. Thank you very much.

who is going to, after all, define the priorities and, from what criteria?

Mr. President, let us be clear, the solidarity mechanism for sovereign debt did not work, nor does it. The price of Greek debt did not drop, Ireland is in.

The economic convolution and the contagion were not contained. The process that was created was created late, it is intergovernmental and should have existed with another format since the beginning of the creation of the euro.
The President of the Commission is now proposing a consolidation of this system.
But in the third of the instruments that are proposed to be used, it suggests the involvement of private individuals.
We had already heard this proposal from Chancellor Merkel and it was as a result of this anticipated and inopportune announcement that the markets shot up.

legislative on economic governance, but it will not do so by sacrificing haste, speed, and putting quality first.

Therefore, let us be clear, the Parliament will participate actively, but a matter as serious as the sovereign debt solution cannot be decided on the sidelines and at the mercy of European citizens and their representatives. The two elements are together.
Finally, we Europeans need a clear European vision in this moment of crisis.
A European mechanism for consolidating sovereign debt is needed, Eurobonds need to be issued, and the Eurozone needs to be sustainably protected through European and non-intergovernmental systems.

The European budget needs to be strengthened, we cannot continue with one percent of the European budget level and we need to put real growth and convergence at the center of European political priorities.

And the President of the Commission cannot be an emanation of the Ecofin Council.

Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, I would naturally like to say that the position of the EPP is clear. It is a position in the sense that.
that the resolution of this crisis, this serious crisis that Europe and the European Union are living, can only be done by deepening economic governance and the community method.

For us, there is no doubt that only with more community method, only with economic governance, only with the instruments of a single, true currency in the euro area area, is it possible to face and attack this crisis.

the community method, to introduce economic governance, to give the single currency the necessary conditions for it to succeed in the context of the European crisis.

It is now up to the Council, in December, to assume its responsibilities.
This is what we are counting on and with your clear adherence to the European ideal, President Van Rompuy.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to start by congratulating my colleagues Luan and Manescu for the remarkable work they have done on their respective reports.
Both constitute an important contribution to the ongoing discussion on the new cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 horizon.
Today, more than ever, the achievement of economic, social and territorial cohesion is essential for the affirmation of the European Union's competitiveness on a global scale.
This goal will only be achieved if we are aware that only by strengthening and developing the regional dimension can we have a cohesive Europe within it and competitive outside it.

In this particular, I would like to highlight three points that I consider to be key. Firstly, decentralization, making local and regional authorities, especially those with legislative powers, participate more and contribute to a better application of the cohesion policy.

Member States to invite regional and local authorities to participate in negotiations on the future of structural funds on an equal footing with national authorities and representatives. And, lastly, the strengthening of the role of regional authorities in the preparation, management and execution of programmes.
Only in this way, with greater involvement of these authorities in the entire process, will the principle of subsidiarity be fulfilled.

Another aspect that I consider crucial is the request for a simpler architecture for post-2013 funds, not as a consequence of the economic crisis, but as a general principle of the future cohesion policy, in order to facilitate the absorption of funds.
The main concern underlying the Treaty of Lisbon was to bring Europe closer to its citizens.
Let's do not just that, but also make your life easier, avoiding unnecessary administrative burdens that deter your participation.
Only in this way will we be able to achieve the goal of true territorial cohesion.
Only in this way will we see the disparities within the European Union, which are now markedly contrasting, and with a huge gap between rich and poor regions, reduced.
More participation also means more responsibility. And it is this responsibility that must be assumed and shared by all, doing more and better in order to have a stronger and more competitive Europe.
Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, I would like to start by congratulating my colleagues Edith Bauer and Anne Ed for the excellent work done on this report.
Human trafficking dishonors our society and requires a strong and coordinated reaction from everyone.
The organized crime behind sexual exploitation, forced labor, human organ trafficking and other ignoble practices must be effectively combated, but it must be mainly prevented.

The NATO Summit took place in Lisbon, so let me say a few words about what happened in my country regarding this Summit.
At that time, the Portuguese authorities banned the entry of European citizens into the country for only one reason: these citizens brought critical texts from the Alliance.
In those days, the least we can say is that an arbitrary regime, a real police of thought, was in place in Portugal.
A regime so special that it led the Portuguese government to buy anti-mutiny material worth 5 million euros and that didn't even arrive in time for the summit.
And these are the priorities, after all, of a government that is facing a huge social crisis.
In the Europe we dream of, freedom of expression is a fundamental value.
The Europe we dream of does not swear in front of military organizations that write their history with blood.
The NATO summit legitimized its military intervention on the entire planet.
The European Union's subordination to military strategy and American interests also came out.
Thirdly, the militarization of access to energy sources has been consolidated.
Finally, the military defense of the development model that generates environmental imbalances and disturbs the social crisis was established.
Therefore, Madam President, I want to say that, in my opinion, with this summit we have lost in democracy, we have lost in freedom and we have lost so that some can gain from war.

And I now give the floor to Mr. Rangel. He has one and a half minutes. Thank you, Madam President. The first point I would like to make clear here and which is important to reinforce in this Parliament is.
Unlike what sometimes seems to be read in the press and in the statements of some European leaders, the euro as a currency was fundamental to respond to the current crisis.

Without the euro, we would be in a very difficult situation, with the currencies of the most fragile countries in a huge devaluation and with a possible German mark in an impossible devaluation to bear the German economy and the European economy.

And that is why the euro was a factor of stability, especially not only for the countries that are in the euro zone, but also for the currencies of the countries that did not want to join the euro zone.

And that is why, because we have to defend this community that has been able to respond to the crisis like no other, and as we will see in the future, for example, what will happen to the dollar and the United States of America, we will see how the euro has, in fact, advantages.

We now have the responsibility in this Council to do everything to defend the euro, to create, in particular, a stabilization fund that follows the community method and is able to introduce responsibility in the.

Countries that are in a more fragile situation and solidarity with those who have fulfilled their obligations and who have not always shown themselves, at least through their external statements, available to be supportive in the context of the Eurozone.

I would like to sincerely congratulate my colleague Sarbu for the excellence of the report produced, strongly advising the Commission to take it into account, especially in those aspects where the complex dimension of agricultural issues, which far exceed the strict dimension of.
Agriculture requires the involvement of other areas such as competition, the internal market and financial regulation, as well as their treatment in other non-EU stages such as the G20 or the WTO.

The absolutely decisive issues for agriculture, for farmers and for the sufficient quantity and quality of food available to the populations of Europe and the world can only be addressed if they are in all these dimensions.

And the ambitious objectives of the CAP reform can only be achieved if the reform goes beyond the strict borders of agriculture and its objectives are also taken into account in the necessary interventions of other policy areas and in other global bodies.
This report made it very clear and I welcome it for that.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner and dear colleagues. I would like to start by thanking all the words that were left here regarding the report that the Parliament presents on Alzheimer's and other dementia diseases.
We all know that the situation we are living in is substantially dramatic and that it is still very under-diagnosed. This has been mentioned here.
And I just want to mention one issue that was transversal to all interventions, but probably not so highlighted, which is the issue of patient dignity, their rights.

And not only of the patients, but also of their families and those who care for them, whether they are formal or informal caregivers, and of the professionals who are associated with this type of disease.

I am, frankly, pleased with the Commissioner's words when he says that he shares the same concerns as the European Parliament and that the European Commission views all the recommendations in the report that the Parliament presents very positively and that it will do everything in its power to put them into practice.
We know that every day that passes is later than the previous one in this matter, given the urgency of what we have in our hands.
And, therefore, we also know that tomorrow the Parliament will make a statement on this matter.
We will wait for the result of the vote, but we know, Commissioner, that European citizens expect much more from us than solidarity and moral comfort.

They expect concrete and appropriate actions from us. I hope, Commissioner, that you will put into practice and that the Commission, which has the initiative, which unfortunately this Parliament does not have, will put into practice.

All this priority that says to give to this area and that transforms it into a legislative initiative so that citizens and their families see their rights respected and are treated with equality and dignity that they deserve. Thank you very much.

I am frankly concerned about the situation that is currently being experienced in Egypt and with today's developments, and that is why I understand that it is not calm that we should have, but we should have solidarity.
Solidarity with the millions of Egyptian citizens who are in Cairo and throughout the country, fed up with hunger, fed up with oppression, fed up with unemployment.
And that is why, after today's speech by Mubarak, after the regime's dogs were released, after creating an open and clean path to violence, we must say that we must stand by these people.
We cannot allow a fear strategy to be created so that they return home.
36 years ago, in Portugal, we would have returned home if we had heard these advice.
I'm glad we didn't come back, because that's how we had a democratic revolution.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I would also like to say that I think this issue is too important for us to continue living in the deception we have been living in Europe.
or a deception or a false promise, as you want to call it, because we have been operating, especially in terms of stem cell collection in the umbilical cords, from misleading information bases.
And we know, and it has already been mentioned, that in Europe stem cell collection through the umbilical cord does not reach one.

And yet we also know that their possibilities for treating diseases can be inexhaustible, diseases like those that have already been mentioned, cancer, like Alzheimer's diseases, rare diseases, there are many possibilities.

But what we let happen was that a set of private cell preservation banks were established, telling parents that they could keep their children's cells at birth and, from there, cure them in the future if necessary.
I think we should be more responsible than that, because the probability of this happening is very low, as we know.
And this false promise that is sold to parents costs money.
For example, in Portugal, this false promise costs three and a half minimum wages.
The solution clearly involves creating public stem cell banks, because only with public banks can we guarantee equal use and equal access.
and effective medical treatment and more research that is equal for everyone and not just using stem cells as a commodity or a growing business, but only for a few.
Therefore, I think that solidarity, common sense, and impartial information are not things that can be classified as an extra requirement.
We don't have the power to impose, we have the power to promote.
This is within our competence, I think we should do it in the name of equality. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. The price of food has reached its historic high and is the seventh consecutive time it is increasing.
And there are several factors that can explain this increase, the first being a short-term factor.
It has to do with the coincidence of bad weather conditions in some countries, such as Russia and Argentina,
But there are two factors that are structural, they are of a structural order and that is why I bring these two factors here.
The first has to do with the fact that some producers and consumers of food that were exporters have become importers, as is the case in China.
And the second has to do with the fact that the weight of some large multinationals manages to make prices play in their favor.
And the example of cereals is very clear at this level. It is dominated by six large multinationals.
This situation puts farmers in a huge uncertainty about food prices.
Europe must therefore do what it has stopped doing for some time, that is, protect its producers and consumers.
In a world where everyone resorts to forms of protection and where multinationals manipulate prices, we cannot continue to be naive. Thank you very much.
I would like to congratulate my fellow rapporteur Marisa Matias and all those who have collaborated with her.
Unfortunately, over the past few years we have seen an increase in the counterfeiting of medicines in Europe.
According to European Union data, one and a half million boxes of counterfeit medicines are sold annually through the legal supply chain.
This is a criminal activity that poses a serious threat to European patients and the European industry.
The aim of this directive is to prevent the introduction of counterfeit medicines into the supply chain and thus protect public health.

I would like to highlight the following key points in the opinion I have drawn up. The introduction of the definition of counterfeit medicine, clearly emphasizing consumer protection. The application of devices.
Safety of prescription drugs, accountability of all stakeholders in the distribution chain and, finally, the application by member states of effective sanctions to deter this criminal activity.
Mr. President, I would like to thank all my colleagues for their comments.
I won't comment on them one by one, that's not what I want.
I think that if there were any doubts about what the word commitment means, it was clear here what commitment means.

We don't all have the perfect proposal, but much more important to know if it is the perfect proposal is to know that we have an instrument in our hands that will allow us not to delay the protection of patients'health any longer.
And we have the obligation not to postpone its adaptation, we have the obligation not to postpone the real action and we can only do this together.
I must also say personally, and the Commissioner mentioned the issue of inspections, that in my initial proposal I presented an amendment for mandatory inspections in third countries.
That is exactly the commitment. And, in the meantime, you gain in some things, you lose in others.
The Commission explained to us that this would be impossible to obtain.
I would like to make another note regarding this commitment.
I think we all have a commitment, but I also think and I am aware that we will all be demanding that it be fulfilled, because otherwise it will not be effective.

And it is in this commitment that safeguards are guaranteed so that we can follow the process, evaluate and systematically have information that allows us to verify if it is being implemented or not, properly or not, and if changes need to be made.

I would like to conclude by thanking the European Commission for its collaboration, and in particular the Spanish Presidency and the Belgian Presidency, with whom we have worked together over the past six months.
There are no perfect proposals, no perfect interventions, there are failures, but I think we have a strong and robust commitment to allow us to fight and defend the health of patients.
And since my intervention is also full of failures, I failed to thank my colleagues Regina Bastos and Amalia Sartori, from the partners of the other committees.
Thank you very much for your support as well.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, it is not worth repeating that the current moment is the most serious test for the survival of the euro and, therefore, of Europe.
The Polimata report opens up constructive solutions and, therefore, I also want to congratulate our colleague for the ideas she has presented.

The gravity of the moment does not result from the fact that the euro zone as a whole has an excessive deficit or external debt. Rather, it results from the fact that the economies that make it up diverge persistently and severely under the impact of the common policy.
And we lack instruments that allow the convergence between these economies, that allow Europe to regain balance, that allow Europe to grow.

Let's be clear, the Eurozone and the European Union cannot survive with the current degree of integration and the diversity of the economies that make up it with a budget of 1% of the collective wealth.
In practice, after the crisis, the only solution we were able to build was the austerity recipe and it is the workers and companies who pay today.
the deficits generated by the speculative crisis of the financial sector, in the salvation of which 26% of the European Union's wealth was committed.
The financial transaction tax, which is based on a very low rate, for example, zero point zero five percent, on high-risk, highly speculative transactions, should indeed be paid by its consumers.
But why shouldn't they pay if ordinary citizens pay VAT on bread, milk and basic products?
The tax burden must be redistributed in a way that harms fewer workers and companies and is shared more balanced by the financial sectors, particularly speculative ones.
And, Commissioner, I think it is not up to the Commission at this time to refuse or avoid the clear message that this Parliament is giving you politically.
Public consultation cannot exclude the analysis of the financial transaction tax, on the contrary, it should be analyzed with the highest priority.
We know well what happened with the flu A and this should serve as a lesson for all of us.
And I don't know if you remember how it all started, but the truth is that it started in one way and then the response was completely disproportionate to the size of the problem.
That is why the report that was voted here today is so important, because we must learn from what was done so that what was done is not repeated.
We have the right to know who made the decisions, how the whole story went and who decided that it had gone this way.
As we have the right to know which countries responded in a certain way, why they responded without transparency and without letting us know.
Minimum of doubts, because we kept all doubts about whether or not there was a business. We have to be sure that there is no leftover if there was a business related to this flu.
And that is why I understand, Madam President, that all threats to public health must be addressed, but it is no different how they are addressed or who pays for them.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. We are talking about proposals on salaries and proposals on the retirement age, and the least we can say about these proposals is that they are frankly unfair.
They are unfair and insist on recipes that have been proven more than once to be failed.

What is happening in Ireland, Greece, Portugal, Spain, Italy and, you know, how many other countries, because this is an endless chain, there are different situations between each of these countries, but there are some things in common.
One of the things we have in common is an unprecedented transfer of the value of work to financial capital.
We cannot accept that.
The other thing we have in common is that the workers, retirees and pensioners are paying for this crisis. And a whole generation of precarious people is also paying for it.
There is no guarantee in this society we live in. And that is why I would like to conclude by saying, Mr. President and Mr. Commissioner, that we cannot continue to condemn people to poverty.
I sincerely hope so.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to start by saying that I fully support what my colleague said.

The prevention of natural and man-made disasters is of enormous importance and increasing importance, and the European Commission systematically presents us with a number of intentions, procedures and calendars.
But there is a very complicated problem, as already mentioned.
The Solidarity Fund is an instrument that normally responds to these situations, but it responds in a very, very long time, from nine months to a year, and this after the disaster.

As has also been mentioned, and I repeat, and we will repeat exhaustively as long as it takes, there is the case of Madeira. A year ago there was a huge catastrophe, it has not yet received any support.
And I ask, and I reinforce this question, is it not time for the Commission to review the procedure of the Fund itself and the financing model itself?
How can we maintain an exceptional fund to deal with increasingly chronic situations?
We don't know where it will happen, but we know it will happen and climate change is there to prove it.
Therefore, an exception can never respond to a situation of regularity. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, the concerns raised here regarding disaster prevention and response are matters of great sensitivity and of the utmost importance for our populations, which should not and cannot be delayed.

We are talking about very sensitive situations that affect people's safety and their property, which often move everyone with the loss of lives, destroyed families, and the destruction of entire lives of work.

But all our demonstrations are of little use in the face of the dramas that impress and make everyone aware in a media-based way, if we then fall asleep on the work we must do so that those situations can be avoided, minimized or, better, helped.
Mr Commissioner, the subject here, very well focused by my colleagues,

It is a matter where the European Union can better highlight its presence among its citizens, helping them in the prevention of disasters, especially when they occur, and be by their side in the moments when they need it most and are most vulnerable.
I will be happy to answer, although I do not want to turn a European Parliament debate into a debate on Portuguese politics.

I just want to say the following: we can no longer stand a government that has failed four times over the course of two years.
It is impossible, it is unsustainable, it is not credible for the markets, there are no more solutions with the socialist government.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. I would like to start by congratulating my colleague Schwab for the negotiating persistence that led to this important commitment and also congratulate all those who collaborated with him on this report.

We want not only to ensure a high level of protection for European consumers, but also that European companies, regardless of their size, can provide goods and services to consumers in the 27 member states without unnecessary legal obstacles.

This new directive will put an end to the legislative fragmentation that has been harming the participation of our companies in the cross-border market and will give an important boost to the internal market.
I highlight the new provisions regarding the information to be provided to the consumer, requiring that this information be clear, intelligible and provided in a timely manner.
It is also important that the burden of proof regarding compliance with information requirements falls on the merchant.
As for distance contracts, especially contracts concluded by phone or internet, their rules should be defined and the consumer protected by simple and effective mechanisms.

We are certain that, at the end of the institutional negotiations, the new directive will contribute to making the European Union more competitive and dynamic, as is necessary in a global economy. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Mr. President of the Council and Mr. President of the Commission. First of all, I would like to congratulate you on the results of the Council of March 24 and 25, particularly on the consolidation of the semester.

European, but much more than that, whether it is the institutionalization of the European stability mechanism or the closure, let's say, of the Euro Plus Pact, which was already coming from the Eurozone Summit on March 11.
I believe that these are very positive results for Europe and it is only a pity that this process was not fully completed on March 24 and 25.
I believe that if we had given that signal, if the States had given that signal in the Council, completely closing this fund reform package, we would be in a position today.
Stronger to face the 3, 4 months. In part, we would have mitigated the effects of the crisis that my country, Portugal, is currently experiencing and about which I also do not want to leave a word.
To say that, in the case of the PSD, fully integrated into the EPP, there is an absolute and total willingness to comply with the requirements and obligations of integration in the European space.
This is what we have been doing, even now, at this moment, when there are difficulties with short-term financing.
Unlike what the Socialist Government has done, the Social Democratic Party has shown its full willingness to provide the guarantees to Europe that are necessary in the context of this crisis.

And with this I want to give this signal, without bringing internal politics to the European Parliament, of the fulfillment, of the commitment, of the total guarantee of the Social Democratic Party in the rigorous agenda that the country will have to have after its elections on June 5.
Thank you, Madam President. Dear colleagues, Commissioner Stefan Fule, the historic moment we are living in requires firm and determined action.
Like many of you, it is with a mixture of hope, concern and expectation that we witness the events that are unfolding in the Mediterranean basin.

However, I am pleased with the proactive position that Parliament is preparing to adopt with regard to the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy to the South, which I hope will lead to a greater presence of the Union in this area, not only as a payer, but also as a committed partner.
First of all, by affirming the absolute need to defend our founding values in relations with neighboring countries.
We can no longer compromise on the defense of democracy, nor on the defense of human rights, and even less on the defense of social justice.

We can no longer privilege short-term stability at the expense of the superior interests of citizens and their uncompromising defense, their individual and collective freedom, with particular attention to women's rights.
In the future, the Union must prioritize a bottom-up approach in its neighborhood policy.
It is essential that this happens.
Only greater involvement of local communities and civil society will ensure maximum effectiveness in its implementation.

But I cannot help but express my frustration. I regret that this Parliament and the Commission do not want to take this opportunity to differentiate, once again, the Eastern Neighbourhood Policy with the countries that may potentially become our partners in the Union in the future, from the Southern Neighbourhood Policy.
I also challenge the Commission to demonstrate, in its review process of April 20, the ambition that the current moment demands, a neighborhood policy.
Tailor-made, tailored to each state, with clear benchmarks and a careful assessment that allows for a future Mediterranean economic space with the new democracies of the South.

To conclude, Commissioner, we are confident that the good environment and cooperation that have characterized the work on this topic will lead to the permanent involvement of the European Parliament in the planning and evaluation of this policy. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. The reports we have discussed and whose rapporteurs I congratulate reinforce a set of initiatives that aim to relaunch the internal market.
I would like to highlight the commitment of the European Commission, particularly Commissioner Barnier, whom I welcome, and the positive reception of this Parliament through the.
Consumer Protection and Internal Market Committee, to give priority to the competitiveness and dynamism of the market, a fundamental pillar of the 2020 Strategy.
Citizens and businesses expect effective impulses for Europe to grow economically again, they expect an increase in employment, they aspire to the creation of more prosperity.

And, as the Commissioner pointed out, opening up markets to our companies, eliminating obstacles and difficulties, will give them a very special boost and an equal opportunity that will allow them to continue their mission as the driving force of our economy.

Measures aimed at reducing the administrative and bureaucratic burden on SMEs and their access to credit and the services market, the European patent and the recognition of qualifications are essential.
The importance of the development of e-commerce in strengthening consumer and business confidence in this type of trade, the focus on innovation,
It is important for strong and lasting growth. Social entrepreneurship is essential for creating innovative business projects for social inclusion.
These are some measures that will ensure this ambitious project of completing, deepening and taking full advantage of the single market for the benefit of European citizens.
Finally, the important recommendation for the member states to redouble their efforts to improve the transposition and implementation of the internal market rules. Thank you very much.
I also want to join my voice to all those who have expressed concerns here about the low income of fishermen, aggravated by the historical prices affected by fuels, particularly in recent months.
As has been said here, fuel costs have a very high impact on the survival of our small and medium-sized shipowners, and are aggravating, in particular, the already fragile fishing income.
This price increase is also bringing us deep negative effects. Reduction of outlets to the sea, misery income for fishermen aggravated by the low prices paid at the first sale.
increases in imports of aquaculture and fishery products from third countries to the European market and a consequent abandonment of activity due to financial difficulties with more job losses.
In this context, to avoid the continuation of the worsening of the crisis, it is necessary to act and act with severity and depth on the problems of fishing.

The Commission must, therefore, provide positive responses with short- and long-term measures to face the adversities that the sector is facing and the serious losses of income that our fishermen are experiencing.
Dear rapporteur, first of all I would like to congratulate in particular the work of our colleague from the EPP, Mário David, whom I represent here today for being absolutely.
I was unable to attend this plenary session and I would like to say that we have always considered that supporting the flood victims in Pakistan was an ethical and moral imperative.
And that is why we strongly support all measures that have been taken in the direction of traditional humanitarian aid.
We really believe that we should continue to work to help stabilize the situation of so many millions of affected people.
What we cannot accept is that the European Union's trade policy is now considered as a proper and suitable instrument for humanitarian aid.

The truth is that this brings two disastrous consequences. One consequence within the European Union, especially for the countries of the South and for their textile and clothing industry, which is now highly weakened by an economic, social and financial crisis without parallel since.

Secondly, at the global level, in the WTO negotiations, where this opening of the world's largest trading bloc, which is the European Union, to these possible Pakistani disputes can completely unbalance the negotiations.
And it is not by chance that they are at an impasse.

It is therefore natural that, in the face of a situation like this, we have to say something about the history of this regulation and the difficulty it has had in these eight months of intense negotiations.

We will collaborate with the most constructive proposals that we will now, unfortunately, have to take a position, which will be a position in the sense of supporting the amendment that, in essence, provides for the end of this proposal for a regulation, as we know it.
We will have to do it at this moment, not because of less solidarity with Pakistan, but because we consider that humanitarian aid should be given on the spot and in its own way.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I would like to start by saying that, naturally, I believe that the agreement that was reached for Portugal is a balanced agreement.
It is a very tough agreement for the populations, but it puts its fundamental point on structural reforms to increase growth and competitiveness.
And I think that is very positive.
