I do not take the attitude of others who believe that countries like Greece, Ireland and Portugal did everything well, did not make a mistake, did not exaggerate, did everything well and it was only the international crisis that caused problems.

No, our governments have made mistakes and had wrong policies. But that doesn't mean that there isn't now an opportunity in the context of the Union to have the possibility of returning to the right path and the right path.

And that is why it is important to remember here that, in fact, it is necessary to tell public opinions that are against supporting countries in difficulty that they are not giving money to these countries, they are only lending money to these countries.
But they are lending them at very high interest rates and, therefore, they are doing a business that is positive for their budgets and their populations.

But I also say here that maybe it is time to have a global European response, with the admission of Eurobonds, with the admission of the possibility of selling on the primary market, to respond to international markets.

And it would perhaps be time for the European Commission, the Fund and the IMF to review the interest rates, so that they can give the possibility of lowering these rates to have sustained growth in these countries that are in difficulties today.

Thank you very much. I give the floor for one minute to Mr. Correia de Campos. Thank you very much, Mr. President, Commissioner and Rapporteur. This strategy is important for all European countries, especially for those whose economy needs more competitiveness.
is essential for the creation of small and medium-sized enterprises,
Today it is more the active generation of new jobs.
It is essential for universities and laboratories whose relationship with the productive sectors depends on their survival.
It is essential for the financial system, which will have a new market in innovation as the classic manufacturing model is exhausted.

Innovation is at the top of the European agenda and, being a pillar of the EU 2020 Strategy, it will have to be served by new financial instruments so that it does not succumb to the budgetary constraints of the situation.
I would like to finally greet Judith Merckx for her important contribution to a more innovative Europe and a more knowledge-based economy. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Madam President, Madam Commissioner, I would like to start by congratulating my colleague Odi on his excellent report.

The interim evaluation, although late, allowed to highlight the critical aspects of the seventh program, its excessive bureaucracy, the lack of interest from the industry, the number and complexity of the new instruments, and the slow pace of disbursements.
There is still a greater risk of large transfers of funds from the current Framework Programme to large-scale and questionable added value programmes.

But it also allowed to highlight positive aspects, greater international articulation and cooperation between scientific groups in common projects, some successful cases, including the European Research Council, and a greater gender balance.
There are priorities that should be developed. First, simplification. Second, promoting scientific excellence, not in some countries, but throughout Europe. A greater connection of.

Framework programme with innovation, with instruments aimed at small and medium-sized enterprises and entrepreneurship, the most successful of which is the Eurostar programme, which should be expanded. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, I am addressing you directly to the proposal you have presented here today to Parliament and I say to you with all frankness that I think we have the right, some of us, to be disappointed with this proposal, because the proposal that is presented is not only weak, but also has many gaps.
I think this is a European issue, not a matter of the States that have nuclear industry and those that do not, it is a matter of the whole of Europe and Europe desperately needs good news.
And I must sincerely tell you that one of these good news is to guarantee to citizens that we are taking care of their safety.
Now, when these tests are done in the terms that the Commissioner presents, that is, a first phase is done by the interested parties themselves, a second phase is done by the States that.

They defend these stakeholders. And a third phase is done by the pairs who are truly stakeholders. I wonder if the result will not be to say, after all, that all nuclear power plants are in very good health and recommend them.

We know that it is not like that and that is why I hope that there will be serious consequences and that we can tell our citizens that we are taking care of their safety and not just pretending that we are. Thank you very much.
I expect a decision of great responsibility from this European Council, especially with the climate that is being experienced in recent weeks.
and more responsibility than the one that existed in the last Council, where they sought to postpone a problem for three months just because of electoral calendars.

I hope that this decision of responsibility essentially makes it clear that economic and financial issues are crucial and decisive for Europe, but that economic and financial issues are instrumental for what is the main purpose of Europe, which is the purpose of maintaining peace.
If we approach the problems in such a way that they only lead to the States starting to distrust each other, to install distrust among the different States.
to create and fuel differences and rivalries between Southern and Northern States, between Central and Peripheral States. What we will be led to is the decline of the European Union.

I believe that what is at stake in this European Council, regardless of technical solutions, regardless of political disagreements, is whether we want the European project to remain a valid project for the peace strategy in Europe.
I think that is what is at stake.
What I notice in many speeches by leaders, both from those in countries in difficulty and from those countries that are paying countries.
Taxpayers, it is an irresponsible discourse, which often even appeals to some characteristics of nationalities that are extremely negative.
I therefore call, and only that, on the sense of responsibility of the leaders of European governments to find solutions that lead Europe to a way out and a solution.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Commissioner. My first words are to praise the work done by the rapporteur, my colleague Giorgio Stavrakakis, who did an extraordinary job in identifying future synergies for increased effectiveness between the various structural funds.

Your report is also part of this joint debate on cohesion policy, a debate that is of greater importance not only because of the substance of the topic, but also and above all because of the opportunity in terms of the timing of its discussion.
In fact, we are currently in the process of knowing the Commission's proposal, not only regarding the new financial perspectives, but also regarding the future post-2013 cohesion policy.
The cohesion policy is a fundamental policy for the European Union.

It is a horizontal policy that, through its instruments par excellence, the structural funds, finances projects and programs in the member states, seeking to reduce the disparity between the levels of development of the various regions.
However, experience has shown us the difficulties in terms of efficiency and results that result from the fragmentation and complexity of this policy.

Therefore, a single strategic framework for the various funds, with an integrated and results-oriented approach, is the starting point for more and better synergies between the various instruments and for the reinforcement of their effectiveness.
It is also essential for better coordination between the various sectoral policies and for better efficiency in the application of resources.
We must take advantage of the danger of the crisis to look for new alternatives.

And it is true that all these reports that are being discussed here today will pose enormous challenges. And we know that to respond to these challenges we also need a good budget. But we have to make a clear distinction between what are the budgetary aspects and the political objectives.
The political objectives are well known and, in fact, only by affirming these political objectives can we offer a future to the regions.

And if that is the case, then we must put the budget at the service of the future of the regions and the citizens, and not the citizens and the regions at the service of the budget. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, the cohesion policy is the key policy for the future of the European project.
The construction of a common space, with an internal market, a currency of its own, requires a certain level of convergence of its member states and regions in order to function.
The current differences in competitiveness and development asymmetries have inevitably led to the weakening of the European space and the crisis affecting the Eurozone.
This is why this vital need for convergence absolutely needs a powerful cohesion budget that cannot be weakened to finance other policies.
The European Union, in order to do more, must have more. And this is achieved by increasing its budget and not reducing, even skillfully, the cohesion budget.

I therefore ask the Commissioner if the creation of the Infrastructure Fund and the new innovation policies that will be articulated with cohesion and regional development, which I support, without an increase in the Community budget, cannot be transformed into the Trojan horse introduced in the cohesion budget.

Modernization and renewal of the energy infrastructure are essential factors for the sustainable and intelligent growth goals we are seeking with the 2020 Strategy and for our energy security that we need.
It is indispensable to involve all regions in this challenge.

To this end, the incentives provided in the regulatory systems must be improved, particularly those applied to higher-risk projects and more innovative projects, such as those being developed in the Azores in renewable energy.

The regions should be associated with the phases of conception and implementation of the projects, in the definition of priorities, in their elaboration and execution, because this guarantees better results and, therefore, a better defense of the European interest.
The current economic situation further accentuates the need to adopt an innovative and integrated approach to energy issues, taking into account all economic, environmental and social aspects.
It is essential not to lose sight of its medium and long-term effects, seeking to ensure safe, sustainable and affordable energy for all European citizens.

The report we are debating is of particular importance, considering the influence that social services of general interest have on the daily lives of European citizens, as well as on social cohesion, job creation and economic growth.

The collaboration with rapporteur Proncias de Roça was very useful and clarifying, as the rapporteur himself just said, allowing the adoption of several commitments in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs.
For the result we have here today and that we have debated, I congratulate and congratulate the rapporteur.
In fact, our main concern was to make it clear that the competences in this matter belong to the Member States.
National authorities are exempt from the competence to define, organize and finance social services of general interest.
Therefore, it is unnecessary to create harmonizing legislation at the European level, given that the realities of these social services of general interest are very diverse in the 27 Member States.

It is enough to try in health, social security, employment, and social housing services, which are examples that proximity and knowledge of contexts are the cornerstone for the proper and fairest provision of these services. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, as rapporteur of the REGI opinion on the future of social services of general interest, I would like to congratulate my colleague Roça, emphasizing the fact that we are facing an essential pillar of the social market economy model that we defend for Europe and in which the SIG plays a fundamental role in its cohesion.

Social cohesion at the European Union level advises not to neglect the existence of minimum levels of protection in all member states, without prejudice to the respect of the competences of their national, regional and local authorities.

European regions have a very important role in providing these services to the population and their opinion should be taken into account, given the nature of their constraints, to ensure that they are provided to the population.

In a time of crisis like the one we are going through now, social services of general interest constitute a social protection network for the most disadvantaged or for those whose income does not allow them access to private services.

It is indeed important to ensure that the member states that decentralize powers accompany them with their respective financial means so that regional and local authorities can ensure their good service to the population.
Ms. Ashton, I would like to start by saying that it is obvious that we must continue to support the democratic revolutions that are taking place in these countries.
I don't have much time, so I just want to leave a few notes.
First of all, we cannot forget that the conditions for negotiation, with a view to a democratic transition and not a civil war, have to be defined by the peoples in these countries.
The situation in Syria is serious, this applies to Syria, but also to Yemen and Bahrain.

If we want to avoid civil war, the last thing these countries need is for Europe to interfere in their internal affairs and, above all, and very particularly, through the presentation of military or paramilitary solutions.
And if I say this, I say it because we must totally reject what is happening in Libya.
NATO and the United Nations have passed all resolutions, even those voted by the United Nations Security Council.
And it is this silence regarding Libya, this rejection that we must make, and it is because it is not in this resolution that I cannot subscribe to it. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. President of the Commission, Mr. Prime Minister. First of all, I would like to congratulate the Polish Presidency on the ambitious program it has brought here and, in particular, congratulate it on the.

Neighborhood policy, not only to the east, but also on the southern border, where I think a challenge is currently being posed, perhaps more demanding than the one we have to the east, which is more long-term and less short-term.

But, having said that, I would like to ask the Prime Minister and the Polish Presidency to pay special attention to economic integration policies, economic governance, and financial market supervision.
I believe that at this moment, no matter how ambitious our goals are in terms of defense, energy, food security, environment, agriculture, and multiannual financial frameworks, if we do not.

If we do not solve the problem of the debt crisis in the European context in a clear and solid way in the face of global markets, we will not have a strong enough Europe to deal with these challenges that the Polish presidency has set for itself.

And that is why I drew attention to the fact that it is essential to convince the other heads of state and government that more economic integration and more economic governance is needed in the European Union.

Without this, what will happen is that instead of being the drivers or at least the representatives of our peoples, whether in the Council, the Parliament, or the European interest commission, instead of being that, we will just be.
Mr. President, as the President of the Machrek Delegation, I would like to say a few words about each of my four countries, in quotation marks, of course.

Starting with Syria and reiterating what some colleagues have already said, it is regrettable that the international community seems to have two weights and two measures in the eyes of public opinion.

It is necessary to denounce, if necessary, the countries that, in the Security Council, and I am referring, of course, to Russia and China, in short, in addition to Brazil, but with veto rights, that have prevented the international community from taking a more consenting position with what should be the values we share.
Regarding Egypt, I believe there is an urgent need to raise awareness among Egyptian authorities about postponing the elections, as has already been done in Tunisia.
As for Lebanon, I think it is necessary that this debate sends a very clear message to the new Lebanese government.
so that they are aware that they will be judged based on their actions in relation to the accusations made by the Special Court for Lebanon.

Regarding Jordan, it is an example that a peaceful transition is possible and that there is perhaps only a need at this stage to raise awareness and encourage the authorities to accelerate the reform process.
Obviously, we cannot forget the peace process in the Middle East in a debate of this kind and reiterate our hope that the Quartet meeting next Monday can.
To be productive and to reaffirm that this House would certainly like to see a much greater involvement of the European Union in this whole process.

I have no doubt that there will be a new round of negotiations before the United Nations General Assembly in September, but I hope that this round of negotiations will be productive and done in good faith.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to start by congratulating the rapporteur and everyone who contributed to achieving this work.
There is no doubt that this report will be a reference in terms of recommendations and solid and coordinated responses to the challenges of the crisis.
If the conclusion that can be drawn is that the crisis we are experiencing will only be overcome with the deepening of European integration.

In a time of serious financial, economic and social difficulties and painful austerity measures in some member states, such as in my country, Portugal, it is a temptation to take refuge in a protectionist and nationalist attitude.
But I am a hero.

The European response to the crisis is a true European economic government that pursues sustainable growth, promotes job creation and develops the social market economy, providing long-term responses with defined objectives that the member states identify with.
The strategy to exit the crisis needs to be financed with a sufficiently ambitious community budget.
To avoid a new sovereign debt and euro crisis, closer coordination in budgetary policies is necessary, as well as the creation of a system for issuing public debt securities and euro-bonds.
I conclude by emphasizing that in this difficult period it is also necessary to maintain the levels of social protection, especially for the most vulnerable citizens. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, President in office, it is common to say that crises help to strengthen Europe.
Historically, this has been the case, but today I am not so sure that this is still true.

The slow, improvised, reactive way the Union is reacting to the Greek crisis makes the situation worse every day and spreads the contagion and lack of confidence in the Union and its currency in a frightening way.
This is despite the problems of the Eurozone resulting from obvious failures in the construction of the single currency, which today focus on its weakest links.

For the current crisis to result in the strengthening of the Union, a strategic vision is needed, as there was in the past and which, unfortunately, neither the Commission nor the Council have been able to print on the European program and project.
However, this Parliament report gives us this vision. More Europe, not less, is the solution.
The Parliament recalls that the market and the single currency generate unbearable divergences between economies and that they must be countered by specific policies.

It recognizes that the functioning of the euro requires a European budget reinforced by its own resources, it requires a European debt issuing agency, capable of protecting States from market speculation.

and provide them with credit at reasonable prices and terms. It also recognizes that diplomas and the transferability of workers between countries require mutual recognition of social rights and pensions.
The Parliament came together to send clear messages. Let's hope the Commission and the Council listen to them.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear fellow rapporteur, first of all I would like to congratulate and congratulate the fellow rapporteur for considering that this report is extremely useful and allows us to take new steps in the area of mediation.
The report presents an overview, a range of solutions adopted by the various member states in the implementation, in the application of the.
Directive 2852-CE of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 May 2008, currently relating to mediation in civil and commercial matters.
Now, we all know the advantages of mediation.
On the one hand, it is an extrajudicial conflict resolution, contributes to the decongestion of the courts, to the rationalization of the justice system, while providing.
At the same time, providing the parties with the possibility of obtaining an amicable, faster and less expensive, less burdensome solution to the dispute they are arguing about.

That is why it is curious to reaffirm the objective of article 1 of the directive when it calls for the adoption of measures to encourage the use of alternative dispute resolution methods and, in particular, mediation.
Promoting access and the use of extrajudicial means of conflict resolution contributes to improving, simplifying and making our justice more accessible.

It is, therefore, a very important challenge for the European Union and for the establishment of the area of freedom, security and justice, I would say, for the idea of the rule of law within the European Union.
And that is why, in this context of crisis, I consider it very important that, as stated in the report, public opinion and operators can be made aware.
Judicial for this topic and to appeal here to the Commission and the Commissioner to quickly present a legislative proposal on alternative dispute resolution.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, I also want to mention the fundamental importance of this report in terms of transparency of what the European energy market is.
And I just want to say that this is a central area of cooperation in European terms, if we safeguard some of the fundamental dimensions. Among them, to prevent the.
Liberalization should turn into an increase in energy prices for citizens, ensure equal access and be careful with sanctions, as already mentioned by numerous colleagues.
And precisely because this is a central area of European cooperation, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I cannot fail to mention and question and ask you, Mr. Commissioner,
I would like to give you the opportunity to explain, regarding the recent statements you made in relation to Greece, Ireland and Portugal, because they are also matters of European cooperation.
Symbolic measures such as putting flags on the half-baked, Commissioner, are reinforcing the shame of citizens who are worthy and who fight for a Europe.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner Shevkovich, Mr. Council representatives, Polish Presidency. First of all, I would like to clarify that I will intervene here in a double capacity. On the one hand, replacing the author of the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs.

My colleague Messer Schmidt, a Danish citizen, who is absent because the election process is currently taking place in Denmark, and therefore I am representing him as a member of Africa, but also as a member of the jury, as a shadow rapporteur in the jury of this report.
The first issue I wanted to say is that in the crisis we are in, in the economic and financial crisis, the issue of intelligent regulation, smart regulation, better legislation is a central issue.

There is no doubt that, in the so-called structural reforms that can make the economic and financial start of the European space, improvement in legislation and regulation is also absolutely essential.

It is clear that a Europe that is intended to be dynamic and competitive, on the one hand, must have simple regulations that are accessible to companies and, of course, to citizens, and therefore must be oriented towards their needs.
The truth is that, in this sense, it is essential today that, first of all, the program of reducing administrative burdens is achieved, that all efforts are made in the direction of.
Promoting consultations with market agents, representative associations of citizens and companies, and assessing the impact of the legislation itself, this is also extremely important, so that.

The decision-making process can essentially be based on the opinion of those who are the recipients of the legislation and can be done without administrative burdens and with less economic and financial costs.

It is important to say that, for the Committee on Constitutional Affairs in particular, the idea of the principle of proportionality and subsidiarity is relevant, this idea that European intervention should be an adequate intervention and not an intervention that promotes the complexity of the system.

And of the regulatory system. And that is why we have paid special attention, in our opinion, to the reinforced role that the National Parliaments have in this dynamic today, precisely because of the principle of proportionality and the principle of subsidiarity.

It is therefore essential that we also involve the National Parliaments at the level of smart regulation and at the level of improving legislation, so that both legislation and regulation are in place at the European level and at the national level.

They should be more agile, more intelligent, more efficient. And, therefore, this is a good time to put into practice what we announce every day, which is a more competitive Europe and a more agile Europe through more intelligent regulation.
Mr. President, the number of homeless people, as well as those living below the poverty line, has been constantly increasing in recent years in several member states.
The economic, financial and social crisis and the increase in unemployment have aggravated this problem, as everyone has already diagnosed.
We all agree that this phenomenon is the denial of important values of the European Union, respect for human dignity and respect for fundamental rights.
In my country, for example, which is subject to a strong austerity measure, the concept of homelessness, according to the National Plan, includes people who are going to ask for help to have a meal.
And the number of people seeking help to eat has increased by more than 20% since 2008.
There is a greater increase in families and people in need who have seen their living situation changed by unemployment and also by bank debt.
This is just one example that demonstrates the gravity of this situation.
Last year, the European Parliament approved a written declaration on a European Union strategy for the homeless.

With this statement, this Parliament warned of the need for the European Union to equip itself with a strategy supported by national and regional strategies with the long-term goal of ending the situations of people sleeping on the street and the long-term homelessness.
National strategies should focus on preventive measures, but also on concrete actions to improve the quality of services provided to the homeless and the provision of affordable housing.
It is also clear that this European strategy must be compatible with the social housing policy of the member states.
We took good note of the Commissioner's words and we noted the point of the situation that made us.

I conclude by urging the European Commission to give a strong impetus to coordinate the action of the Member States and regional authorities in order to combat this social injustice. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, we have discussed the peace process in the Middle East, but is there any ongoing process that I have missed?
Unfortunately, no.

The European Union, like the majority of the international community, repeatedly speaks out in favor of the existence of two peoples and two states, sharing the space between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean, which have the right to aspire to live in peace and security.
But without dialogue between the parties, entangled in a volume of hatred and misunderstandings that has been going on for 63 years, only extremism and frustrations are fed.

It is essential that Europe and the Arab League get much more involved in the search for a negotiated solution for the borders, based on the existing ones in 1967, with the exchanges that allow most of the Jewish settlements to stay in Israel.

That the issue of Jerusalem, the holy city, the future capital of the two states, be clarified and mutually accepted as a symbol of peaceful coexistence between two peoples who have the obligation to fulfill the prophecy of Isaiah that this is the land of milk and honey.

that all EU countries participate in the resolution of the Palestinian refugee issue and that the international community, and in particular the Arab nation, participate in the necessary financial compensation.

It is still absolutely essential that a military force under the auspices of the UN and the participation, among others, of American and Islamic forces, be placed on the ground as a guarantor of peacekeeping.
So there is courage and political will.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, tourism needs a clear and coordinated European approach, with a close eye on the potential and challenges that the different modes of tourism have to offer us.
The tourist diversity that the European Union presents is so rich that it allows for exponential growth of this sector and the competitiveness of the European Union itself.

A bet on this key sector, which represents 10% of the GDP and about 12% of employment in the European Union, will allow us to create not only European added value, but also to face the economic crisis we are in.
I come from an outermost region, Madeira, where tourism is the main economic activity.

And, therefore, the creation of a specific item for the sector in the 2014-2020 financial framework is essential for a cohesive and sustainable growth of tourism, which is essentially composed of small and medium-sized enterprises.

The implementation of a true sustainable and diversified European tourism policy requires a concrete strategic plan with a well-defined timetable, actions and funding capable of strengthening the visibility and quality of the tourism sector in the European Union.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. The lack of an ongoing peace process is calling into question basic rights and has led to the adoption of unilateral measures from both sides that do not have.

It has not contributed in any way to a relaxation of tensions in the region and even less to the effective search for a life for the two peoples who have the right to live harmoniously in peace, security and dignity.

It is time for the international community to say enough. It is time for Europe and the Arab League to promote the search for a lasting solution, with common sense, presenting viable solutions, without delay and with limited deadlines.
It is clear that the United States and Russia are no longer part of the solution.
Let's start with Jerusalem. Why not recover the initial idea of a separate corpus administered by the UN and that obviously functions as the capital of the two States?
Frontiers. Let's start with the 1967 ones.
Exchange plots of land as much as possible and in a coherent manner.
Take care of the defense of Israel, an obviously unavoidable issue for the Jewish people, for example, by placing blue helmets with Americans, Europeans and Islamic forces next to the Jordan River.
There are about 4.8 million refugees and they have the right to their dignity, to a future linked to a land preferred to their own.

But it is not exclusively an Israeli or Palestinian problem, it is also ours, it is of the Arab neighboring countries, of the Arab community in general, but also of Europe and the rest of the international community.
The colonies must end their expansion, and this is not negotiable.
The announcement made today is shameful and translates hypocrisy and bad faith into an announcement of willingness to negotiate immediately.

Above all, we want negotiations of good faith, committed, with a deadline for their conclusion, from which the international community, in order to maintain its credibility, will have to have another attitude.

Thank you, Madam President. Madam Commissioner, the shameful situation in the refugee camps in Tunisia has already been mentioned here, we all share and I share much of what my colleagues who have just spoken have said.
I won't refer to that, in particular I refer to another situation that is more omitted, which is that of the citizens who were received in the homes of families in Tunisia.

And this is one of the situations that should make us even more ashamed, because let's look at Tunisia in a crisis situation, it knew how to be supportive. Europe doesn't know how to be supportive and it is not in a process of transition to democracy and it didn't know how to be supportive, it didn't know how to receive.
I think it is, in fact, shameful that we can count as a few hundred the number of refugees that were received in Europe.
Many of these people, contrary to what was said, cannot return to their homes.
And there were children who were enrolled in public schools, which have implications in terms of infrastructure, implications in terms of what is the reception in these countries.
And that is why, Commissioner, I am very sensitive to the appeal you make, and I do not say it ironically, I say it seriously. But, please, what about the Commission?
And Europe!
What can you do?
How can Europe live so well with this double standard?
We are so quick to repatriate and so slow to help, Commissioner.
I can't continue like this.

Mr. President, I would like to congratulate you, of course, for this supplement of hope that you gave to all the European deputies and, in particular, to the citizens of the European Union that we represent here.
And, having said that, I would like to say that we now expect the Commission to take very, very decisive action with the Council so that this sovereign debt crisis can be resolved in the short term.
We know it's a marathon, but we need immediate signs.

And, therefore, without prejudice to the fact that we are all starting to think about a change in the treaties that gives the political translation to the entire project that we have brought here today, without prejudice to that, something needs to be done now.

This set of measures and, perhaps, an agreement between the States, what I have called a kind of parasocial agreement that goes beyond the Treaties and that can, from this moment on, put all these ideas into action.
Congratulations on your courage and determination.
I believe we are on the right track and we are leaving here today with another determination.

Mr. President, the crisis that the European Union is going through has had serious consequences in all member states and thousands of workers are affected by the layoffs caused by globalization and the crisis.
We cannot fail to express our solidarity with these workers who lost their jobs and to say that Europe must help the member states to maintain an employment rate and to combat unemployment.
The rapid reintegration of workers into the labor market is a priority objective.

An example of the usefulness of this fund is my country, Portugal, which has used it four times, although we are aware that access to this fund could be improved, especially in the countries most affected by the crisis.

Thanks to the existence of this Globalization Adjustment Fund, it has been possible to help thousands of workers through vocational training measures, aid for the creation of companies and recruitment incentives.

This proposal is positive because it will allow member states to request the intervention of this fund to support workers who have been laid off as a direct consequence of the economic and financial crisis.
We support the extension of the deadline and we believe that the member states most affected by the crisis should have greater and easier access to this Globalization and Crisis Support Fund.
Thank you, Mr. President. I congratulate the Polish presidency and also Commissioner Ali Ren, just to say that I believe that.
Today, following and developing what was done in the State of the Union speech, a very, very big step was taken to be able to solve the problems of the euro zone crisis.
Because the Commission has committed itself here to use its power of initiative and to use it together with the Council to resolve this crisis.
I believe this is an extremely important step and it is the only way we have at the moment to solve the eurozone crisis.
There is no possibility of solving it in the short term only with an intergovernmental approach. And that is why it is necessary that the States, the governments of the States, give the.
The Commission has the instruments and the mandate to lead this resolution process, to put into practice, execute and develop this roadmap that you have presented here.
But I would not want to fail to say that this is not incompatible with the fact that we do, at the same time, develop our ability to change the treaties.

I am also convinced that in the medium term the treaties need to be changed, but we will also have to do it in order to strengthen, in order to give more strength and greater position to the Commission.

It is by strengthening the community method, now in the short term and then with a change in the treaties in the long term, that we will achieve more integration and a solution for the seventeen countries of the euro zone and for the twenty-seven countries of the European Union.

Thank you, Mr. President. Dr. Durão Barroso came here today to announce as one of the measures that banks that do not have capital requirements must present plans to obtain them and, if they are unable to present them, they must then suspend dividends and bonuses.
I could not help but agree with this presentation made by the President.
This week we saw what happened with Dexia Bank and a few months ago an administrator of this bank received a prize of 600 thousand euros for his wonderful administration as we know.
But to be serious, Mr. President of the Commission has to call the governments and present the complete package. And the complete package is what has the essential.
The essential thing is that taxpayers'money has a credit policy for growth in return.
The essential thing is that banks start paying taxes on their profits, which does not happen in many countries, particularly in my country, Portugal.
In two years, or rather, in three years, it is the second time that we are asked to save the banks with taxpayers'money, from the unemployed.
banks that also save the economy, helping to create jobs.
Mr. President, Mr. High Representative, there are times when I think we need to take stock and this seems to be one of those times.
And it seems to me that it is because we always go in the pace of events and the response of event to event and we lose a bit of what is the perspective of the whole.

It is true that each case is a case and each country we are talking about here is a specific case, but, forgive me, High Representative, it seems to me that it is difficult to examine what criteria the European Union has used to act in each of the cases.
I fear that we are often hostages of the interests of the countries of the European Union, of some of these countries of the European Union, and not of all.
And that is why we use the expression double standards so many times in this House and we continue to use it.

Sometimes it is sanctions, sometimes it is sanctions, sometimes the interference goes to the bomb, as was the case with Libya, other times it is total silence, as was the case with the invasion of Bahrain by the forces of.

Saudi Arabia. And, Baroness, let me tell you, I have been carefully studying all the files, I have not yet seen a single statement from European institutions condemning the invasion of Bahrain by Saudi Arabian military forces.

Death sentences, endless violence, doctors and nurses are sentenced to up to 30 years in prison by a military court because they allegedly were against the regime and not helping the injured who needed them.
Regarding the dictatorial monarchy of Bahrain and the dictatorial regime of Yemen, the Saleh regime, we have had much more silence than actions.

I am not in favor of interference, I never was, but I fear that we will put ourselves in an uncomfortable position, a position seen from the outside, Madam Baroness, which is, instead of helping development, aspirations.

Democratic and revolutionary in the peoples of Arab countries, instead of helping the Arab Spring, what we do is prevent it from spreading, either by process or by defect, and I don't think we should be left with that sin.
I hope that the awarding of the Nobel Prize to an activist and emitter can serve as a sign that our side is on the side of the peoples who are in revolution. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, this is a good report from colleague Casa.
First of all, we have to ask why we should review VAT in the European Union.
Firstly, the need to make it compatible with the single market
The more VAT regimes and varieties, the less fluid the market will be.
A VAT reform favors e-commerce, focusing competition on the value and basic price of goods and services and not on tax differences.
It combats fraud and ensures trust, which is so necessary, especially in cross-border transactions, improves the economy of SMEs and reduces administrative burdens.
What other measures with the discounts are already underway in the single market that can be associated with VAT?
Firstly, a simple, clear and transparent digital support mechanism, measure seven of the single market.
Measure 5, on services, the need to review the legislation on standardization and the implementation of the directive.
The new measure aimed at removing tax obstacles and explicitly reviewing the VAT system and the VAT equalization in online and face-to-face trade, which we all feel when we order books.
There are two main reasons for the pressure to reform VAT.
first of all, the economic crisis
More revenue is needed, including, probably, in some countries, the reduction of contributions to labor to promote economic development, passing this burden to VAT.

Secondly, the second major source of pressure is population aging, demographic aging and the trend of shifting from indirect taxes to direct taxes, due to the reduction of the population base of incidence.
It is necessary to rethink the balance between this direct and indirect taxation.
Finally, in these reforms, we have to reconcile subsidiarity with harmonization.
It is necessary to restrict the variation range in the normal VAT rate so that we can all understand each other better.
Greater transparency is needed in the definition of the reduced VAT rate and its scope, a clear and widely disseminated list of reduced rates.
It is necessary to study the exemption thresholds for SMEs, knowing that each exemption drags with it a procession of small or large frauds.
Finally, I would like to welcome the Commission's recent proposal to create a European VAT.
Madam President, I would like to thank my colleague Rula for the excellent report she prepared.

The advantages of public procurement are certainly known, but the obstacles are also evident. Conflicts of interest between European legislation and the objectives of the member states harm competitiveness.
The dichotomy between price quality and the complexity of laws and procedures is evident.
It is essential to look at the good practices that exist, particularly in Portugal, where electronic procurement has worked well and has facilitated public procurement.
Effective European public procurement represents a privileged means of controlling the public deficit and more growth.
To do this, it should have a stable and predictable legal framework, less bureaucratic procedures to attract SMEs and defend social and environmental values.

That is why I am pleased with the intentions that Commissioner Barnier presents to us here for the revision of public procurement, as this year, as one of the twelve priorities of the Single Market Act. Thank you.
I would like to congratulate my colleague Rula and everyone who collaborated with her.
The issue of electronic public procurement is important in the field of public contracts.
Unfortunately, the objectives proposed by the European Union, 50% of the electronic procedure awards in 2010, failed, with average values of 5% being scarce.
Only a few countries, like my own, Portugal, have been successful in this area.

The advantages of electronic public procurement are too evident and have been stated here. It allows the expensive access processes to be replaced by a simple consultation of the electronic platform, that is, it reduces many costs for companies, especially for.

Small and medium-sized enterprises. The dissemination on the internet and the ease of receiving procedural parts expand the number of suppliers, increasing competition and allowing better purchases. It makes the process of awarding public contracts.

More easy and flexible, it simplifies access to public contracts in the European Union, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, thus facilitating the participation in the public contracts market of these important engines of the economy.

In this sense, we welcome and encourage the European Commission to strengthen the mechanisms to transform electronic public procurement into an increasingly comprehensive reality. Thank you very much.

We are living decisive hours for the fate of Europe. And if the situation has quickly passed, before everyone's eyes, from a problem of the Greeks or the Portuguese to a problem of a great European dimension, the truth is that the insufficiency of the solutions pointed out and their delay have not produced any effectiveness in the rapid deterioration of the situation.
The search for solutions directed to the States, to the detriment of truly European solutions, allowed the markets to continue speculating on sovereign debts and imposed deadlines and rhythms.
Absolutely impossible that some states are trying to achieve with measures of unimaginable brutality applied to people, companies and the public sector.

A common solution, already found for the risk of European sovereign debts, is absolutely unavoidable, which removes the pressure from the markets and speculation and gives time for the adjustment that is essential to carry out.
Without this, what we will have in the end will be countries that will continue to have no means to pay the creditors, destroyed economies and a lot, a lot of suffering.

To the shadow rapporteurs, with whom I had a fruitful collaboration, and I also thank the rapporteurs of the opinions of the four committees involved. These opinions are a valuable contribution to this report.
We received 400 amendments and drafted 47 commitments that were all approved.
This demonstrates the importance and interest raised by this topic of new skills and jobs.
It is, after all, about preparing Europe's human resources, anticipating the needs of the labor market in the next decade.
The key strategy for drafting the report was to reformulate the common ideas to avoid repetition and ensure the coherence of the report.
I think that goal has been achieved.
We all know that the crisis that is currently affecting us has highlighted the weaknesses of the European economic and social model, as well as has cancelled many of the progress made in the past.
Since the first effects of the crisis began to be felt in the labor markets in 2008, Europe has already lost more than 5 million jobs.
Today, almost 23 million people are unemployed.
Youth unemployment is even more frightening. The youth unemployment rate is close to 21% and represents more than double the general unemployment rate.
On the other hand, unemployment rates vary depending on the level of qualifications in all member states.
This means that people with higher qualifications find a job more easily.
We also know that in the near future, the needs in terms of skills, competences and qualifications will increase in all types and levels of profession.
In this context, Europe faces four challenges: first, job creation, second, the need to develop and remain competitive.
Then, the sustainability of social security systems and, finally, the difficulty of finding people with the right skills to fill job offers.
This report has a double objective. First, to emphasize the need to act quickly to fill the skills gaps in Europe. Second, to better anticipate the needs of the labor market in terms of skills.

Several measures are highlighted for this. First, to ensure the availability of skilled labor, it is necessary to improve basic skills, as well as skills in science, innovation, information and communication technologies, as well as foreign languages.
As I have already mentioned, skills needs must be identified early, within a horizon of at least 10 years.
Today, the potential of a new sustainable economy, the green economy, and the need for investment in ecological qualifications are known.
Then, participation in lifelong learning, professional requalification and the reduction of school dropout should be increased.
Another important issue is the mutual recognition of diplomas and professional qualifications and the urgency of moving forward with this recognition.
Fourthly, we draw attention to the connection that should exist between educational institutions and the needs of the labor market.
Internships must be of quality and supervised by tutors so that they can lead to employment and end possible abuses of the situation of interns.
Particular emphasis is also placed on the role of social partners and social dialogue.
The report also proposes measures to promote demand and job creation.
We have a future ahead of us and we have to create employment.
And small and medium-sized enterprises play a decisive role in this goal.

It is also necessary to strengthen the single market to facilitate the free movement of workers, hence the need for coordination of social security systems so that workers can see their acquired rights guaranteed, especially the portability of pensions.

Finally, the issue of labor market flexibility. To improve the functioning of the labor market, flexicurity rules must be adapted to the socio-economic contexts of each member state. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Madam President. I would like to start by thanking all the colleagues who spoke in this lively debate.
All colleagues had very useful interventions and contributed to a very constructive discussion on an ambitious agenda at a time when we are living a serious crisis.

Incidentally, this discussion is taking place exactly on the eve of a European Council that will show whether or not there is the political will to overcome the difficulties we are experiencing and if there is the will.
policy for a deepening of our coordination in economic terms and if there is really a harmonized and unified will to be able to carry out the ambition that is in this agenda. That is, to have

New jobs in the next decade, new jobs that will give young people who are unemployed today and those who are being trained hope in the job market, hope in an inclusive job market that will give them an answer to their needs.

ambition of dignity through work and that they also have the opportunity to be in a permanent dynamism to keep up with the challenges of a globalized economy and with a dynamic that has no parallel in the last generations.

Therefore, our ambition is really that there is job creation, that there is economic growth, so that we can not only respond to those who are unemployed as a result of the crisis, but also to those who will enter the labor market.

The answer to the great challenges that lie there with the green economy, with health services, with services in the area of transportation, housing, which require a different vision, an intelligent vision and an inclusive vision of the labor market from all of us.
It is a big deal for everyone.

Thank you very much, Madam President. What we were told today here in the Council's statement is that, for technical reasons, democracy would have to be sacrificed in the European semester. But what we are talking about is a political issue and the question I ask is whether there can be political coordination without democracy.
Where is it that the scrutiny of the European Parliament is finally?
Where is the scrutiny of the National Parliaments over their major budgetary options?

But if the issue were technical, as was said here, then we are talking about a variable technique. Because we know how the Council substantially alleviated the conditions of the four countries that are on the waiting lists, France, Italy, Hungary, Spain. The same did not happen with the countries that are under rescue.
So, what intergovernmental model is this that allows Germany to give opinions about Portugal, but does not allow Portugal to give opinions about Germany?
And, Commissioner, I ask you to pay attention to this. No democratic legitimacy problem is solved by asking the members of parliament to consult the information on the internet.
This is a problem of info-exclusion, not a problem of democratic exclusion, which is what we are talking about here.

Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues. First of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur of Ardennes for the quality and opportunity of this report and also Commissioner Andor for the initiatives announced.
Poverty is indeed a very serious problem that requires effective and rapid action to stop the increase in the phenomenon that currently affects more than 80 million Europeans.
The serious crisis we are going through has aggravated this situation and made the times we are living in dramatic, as Commissioner Andor said.
The number of people unemployed is constantly increasing and we all know that the lack of employment is a passport for poverty and social exclusion.
This panorama requires resources, will and a lot of commitment from the European Commission and the member states.
If this does not happen, the goal of lifting 20 million European citizens out of poverty during this decade will not be achieved.
Therefore, I warmly welcome the initiative of the Platform against Poverty, which is a very important instrument for ensuring social justice.
But nobody doubts that the best antidote against poverty and social exclusion is job creation and the promotion of economic growth.
Mr. President, access to the internet should be considered today as a new fundamental right of citizens and not just as a mere object of commerce.
They depend on essential things, such as freedom of expression, access and sharing of information, access and sharing of culture and knowledge, as well as democratic and media pluralism.

And that is why this access cannot be subject to speculative tariffs or contracts that block the free choice and the possibility of easily changing supplier, particularly in the world of mobile telecommunications, as we also know.
Active citizenship therefore requires that complete and transparent information be provided.
Blocking the use of the internet is not only exclusive to political regimes that are afraid of their people.
It can also happen as a result of economic options, by offering privileges to potential clients and less equal treatment to clients who are not as profitable.
That is why I support the Parliament in clearly standing by the neutrality of the Internet and defending its total ability.
Let's talk the truth.
We have been taking the medicine to get out of the crisis for three years and the situation is getting worse day by day.
Instead of healing, we created two fatal vicious circles.
The first between banks and states.
In Europe, it is easier to discuss the bankruptcy of a state today than that of a large bank, but it is still expected that banks will finance the States and that the States will save their banks.
This spiral must be broken.
The Commission must move forward with European legislation that protects taxpayers from bank crises.
But it is also vital to protect the debt of the States from the attacks of speculators.

And for this, it is urgent and late to prepare the coordinated issuance of sovereign debt, called Eurobonds or Stability Bonds, and to guarantee it through robust instruments of a community and not intergovernmental nature.
In short, we also need to review the involvement of the European Central Bank.
But the second vicious circle results from the argument that some states are rich because they are virtuous, while others are poor because they have sinned.
This narrative is politically explosive and technically wrong.

She ignores the essential fact that a single market and currency, built by political oppression and among unequal, necessarily aggravates the imbalances of competitiveness between the center and the periphery.
And this is what needs to be tackled in economic governance.
No, Mr. Rompuy, through sanctions that promote the crushing of salaries and income with the control of one country over another.
Mr. Commissioner, first through the involvement of both countries with surpluses and countries with deficits, in order to converge productivity through investment, education and science.
The tensions have only generated unemployment, disappointment and another tool that we cannot control.

Thank you, Madam President. Madam Commissioner, the integrated maritime policy advocates a coordinated approach to the management and governance of oceans, seas and coasts, in a global and coherent perspective of all European policies related to the sea.

Having a global perspective and an integrated approach implies the interaction of European policies related to the sea and calls for better governance through greater involvement in the European decision-making process.
The success and relevance of this policy has been demonstrated over the last few years through the various initiatives funded in the form of preparatory actions and pilot projects.
The integrated maritime policy should, for this very reason, continue to benefit from adequate funding during the next years of the current financial programming period.
In this sense, I advocate for adequate funding until 2013, not only to consolidate previous projects, and support the definition of a stable framework with regard to the objectives of this program.
Policy, governance, sustainability and maritime surveillance issues are, for obvious reasons, topics that particularly interest some regions of the European Union, such as the outermost regions.

The RUP are regions that, with the exception of French Guiana, being small and small, depend on a reduced number of economic activities and in which activities related to the sea and fishing assume special importance.
Moreover, the outermost regions contribute to the European Union having the largest exclusive economic zone in the world.

The Outermost Regions represent more than half of the European Union's exclusive economic zone, about 15 out of 25 million square kilometers, and together with the coastal regions, they are fundamental to the economic growth of the European Union and its member states.
A program like the integrated maritime policy should benefit these regions, prioritizing the transnational coordination of maritime policies and relevant international cooperation.
It is therefore necessary to guarantee continuous and sufficient funding, not only for the next two years, but also and above all for the next financial framework, from 2014.
I would like to take this opportunity, when speaking of an integrated maritime policy, to highlight the enormous potential that the Atlantic and Inland dimensions hold for the European Union.

The Atlantic, being the western maritime border of Europe, also establishes its connection to the North and South Americas and Africa, giving a strategic dimension to Europe that is indispensable in the architecture of a maritime policy developed with the eyes fixed on the future.

And it is thinking about the future that the integrated maritime policy, in addition to promoting the articulation of maritime activities, should put the potential of the Atlantic in its three-dimensional dimension, based on science and technology, at the forefront of its priorities.

The research of the Atlantic's Mediterranean crest, deep sea and seabed is a new frontier whose potential exists in biotechnology and mineral resources and is of incalculable value for the knowledge economy.
The Union should take advantage of the privileged position of the Azores and the excellence of its Oceanographic Department to install a Deep Sea Observatory there. Thank you.
Enough of this path.
When the diagnosis is wrong, the remedies do not work.
And in the case of the Eurozone, excessive remedies have led to death.
The successive miraculous solutions that were being proposed were also equally discredited by the markets.
the Financial Stabilization Fund, the successive shares to strengthen the Stability and Growth Pact, the Troika's revenues in the countries under the program.
Blind discipline without growth generated a recessionary wave and between totally interconnected economies that therefore contaminated themselves with bankruptcies and unemployment.
And in the hands of the markets, that is, of the rating agencies and speculators, governments fall one after another and solvent countries become insolvent.

Changing the treaties now is another step in this disastrous trajectory, with an aggravating one. We risk destroying what remains of national sovereignty by putting countries in the hands of the European Court of Justice.
No, it is not necessary to alter the treaties.
In this emergency we are in, two decisions need to be made.
First of all, a real agenda for sustainable growth and cohesion must be implemented.
Where is Agenda 2020?
Where is the recovery budget?
Where are the projects, the project bonds for the structural investments of Europe?
And, secondly, sovereign debt must be protected.
Of course, Eurobonds are necessary, but in this emergency we are in, it is urgent that the European Central Bank, directly or indirectly, defends sovereign debt against speculators.
Not in a shameless way, but with a definitive, decisive position, as is the responsibility of any central bank that defends its currency and the economy that supports it.
For this, it is not necessary to change the treaties, it is necessary to have political will and European conviction.
We moved the treaty when we had learned all the lessons from the current crisis. And there are not a few lessons to be learned, but this is certainly not the time. Thank you very much.
Mr. President and Commissioner Dali, the first Single Market Forum, an idea that stems from the Greek report, took place in Krakow.
was rich in content and fruitful in the debate carried out by the Polish Presidency with European, national, regional and local authorities and civil society.
We have a roadmap outlined in the Commission's communication of April 12 with the 12 levers.
It needs to be passed to the EIB, as well as the strategy of the other thirty-eight priorities identified in the single market act.
For there to be a market, it is necessary to have confidence.
Now, the trust of citizens and consumers cannot be seen as a given, it needs to be stimulated, nourished.
The single market is not just a buying and selling operation, it involves horizontal policies, such as health, social and consumer protection, labor law, the environment and sustainable development.
The Single Market Forum should, therefore, become an emblematic event of the European Union, with an annual event and a diverse and increasingly participatory audience.
Mr. President, I think we are at a time of balance in terms of these crisis policies, austerity policies that have affected so many countries, and also the so-called structural reforms.
And it is in this context that I think we cannot fail to see how they have generated so much social commotion.
And it has generated social commotion not only in the countries with the greatest difficulties, in the countries of the South, not only in the so-called PIGs, but also in other contexts of Europe.
Just last week, we had the biggest general strike ever in Portugal, both in the public and private sectors, a strike that went out into the streets.

But if we look at what happened today in the United Kingdom, we see that we are witnessing the biggest strike ever, especially if we take into account that people took to the streets just as they did in Portugal.
And we are expecting a big demonstration in Brussels on Friday.
What this proves, Mr. President, and what the strikes prove and the people taking to the streets, is that the causes and problems we have faced are common and that is why the reaction is also common.
The European Union crisis is spreading to all member states, reaching unbelievable proportions.

We have seen chaos in the financial markets and the growing inability to secure the essential financing for the activity of our small and medium-sized enterprises, even if they are healthy, leading them to despair, bankruptcy, and unemployment.
It is a spiral that fuels the recession and is destroying the economy and society.

Nobody denies the need for strict budgetary discipline, deep restructuring, and more economic governance. But these are necessary conditions that, in the short term, are no longer enough to counteract the ongoing degradation in the Union.

And if it is true that policies are needed to stimulate employment and growth, without which we will never be able to control sovereign debts, the central issue today is to guarantee the financing of our companies and our economies, without which the Union will rush.
Therefore, more than ever, more than the revision of the treaties, we need today a strong and secure intervention of the European Central Bank.
Thank you very much, Madam President, Commissioner. We are all here today united around a resolution with a set of very important requests in terms of intervention.
We are talking about the World Day of the Fight against HIV/AIDS and this assessment of the resolution and communication of 2009 is fundamental.
It is fundamental precisely for things that have already been mentioned.
We repeat because, unfortunately, there is still room for repetition, which means that there is a lot to be done.
There are many new cases diagnosed every year in Europe and in the European economic area. A report from 2010 speaks of more than 25,000 new cases.
If we consider the neighboring countries, we are talking about more than 100,000 new cases
And if we think that there are things that cannot get worse, they can always get worse.

And one of the issues I want to make very clear here has to do with the divestment that has been made in the health sector as a result of the economic and financial crisis we are currently experiencing.
And this divestment has affected very seriously areas that are fundamental to the fight against HIV/AIDS.
And that is why, Commissioner, I think that the Commission has a fundamental role here in asking the Member States to fulfill their obligations in these areas.

A second issue also has to do with the increase in discrimination, also evidenced by the economic and social crisis, discrimination of workers who have lost their jobs because they are importers of this virus.
And that is why prevention, treatment and care should be equal for everyone, regardless of sex, age, and the region where they live.
And I hope we can implement these measures with the support of the Commissioner. Thank you very much.
Welcome to this Parliament, Mr. Draghi.
We are living in special and dramatic circumstances, and they require determined and urgent measures.

The spiral between the debt of the States and the debt of the banks must be broken, but at this moment the priority is to defend the States, to ensure that the countries of the Eurozone and the Euro itself are not destroyed by the rating agencies and speculators.
In the report that we will approve, Tremosa and Basel, we have proposals to rethink the architecture of the Eurozone, to create Eurobonds and a European treasury, but all this takes time.
At this moment we are talking about an emergency and, in this context, the only solution is in the hands of the European Central Bank.
Technically, the European Central Bank knows what needs to be done.
Today, it should not be inhibited in its intervention and action by limited interpretations of its mandate.
Your mandate is to safeguard the euro, not to deal with inflation.
At this moment, there is no doubt. Saving the euro and doing what is necessary is what this Parliament and the citizens expect from the European Central Bank.
Good luck and courage, Mr. Draghi.
The European Neighbourhood Policy already explicitly stated the positions that the European Parliament has been taking.

And it was with great satisfaction that we saw inserted in the subsequent communications of the Commission and the Council a large part of the principles and proposals that we have been defending in this House.

I would like to thank you for the excellent and permanent collaboration and coordination we have maintained throughout this time with Vice-President Cathy Ashton and Commissioner Stefan Fula and their offices.
First of all, for the upgrade achieved in our relationship with neighboring peoples.

By giving priority to relations with the general population and with civil society organizations in particular, we will be giving greater objectivity and greater effectiveness to our neighborhood policy, which is intended to be exclusively based on the universal values that we defend and share.
However, I would like to emphasize that the European Union does not intend to impose a predefined model or formula for political reforms in third countries.
But when it comes to our taxpayers'money, we should give more to those who are doing more in the approach to the values we believe in.
This principle means that the faster a country progresses in its internal reforms, the more support it will receive from the European Union.
The principle of more for more is therefore correct, fair and coherent.
Which means, of course, that we also anticipate the possibility of cases or countries where we will have less for less.
The neighbourhood policy is now based on the defense of the pursuit of common values and commitment to democracy, human rights, the rule of law and good governance.
But this search implies greater accountability.
Our partners are called upon to take more responsibility in the process. That is why we defend the principles of greater differentiation, greater conditionality and the more for more.
By taking a bottom-up approach to our partners and custom-made policies, which we call the bottom-up approach and tailor-made policies, we make institutional development and capacity more effective.

The institutional building that we want to defend so much and that is at the base of the rule of law and the democratic process that we want to see implemented as soon as possible in the societies, economies and communities of our neighbors.

The idea is to give the floor to citizens, as well as to all civil society movements that identify with our values, supporting organized movements that strive to achieve positive and democratic changes in their countries.
countries, improving the rights of women and children, building and deepening the principles of freedom, whether of expression, association, religious belief, press, choice, etc.
etc., with fair elections, with the fight against corruption, a Rule of Law, greater social justice, respect for minorities, environmental protection and resource efficiency.
The serious economic and social problems that our neighbors are facing also need to be the subject of immediate action.
It is evident that without our concrete help, the democratic processes in progress may fail.
These were the ideas we have always defended for the future European Neighborhood Policy.
These are the proposals in the report that we are putting to the vote.
Now it is time to act.
On our part, we will remain attentive and exercise the new powers of monitoring and supervision now enshrined in the European Parliament.

Finally, I would like to thank my colleague, co-rapporteur and friend Marek Sivic, to whom I leave a very special word of recognition for his remarkable work in the eastern part of the neighborhood policy.
Also to the Shadow rapporteurs and to all of you for the many suggestions proposed in the amendments you have presented and which I believe have enriched our work.
And a final word to the Commission Secretariat and the political advisors for the excellent support work I have benefited from.
In the European Neighbourhood Policy, without including the outermost regions as active borders of Europe in different parts of the world.
As external borders, the outermost regions convey our values of democracy, peace, respect for human rights and fundamental rights to third countries in these regions.
Regions such as the French outermost regions absolutely need greater integration in their geographical areas.

Distant from the internal market of the Union, this integration is fundamental for its development and constitutes a huge potential for the deepening of the neighborhood policy with neighboring third countries.

The neighborhood policy requires a new impetus, an impetus that also takes advantage of the privileged historical-cultural relations that the outermost regions of the Azores, Madeira and the Canary Islands maintain with North America and South America.
These regions can and should play a more active role in favor of the European Union within the framework of a new European Neighborhood Policy.

Mr. President, it has been a year since last September, after a deep debate in which I also committed myself as responsible for this matter in the Socialist Group, promoting meetings and debates with European, national and regional organizations linked to.

Retailers, industrialists and farmers, the Parliament approved the Bouvet report, containing a comprehensive set of recommendations to the European Commission with the aim of a fair income for farmers and a better functioning of the food supply chain.

Since 2008, communications, reports, recommendations have been produced in the Commission and Parliament, and high-level forums and groups have been established to solve this serious problem, without anything changing in practice, beyond greater awareness.

We return to the subject and it must be said without hesitation. A significant part of the problems that farmers go through derive from highly penalizing behaviors imposed, above all, by operators of modern distribution.
the problems are more than identified.
What has been lacking from the Commission and the Member States is an effective political will to implement the solutions.

Saying that this treaty is useless.
Unfortunately, it is mostly dangerous.
First, because it reinforces, with more punishments and rigid rules, a recipe that does not work.
The recessionary spiral has been launched.
Who can trust a doctor who does not distinguish weight loss from anorexia?
A doctor who, the more the patient weakens, the more insists on the remedy, while openly discussing the probability of his death.

23,700,000 are unemployed.

The Great Recession is not a fatality, it is an ideological obsession.

Citizens demand options, not words, but competent options. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Madam President. The Commission and the governments now promise to reprogram the structural funds to support SMEs and create jobs.

However, it is good to remember that at the end of last year, the Commission also decided on the suspension of the allocation of structural funds to countries that did not meet or did not meet the deficit or debt objectives.
You don't have to be very genius to realize that either the promise succeeds or the punishment succeeds, but you can't do both at the same time.
And that is why, Commissioner, I want to ask you a very direct question: does the decision to suspend the allocation of structural funds remain, has it been frozen or has it been annulled?

In other words, will Greece, Portugal, Ireland and other countries still be able to use the funds they are entitled to if they do not meet the objectives that are being imposed by the Commission and by you?

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. The proposal made by President Barroso to redirect the available structural funds to support our SMEs.
And stimulating employment, especially youth employment, could not be more welcome, especially for economies that are being subjected to strong austerity measures, such as the Portuguese economy.

With the external intervention agreement and the great difficulties of financing the economy, and in particular our small and medium-sized enterprises, by the banking system, this proposal is of special importance for regions such as the Azores, which, with high absorption and good use of funds, but inserted in a recessive context.

National, they can achieve a real possibility here to stimulate their economy through small and medium-sized enterprises and the indispensable contribution of our generation of young people, who are always better prepared, in the best response to growth and employment that with these funds.
three options.
