Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the milk package presented here as an instrument of organization of the sector contains important positive elements such as the strengthening of the role of producer organizations and interprofessional organizations and contractual aspects that in some Member States can, with the formers, leave us.

However, it is far below the instruments that the sector needs to prosper in the coming years, within the framework of an agriculture that we want to have in Europe access to the fair distribution of value in the food chain, which does not become an agriculture of large intensive farms concentrated in a few member states.

If improving the condition of self-regulation in the relationship between sector actors is desirable, thinking that this alone is enough is a serious mistake that can drive thousands of milk producers away, dozens of regions and even some countries of dairy activity.
The debate on the regulation of the dairy sector from the perspective of a sustainable economic, social, environmental and territorial sector still remains to be done.
And we cannot abandon the milk quota system without ensuring real supply management tools.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Commissioner. From May 2010 until today, we see how a problem that seemed manageable has worsened in an uncontrolled way.

It is true that the fight against the crisis opened by the financial markets has aggravated the indebtedness of the eurozone countries and that the most vulnerable have become particularly vulnerable.

However, is it possible that countries sharing the same currency are left to the fate of the attacks of financial operators and those who win, betting on the probability of euro countries going bankrupt?
The terrible consequences of the Commission's inability to respond have generated problems that are unquestionable today.
The speculative interest practiced on individual countries made any exit strategy from the crisis impossible.
The consequent aggravation of the country's economic problem justifies new interest rate increases until the total cut in credit kills the country's economy and the contagion does the rest.
This Parliament has long advocated for a common way of managing sovereign debt, subject to demanding but clear rules.
We welcome the fact that the Commission has finally produced a green paper on the subject, which was called.

Today it is clear that without any kind of obligations of this type, properly articulated with the European stabilization mechanism, the so-called protective barriers, the so-called firewalls for sovereign debt, do not exist. And as long as they do not exist, the euro is in danger and Europe too.

In the resolution that this Parliament approved by a majority regarding the new treaty, it was absolutely clear that it is not acceptable to continue imposing more rules of fiscal stability, budgetary discipline and sanctions on euro countries without taking concrete and urgent steps in the joint management of sovereign debt.
The two processes will have to evolve in parallel.
This is what we expect from the Commission and it is too late now.

I would like to think that this House of European Democracy will unanimously reject the behavior of President Assad and the Syrian authorities in the massacre of their own people, which we, powerless, witness on a daily basis.

The entire international community must maintain pressure on the Syrian regime through the application of new restrictive measures.
The murders have to stop and this is not negotiable.
insist on dialogue, without a doubt.

A democratic Syria needs a transition period and guarantees for all its minorities. However, the application of more restrictive measures to the Syrian regime is not possible if all countries do not row in the same direction. And this has not been clear and, unfortunately, it has not happened.
In addition to thousands of dead and two resolutions shamefully rejected in the United Nations Security Council,
We continue to reject the position of China and Russia, increasingly isolated in relation to their unbelievable support for the Syrian regime.
Everything else remains. A rotten, desperate and cornered regime continues to govern a country and we, the international community, remain powerless to stop the genocide of a people.
We are already behind in tightening the action of the European Union and the international community.
We need to give more concrete support to the Arab League in its interventions and in its intentions to send a peacekeeping force to Syria.
We must unconditionally support the work of the Red Crescent in its efforts to minimize the suffering of the populations.
The International Criminal Court must immediately initiate proceedings to punish those responsible for the crimes being committed against humanity.

And as a way of putting pressure on countries that have maintained support for Assad, also prohibit the European Union's trade exchanges with all Russian or Chinese companies that have trade relations.
and the commissioner yesterday.
Thank you, Mr. President. Welcome, Commissioner, to discuss this very important topic.
In fact, we are talking about central issues related to data protection and, above all, in a context where there may be conflict between two different jurisdictions.

And data protection is, in fact, one of the sensitive areas that has generated so much controversy and, in my opinion, should continue to generate. Because we are talking about what can be the shock between.

rights and guarantees, the safeguarding of European citizens who are protected by European legislation and then are overtaken when the legislation of other countries overlaps with European legislation.
is sensitive for several reasons.
It is sensitive because there is a break and there is a doubt about what is a contract that, for all purposes, exists between European citizens and European institutions.
When they give up their personal data, they give it up in the understanding that they will be protected by European entities and institutions and that they will not be distributed for other purposes.

And, therefore, there is a breach of trust here and this is a fact that is complicated to manage and, on the other hand, it is also a serious and perikulating situation because the European Union ends up transferring personal data to third countries, thus breaking the seal of trust that is generated.

between European citizens and European institutions. And therefore, if citizens accept that European institutions can be guardians of their personal data in so many different areas, from health issues to other issues, as mentioned, of companies.

Those who require data, and I am specifically talking, for example, about the case of the United States, which systematically requires data from the European Union, what we are doing when citizens assume that they are giving in and, as I said, that the European Union is the guardian of their data, what is done is a breach of trust.
Therefore, I also want to tell you, Commissioner, that these issues have been problematic many times, for different reasons, but I will always be on the side of the citizens'demands.

They want to safeguard the protection of their personal data. And if there are demonstrations that they want to do because the European institutions do not comply, I think we should be on the side of the citizens and not the other way around.

It is almost a kind of betrayal that is being carried out. And that is why this question we ask you, these questions we put to you, Commissioner, is so that you can clarify once and for all, because no community is built with destruction as its basis or foundation.

Decrease in the bonds of trust that exist between its citizens and its institutions. And in this sense, Commissioner, please answer us to what extent we can ensure that European legislation overlaps with the legislation of third countries.
Because if it is true that European legislation overlaps with the legislation of the 27 member states of the European Union, and citizens renounce this,
From this sovereign space, at many times, why can we accept that other countries, such as the United States, then overlap with European legislation that overlaps with national legislation?
This needs to be clarified because it is indeed very sensitive, it is serious and it is an issue that we should take into consideration.

And, finally, Commissioner, I would like to ask you to please tell us what the Commission is doing so that this does not happen, so that it is not recurrent and so that the personal data of all citizens and.

Companies and various sectors that are referenced in these issues should, in fact, be data that people can trust, that they are protected by what we protect. And by this I mean that I don't even share that all the information that is stored should be stored, but that is another debate.

Regarding this, as it is a serious issue and as it is a pressing issue in terms of what the rights of citizens are, I would like you to give us these clarifications so that we can all be more at ease. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, I would like to say that we expect a major economic decision from the next Council for the countries that are under aid, which is very much linked to the issue of structural funds.
it is necessary to flexibilise the structural funds

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I congratulate the rapporteurs and the. But I would like to say that enough of pious speeches about employment and growth.

Today, with the first results on macroeconomic imbalances in Europe, the veil begins to be raised about why in the European Union and, in particular, in the Eurozone, some countries grow while others fatally fail.
Europe is losing competitiveness in external markets and this agenda needs to be revised because this is where much of the insufficient internal growth lies. But, focused on the internal market,
Four countries, including Germany, accumulate surpluses year after year, while twenty other countries, I repeat, also accumulate deficits year after year.
As deficits accumulate, the external debt of these countries increases unsustainably.
Of course, this process has to be controlled,
Of course, discipline is needed.
But today it is important to ask ourselves, is the solution of the most fragile crushes with recessive policies the only possible solution?
Is the tax competition of some winners within the internal market still tolerated?

Can the largest European economy continue to develop common policies that favor it and internal economic policies that, being right for its economy, capture most of the gains of the internal market in its favor?

Openly, the possibility of bankruptcy of sovereign states in the euro zone, when they know that the firewalls never left the dossier of intentions?

As long as this desire does not exist, out of respect for our fellow citizens, let us stop saying that we defend growth and employment, because it is not true.
and citizens cannot continue to be deceived.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to start by greeting the rapporteurs.
Saying that we are living through the most serious financial, economic and social crisis since the creation of our modern international financial model is already a commonplace.
Emphasizing that unemployment rates in the European Union have reached historic records is never too much to demand that the fight against unemployment be the priority of priorities.
Youth unemployment is dramatic. In my country, Portugal, more than one in three young people are looking for a job and have no prospects of getting one.
Our citizens are disbelievers
It is urgent to give them back confidence.
After years of reckless management of public finances, it is time to adopt budgetary consolidation reforms and put the accounts in order.
But let's not be fooled, austerity without economic growth is only a partial solution.
The creation of more jobs and better jobs is the great European goal.
Measures to ensure that young people who will not be left without a job or training offer for more than four months, as well as to reduce the risk of poverty and social exclusion, must be a reality.
A year ago we witnessed the tragic combination of an earthquake, a tsunami and a nuclear industrial accident, all in sequence.
Today we pay a sincere tribute to the many thousands of victims of Fukushima.
Honoring the victims is telling them that we have learned the lesson, we must learn to deal with natural disasters, with nuclear we have the obligation to avoid them.
But, unfortunately, that doesn't seem to be the truth.
One year after Fukushima, new nuclear power plants are still being built.
One year after Fukushima, new nuclear power plants are still being planned.
Unfortunately, Japan has the memory of the tragedies that last, Hiroshima, Nagasaki, and we Europeans also have the memory of a tragedy that lasts, Chernobyl.
Fukushima forces us, for all this, to reopen a debate that should never have been closed, the debate on nuclear energy.
A year ago, nuclear energy was unquestionable for the Japanese. Today, two thirds of the Japanese do not want it.
They know that it costs lives, they know that this cost has no price. On the contrary, it is a cost that increases from generation to generation.
The stubborn policy in favor of nuclear energy is the policy of arrogance.
Here in Europe, we also have a majority of public opinion against nuclear power, and despite this, nothing seems to change.
There are 320,000 refugees in Japan today. Of these, 100,000 will never be able to return home.
What used to be familiar is now dangerous. What used to be comfort is now ruin.
It is the ruin of a building or a house with radioactive vegetation. It is the ruin of contaminated soil or water.

And Fukushima cannot be visited like other ruins, for example, a May ruin or a Roman ruin. But, however, like these, Fukushima also depicts a civilization, and the ruin of Fukushima depicts our civilization.
the one that chose to include a deadly technology in its development model.
An earthquake and a tsunami have no culprits, but a nuclear disaster has those responsible.
In Japan, as in Europe, many citizens have decided to create nuclear adeosis movements.
They know better than anyone that safe nuclear energy is something that does not exist. They know better than anyone that there are no stress tests.
They can simulate what happened in Fukushima. And that is why we know that energy policies are national.
As already mentioned, diabetes affects more than 30 million people in Europe.
And these are, in fact, numbers of an epidemic.
And that is why I understand that it is also justified to make a specific resolution regarding diabetes, especially since it is the first time that this Parliament has dedicated itself to this topic.
It is the result of collective work and it is a work that does not cancel out the work done so far on chronic diseases, on the contrary, it reinforces this ability that we have to intervene together.
We have about 325,000 deaths per year associated with diabetes, because we know that diabetes is the main cause of, for example, heart attacks, blindness, amputations, and failure of vital organs.
And in the face of these data, we have two options, in my opinion.
The first is to say that it is not that serious, that we can live well with this and that each government should take care of itself.
The second is to say that the absence of a European strategy in this area is part of the problem.
I understand that we have a lot to do on this side.
And we have a lot to do in early diagnosis, coordination, and investment in research.
And that is why this resolution is worth a start and a joint effort in this direction. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. What I wanted to draw attention to, basically, was to congratulate myself on the results of the Council.
Not because the measures are ideal, but because they are possible.
There is no doubt that today we have come much further and we can be more optimistic than we were three months ago and six months ago.
Many states have been making a huge effort to stabilize and consolidate their public finances, and this effort has only been made in some states by the induction of the European Union.
It is fundamental for them to regain their credibility in international markets and it is fundamental for them to grow in the long run.
With these guarantees that the States have given, among which the Portuguese State stands out, in order to make fiscal consolidation, budgetary consolidation, I am.
Convinced, also with the new treaty signed between the 25, that we will be in a position to seriously relaunch growth in the next steps of the European Council.
But only with this confidence that is being generated little by little is this growth that has to be made.
And that is why I say that solidarity between the richest and the poorest is important, but also between the poorest and the richest, giving these guarantees.
Mr. President, I would like to say that it is with great joy that we have seen that steps have been taken to integrate Serbia into the European Union.

This is very important because the experience of countries like Portugal, Spain or Greece, which were countries that lived under dictatorships and had a set of very serious problems, is the experience that European integration was the way to consolidate democracy.
And that is why Serbia deserves this opportunity as well.
I would like, in any case, to give a slightly different note here from the one given by my colleagues.
I know and health is very concerned about minorities, but we must not forget the Serbian majority. It is essential that the Serbs themselves have a place in the European Union and a full place.
This cannot be forgotten.

There will be no peace in the Balkans without Serbia. And therefore, no matter how much we emphasize the rights of minorities and they must be respected, we cannot forget the Serbian majority, its identity and its full right to be European citizens, equal to all others, with their own state and their own national pride.
Thank you, Mr. President. Portugal voted last week on the treaty, or rather, the budgetary ultimatum, which is not, in fact, a European treaty, it is good to mention it.

The favorable vote of the government parties reflects the accumulation of decades and decades of stupidity and a typical attitude of the good, fat student who does not think and obeys the bad teachers.
The position of the PS and its leader was to move from a very dangerous violent abstention to a crowded vote in favor.

This alliance makes our Portuguese Assembly the first Parliament to accept the humiliation of amputating one of its most important functions that the people elected, deciding the country's budget annually.
This is another blow by the European Union, another blow in which the power of money is increasingly beyond the reach of the citizens'votes.
And I ask, Mr. President, is it democratic for someone to vote so that they can no longer vote? Thank you.
Budgetary consolidation is imposing almost unbearable demands on some European citizens.
However, fewer and fewer people have to bear a greater burden every day.
The tax burden falls on workers, small and medium-sized enterprises, and consumers, and in the meantime, there is a completely excessive tax evasion and escape.
The European Socialist Group wanted to know how much this tax evasion and avoidance was worth in the 27 countries and they are worth one million million euros, in English one trillion euros.
This is more than the countries of the European Union spend on health.

This means a volume such that if we spent only one fifth of this value on investment, investment in Europe would rise from 2.7% of GDP to 3.5%. We are therefore talking about an exceptionally high value.

And the sense of the resolution that we are going to approve, initiated by this Parliament, is precisely a very clear requirement to the Commission and the Council to accelerate the concrete action to combat tax evasion and fraud.

This means, in particular, concrete initiatives of tax cooperation within the European Union, tax cooperation with our neighboring countries, particularly Switzerland, but negotiated by the Commission and not bilaterally country by country.
This means reforming and harmonizing accounting rules, increasing transparency and reporting.
This clearly means reactivating the fundamental issue of combating tax fraud and evasion through tax havens.
Europe is not a minor partner.
Europe is a great partner in the international context
Europe has an obligation, within the G20, to clearly defend a common fight against tax fraud and evasion.

Without this, we lose credibility with our citizens and, therefore, my last words are, in this debate, to encourage the Commission and the Council to start an effective fight against fraud and tax evasion. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to start by congratulating my colleague Nibler on her excellent work and pointing out the coincidence that on Europe Day, which we are celebrating today, we are debating and tomorrow we will approve measures that meet the legitimate aspirations of our citizens.
The regulation is about imposing limits on mobile phone rates charged to European consumers when they use roaming, with the main goal of ending roaming in the European area from 2016.
Our citizens are starting to benefit from a sharp drop in prices for calls, SMS and data.
If today there are operators who charge 3 euros per megabyte, from July the maximum price they can charge is 70 cents per megabyte, increasing this value to 20 cents in 2014.
As for the calls received, the maximum price that can be charged will be 8 cents this year and 5 cents in 2014.
In July 2012, a family with two mobile phone users will save, as the Commissioner said, 200 euros on their bill.
Second benefit: higher quality of information for consumers.
From the summer onwards, operators will be required to inform consumers of the prices they charge when traveling outside the European Union.
So far, the obligation will only be within the European space.
Third advantage, the possibility of more operators entering the market, which means increased competition that will stimulate better services and better prices.

Finally, in the near future, the consumer will be able, if they so wish, to have two contracts, one for services in the national territory and another for services abroad, maintaining the same mobile number and having only one bill.
It will equally be given to the consumer, to our citizen, the possibility of contractualizing with any European operator that offers him the best price.
This report is the perfect example of the Europe of citizens, the Europe of freedom of movement and freedom of establishment. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, in February 2009, this Parliament approved a report in which it supported the European Commission's proposal to relaunch the European economy.
There were clean energy projects, transportation, new technologies, innovation, and already at that time the role of the European Investment Bank and the structural funds was being considered.
After more than three years, we were able to produce the Six-Pack, the Euro Plus Pact, the Budgetary Pact, the Two-Pack, all of them full of reinforced discipline and sanctions.

But, in the meantime, while unemployment, especially among young people, reaches frightening levels, the European economy is entering a recession and more than seven of its member countries are experiencing negative growth,
And, meanwhile, while Greece is nothing more than a first stone that threatens to ruin the castle, the recovery agenda seems to have been forgotten.
At this moment, this agenda is clear.
What matters at this moment is no longer to give it an urgent character, it is an emergency character in a situation that threatens to explode.
Urgent intervention is needed on a set of pillars.
First of all, the European Marshall Plan must be established with investment promoting growth, employment and convergence.
Project bonds are one of the possible sources.
Secondly, it is necessary to stabilize the interest with which countries finance themselves.
Let us at least prepare ourselves to coordinate sovereign debt issues and jointly manage the accumulated debt.
Third point, the European Stability Mechanism and the European Central Bank must prepare to function in fact as real firewalls in the defense of European sovereign debt.
Fourthly, the credit that was massively transferred by the European Central Bank to commercial banking must reach companies.
One billion euros is retained in the banking system, while thousands of viable companies die every day due to lack of funding.
Fifth point, investment doesn't make sense without demand.
The most fragile economies are crushed by austerity plans.
It is the strongest economies that have to free up internal demand.

The fact is that almost 80% of exchanges are made within Europe today. And it is up to the Commission, Commissioner Olli Rehn, to make recommendations aimed not only at the most fragile economies, but also at the most dynamic ones.
And, finally, Mr. President, we must put a limit on the revenues imposed by the troikas.

Enough is enough with the punitive style, without dialogue and without accountability, with which high officials determine the fate of millions of European citizens and the democratic institutions of member countries. Thank you very much, Mr. President.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Commissioners. What I wanted to say is very clear. Naturally, the Portuguese MEPs of the EPP fully support all measures that can contribute to growth. There is no possibility of.

If we get out of this crisis without promoting growth, especially in those states that are most affected by the financial crisis. But sometimes, when I hear some colleagues here, I get the feeling that they think that there can still be growth with excessive deficits and bad public accounts.
Now, we have to continue to insist on reducing spending and structural reforms. We can do everything on the growth side, but we cannot abandon the path of containing and reducing public spending and.

Structural reforms. More growth cannot be more relaxation, more rest. More growth and more growth policies must go hand in hand with great rigor in public accounts and great rigor in structural reforms.
If we start talking about growth and thinking that there are magical solutions for growth, we will end up with unsustainable public debt again and we will continue without structural reforms.

That said, I would like to draw attention to the fact that at tomorrow's summit, it will not only be a matter of long-term or medium-term growth, it will be a matter of the urgent issue of Greece. And I think it is essential that European states somehow stand by Greece.
We are responsible for finding a solution to the Greek problem. And I would like to reject the statement of the British MP who spoke about the Portugueseization of Europe.
Portugualization of Europe, at least in terms of values, would not be a negative thing. And therefore, I reject this idea of trying, finally, to humiliate or try to reduce any peoples.
We are all Europe and we all have a place in it.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, you came here to tell us that every extra euro spent on debt is one euro less for job creation. So, explain to us why you continue with this obsession.

He also came here to tell us that one of the Summit's priorities is to keep Greece in the Eurozone. And I ask you, Commissioner, do we believe in you or do we believe in Dr. Durão Barroso or Mr. Trichet, who have been saying exactly the opposite for I don't know how many days.
You spoke about maintaining the Eurozone, I ask in which euro?

In the euro we are living in today, in this area we are living in today, or in the euro that was announced yesterday by Deutsche Bank in a study in which it referred to a G euro, a second-class euro, if the left wins the elections in June in Greece.
This is a trap, Commissioner, it is the trap of a Europe held hostage to governments and the trap of a Europe held hostage to financial interests.
Let's not let people live on fear, because it's not a way to live. Europe can be something else. You know, there is no lack of money, there is a lack of shame.

Mr. President, Mr. Minister Vaman, the first thing I would like to say is that it is regrettable that in a debate of this importance the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative, Mrs. Ashton, is not present.
In any case, we are pleased to work once again with Mr. Minister Vaman, who made a statement here in which I fully agree.

First of all, I would like to express my words of comfort and solidarity to the Guinean people, who have been basically the people of Guinea-Bissau, a people systematically massacred by democratic instability, political instability and great insecurity.
It was no longer enough to be surrounded by poverty, it has been systematically affected by these evils.

I would like to say, on the other hand, that the EPP, during its presidency, has been following this issue from the beginning and that it is also regrettable that the European Parliament, after only one month, is able to have a debate on this matter.
This has to do with the invisibility of the Guinean people and the Guinean issue.

And this invisibility is due only to the fact that, unlike other matters, which are also very serious, there are no major economic interests at stake that motivate European, American and world powers to debate the situation of the Guinean people.
But I must say, if an external reason is needed, if misery and political instability are not enough for us to have a global humanitarian and political action, there is a.
Unless the situation of drug trafficking that spreads in Guinea and directly affects European and American peoples were a reason for us to take action on this.
And that is why I ask here the European Union to be stronger.

There is no doubt that the 2048 Resolution, there is no doubt that the decisions of the European Union, the Community of Latin-Portuguese Countries, the African Union, but perhaps not, the Community of West African States, are heading in the right direction.
But resolutions are not enough, actions are needed.
We have to be firmer, we have to be more effective with the States that have the capacity to intervene in Guinea-Bissau.
This is our obligation.

And I believe that the European Union, at this moment, is responding well in terms of principles, but it is not responding as it should in terms of practical instruments, operation on the ground, and that is what I ask the Council and the Commission.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, globalization has brought with it a disproportionate growth of the financial sector, whose transactions are today, as we know, seventy times greater than global wealth.

Opacity, very frequent transactions, high remuneration, and very high risk have not only characterized the world we live in today, but have also been the fundamental reasons for the crisis we are going through.
However, this crisis came to ask ordinary citizens for accounts and efforts much more than the sector that had caused it.
So, today, this moment is important.

It is important and I personally would like to achieve a situation in which the tax would be generalized in all European Union countries and subsequently extended to the rest of the world, through active participation of the Commission and the European Union in general in the context of the G20.
I would like it to be covered or cover all products without exceptions.
I would like it to serve as a basis for the necessary reinforcement of the European Union's own resources.
In the short term, we have to accept commitments, but we must not lose the sense of where we have to go.
And this can only be achieved with a clear identification of these objectives by this Parliament, by the Commission and with a great spirit of commitment also on the part of the Council.

This is what European citizens expect from us today and I can only thank the role of not only Ani Podimata, who was tireless in this process, but of all those who managed to overcome the differences to reach a common position.

Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, colleague Podimata. Today we are discussing here for the first time the tax on financial transactions and its approval is the first sign that speculation does not go completely unpunished in this crisis we are living in.
This House and the European institutions must be accountable to the people and not to the financial markets.
For decades, financial market lobbies have been able to govern the world without opposition and without any problems.
It was obvious to us that during 2008 and 2012, the crisis of the speculative financial market was at the root of most of the problems we experienced.
And yet, these speculative financial markets managed not only to do nothing, but also to transfer money directly from the pockets of citizens to these speculative markets.

Mr. President, we have been fighting for this for many years, but it was only when the people all over Europe started to say enough that finally there was some initiative on the part of the institutions that govern the European Union.
And, therefore, this is the answer we have to give to the citizens. It is the first signal we have to give them.
The citizens of Europe who have paid for everything do not deserve our disrespect.
And therefore, this proposal is not complete, it is not perfect, it will not solve the whole problem of financial speculation, but it is an important sign.
We have been asking the financial markets for apologies, not us, the European leaders.
they should apologize to the people who have affected.
And, to conclude, Mr. President, a famous politician today, we are talking about these markets, these markets that govern us without ever having been elected.

I sincerely hope that governments will give a sign of confidence to the people and I sincerely hope that with this approval and the positive vote of my colleagues we will start talking about justice and solidarity in Europe.
Colleagues, find the courage, let's get this project through.
Thank you, Mr. President. The financial transaction tax should work as a way to control and discourage high-risk speculative activities in the financial sector.
It aims to reduce speculation and expand healthy competition, the basis of the single market, and also generate revenue.
The Podimata report tried to bring the European Commission's initial proposal closer to the well-known UK Stamp Tax. Thus, we made this proposal more attractive to reluctant member states.
It is expected that the Council will also understand the message.

If the Commission's proposal applied to transactions of financial institutions located within the territory of the European Union, it is now intended that transactions of European assets, even if carried out by non-Europeans, are also taxed.
This measure will expand the revenue base and reduce leaks.
It is expected that tax revenues will be considered as a source of the Union's or the States'own resources, reducing the taxes of the Member States, an issue still to be decided.
Mr. President, I conclude by congratulating the rapporteur for the quality of her work and I hope that this symbolic text.
Madam President, this weekend we had another request to save private banking.

They keep saying the same argument, which is to avoid the contagion of the Eurozone. And what I ask is if we have learned nothing. Greece, Portugal, Ireland and now Spain, and yet the contagion continues.
But what root of containment of contagion is this that is destroying us?

This policy doesn't work, we should already know that. It's the same rulers who say that there is no money for culture, education, health, public goods, who, when banks ask the markets, make it appear almost by miracle.
This economic policy is not a remedy, it is a deadly poison for growth, for employment, for the European economy, for social Europe.
The markets rule and governments obey and blackmail the people. And that is what governments are doing with Greece at this time, during the election period.

I sincerely hope that for the good of all of us, the Greek people will not be blackmailed next Sunday and will give us a lesson, because this recipe, Madam President, is a recipe for disaster. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Dear colleagues, unfortunately, the proposals we have discussed here today confirm the prohibition of anti-crisis policies in the euro zone and still implement the logic of the Budgetary Treaty.

There are some declarations of intent, but they are very timid. I refer, for example, to the roadmap so that one day we can start thinking about ways to define a possible legislation for the hypothetical introduction of Eurobonds.
The problem is that this day is only when all the problems of the Eurozone are solved and it is late, and it is really late, to arrive.
We support some aspects of this proposal, but at this pace everything will be too little and too late.
Placing a country under legal protection implies maintaining fees and amounts, as well as giving priority to new loans. In other words, it requires the
Member states that honor their debt, but they are deprived of all the instruments that can allow them to grow and find the resources to do so.

Let's be frank with each other. The only legal protection that exists in these proposals and that is provided is for the creators, but even those will not be resolved, because it is not effective for them.

As we have seen in Greece, Ireland, Portugal and now in Spain, this means condemning countries to recession, unemployment and insolvency. And I conclude, Mr. President, by saying that the aggravation of these situations and their spread to other economies brings us closer to a point of no return.

Faced with the complete failure of austerity, the European Commission or the German government propose the same policy, but under the austerity regime. It is neoliberal fanaticism that is killing the euro.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Given the extremely limited time we have, I just want to say to the Commission at this moment that you can count, as you have always done, on this.
Parliament in an effective work for the solidity of the Eurozone and Europe, but this can only be achieved when there are initiatives that focus on discipline.

We managed to add the conditions for a balanced sharing of gains and sacrifices among the different member states and among the different citizens and a hope that we will get out of the crisis we are going through.
For this hope to exist, other initiatives are needed and these are the ones that this Parliament is trying to fill, an initiative focused on investment, growth and control.
of sovereign debt, which has been the Achilles'heel, and which clearly reflects the fragility of the economic systems of some of the member countries.
Mr. Commissioner, you can count on us, Council, Madam President, you can count on us, but the agenda must be a comprehensive agenda, it cannot be an agenda that does.
It is not the discipline that is the condition for everything else to follow, nor does it make discipline the alpha and omega of our European proposals.

Our citizens expect this from us, they can count on Parliament and I want to thank again my colleagues, the rapporteurs, Mr. Gozés, who is the other rapporteur, and all the colleagues who, as shadow rapporteurs or merely active elements in the construction of this project, were able to contribute.
for a more balanced, more solid Parliament project, and I hope it deserves the respect, the ability to dialogue and the spirit of construction and commitment that it has had so far.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Thank you very much, Mr. President. Thank you very much, Mr. Commissioner.

Thank you, Madam President. In addition to thanking all those who collaborated for this result, I would like to ask that the final vote be postponed so that we can negotiate immediately at the level of the trialogue.
Europe is facing three agendas today: the growth agenda, the agenda concerning the management of banks, and the agenda concerning the management of sovereign debt.
And dealing with the European semester implies including these three dimensions.
Regarding the issue of growth, I think it is important to emphasize at this point that the Commission's recommendations cannot focus only on.
Countries with deficits. They also have to focus on countries that have surpluses. And if some have to crush their domestic demand, the others have to free it.

I also think that, in terms of growth, it is essential that the Commission controls the recommendations of the so-called Troika, because when a country enters a recession, it cannot continue to crush its public investment, to crush public spending, as if nothing had happened.
The troikas have to have their revenue reviewed and adjusted according to the results. And I want to tell you, Commissioner, that today we approved here in Parliament.
Parliament, the need to launch an instrument for growth and anti-cyclical activity of the order of 1% of the European Union's GDP for 10 years.
A second dimension is the dimension of what is now called the Banking Union. We asked in Parliament that this be done two years ago, in a report from June 2010. So far, it is to be implemented.

A third dimension is the sovereign debt dimension. Without it, there is no stability in Europe. And I also want to tell you that today we approved the Tupac here, but we introduced in the Tupac, in addition to austerity,

Some of the other dimensions that have been missing, and that is the immediate establishment of a redemption fund, using German terminology, so that sovereign debt, which exceeds sixty percent, can be managed jointly.

This is a legislative text and we are waiting for the Commission's good support for this initiative of the Parliament, so that we can control the completely threatening spiral that is currently destroying the European Union. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. Now that we intend to discuss a growth pact, it is essential not to forget the citizens and consumers, in fact the human and social dimension.

This gives it body and was the theme of one of the three reports on the Single Market Act of 2001. Because any growth pact should take into account the sacrifices and social benefits that are linked to it.

As important as an internal market test, it will be to carry out a social impact test of all the measures taken to implement the single market. A test, yes, an examination that allows us to measure the progress achieved for the benefit of the citizens of the European Union.
Since 2008, Europe has already lost more than 6 million jobs.
In my country, Portugal, the economy is suffering an unprecedented contraction and unemployment among men, women and young people has reached historic records.
According to the Bank of Portugal, the situation will worsen in the next two years.
It is in this context that we support and welcome the initiative of the new employment package and congratulate Commissioner Andor.
Insisting now and always on the basic premise of the need for economic growth, the member states will really have to focus their efforts on job creation.

The means for this should be through hiring subsidies that create new jobs, reducing the tax burden on labor and support for the creation of new companies and entrepreneurship, but also for small and medium-sized companies that keep jobs.
National employment policies must bear in mind that the areas with the greatest potential for job creation are health, information and communication technologies, and the green economy.
As stated in the communication, it is urgent to reduce the gap between the qualifications provided by education and the skills required by the labor market.
On the other hand, one of the solutions to combat unemployment is the mobility of workers.
It is also crucial that the use of structural funds for job creation and the practical importance of the Euros portal as an instrument, by excellence, of recruitment and job offers in Europe.
Finally, social governance has to be on the agenda because our citizens are eagerly waiting for concrete results. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Commissioner. It is true that six months have passed since this scandal with the GDP and the most unbelievable thing is that for ten years a private company could have managed to.
operating in the market and having introduced silicone implants that should be used for the construction and manufacture of mattresses and were used by women in 71 countries.
This affected a large number of hundreds of thousands of women, as already mentioned, it is estimated that around 500 thousand.

Now, we are talking about estimates because there were failures and there were serious failures in this process. We know that what happened to this company is a criminal case, it is a fraud, it is a court case, but we also know.

There is a fraud here that should be controlled by the courts and the courts will deal with it, but there is a legal loophole, there is a legal vacuum and we should deal with it. We have responsibilities in this matter.

For 10 years we were unable to identify what the criminals were able to identify. And therefore there was a gap in terms of control, in terms of traceability, in terms of files, in terms of records. Everything failed. But these gentlemen of this company were able to put into practice what we were unable to control.

This process is not only about the lack of information, which is very important, in fact, the lack of information in all matters related to breast implants, but also the humiliation of thousands of women and the humiliation, in particular, of those women who had to undergo tests to find out if they had placed the correct implants or not.

We are talking about a public health issue and we cannot be lax when it comes to public health. We control so much unnecessary things, we even control the authenticity of spare parts in cars, we recently approved a directive on this.

We have to control what is fundamental to people's lives. The revision of the medical devices directive is good news. It was the best news that we didn't have to do it. But now that we are going to do it, we are applying it with.

conditions, with traceability, transparency, control, sanctions, because, unfortunately, even if the sanctions are applied, they will no longer be applied to the women who have suffered from this problem and the States must assume full responsibility.

Mr. President, I would like to state very clearly that for us the Council that will take place at the end of June is fundamental and that what is essential is that a European solution to this crisis is sought.
From our point of view, the problem so far is that we have dealt with each of the issues that arise individually.

The time has come for a global solution for Europe, a solution that involves, as President Dole has made it very clear, more integration, more cooperation, a greater approximation of European policies and a revaluation of the community method.
It is essential that growth is next to stability, but that we do not abandon the concerns of stability.
We therefore count on a global European response, not a response divided for each state or region that is in difficulties.
Productive and more production possibilities have caused considerable increases in the milk produced, creating critical situations, surpluses and low prices in the milk and dairy market.

In many regions with strong productive potential, these surpluses were placed at balance prices in the market of other countries, causing even greater pressure to lower the prices paid to producers in these countries.

This happened, for example, with French milk sold in France at twice the price sold in Galicia. And producers, with the high increase in the cost of raw materials and production factors, saw their ability to resist low prices extremely reduced today.

This is a bad omen for many farms and many productive territories in Europe and it also seems to be a clear omen that the future may be without quotas and without adequate supply regulation instruments.

Therefore, a detailed audit must be carried out on the territorial impacts on thousands of farms throughout the European Union of the abolition of these instruments that we have today to regulate supply.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to start by congratulating the fellow rapporteur on this report.
This is a matter of extreme importance for Europe.
At a time when we are experiencing a serious economic, financial and social crisis, protecting intellectual property rights by fighting counterfeit products is fundamental for the European economy.

This protection should reinforce the performance of research and promote innovation. It should ensure scientific and technological knowledge, contributing to the development of new products and services.
All this in order to generate growth and create quality jobs.

Unfortunately, in recent years we have seen a significant increase in the violation of intellectual property rights in Europe, which represent annual losses, as already mentioned here, of 250 billion euros for companies and the destruction of 185,000 jobs in the European area.

But, beyond these negative effects on the European economy, the violation of these rights also constitutes a serious threat to the health and safety of European consumers, since many counterfeit products, such as food products, cosmetics, medicines, etc.,
etc., are produced in unregulated environments.
Therefore, the customs authorities of the European Union play a crucial role in preventing the entry of counterfeit products into the internal market.
The revision of this regulation aims to strengthen the control of the application of the legislation in question, to strengthen the legitimacy of its intervention, and to increase the.
Legal clarity, adapting the provisions of the Regulation to new realities and new developments, thus contributing to better protection of the European economy and consumers.
Intellectual property rights are, therefore, a crucial priority to achieve the objectives of the 2020 Strategy, in order to achieve intelligent, sustainable and inclusive growth. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President. In fact, the election of the new Egyptian President in the post-Mubarak era is good news. But we cannot delude ourselves. These presidential elections do not in any way close the transition process that is taking place in Egypt.

It was rightly mentioned that the dissolution of the Parliament days before the presidential elections put several risks on the table. And, in this case, the power that is concentrated in the Superior Council of the.

The Armed Forces were, to say the least, exaggerated. They have legislative power, they have reduced the power of the President and, in addition, they still have in their hands the definition of the changes in the Constitution.

Now, all this raises some concerns for us and should raise some concerns for us because Egyptians risk being hostages of military power and returning to the past, with the lack of a fundamental element, which is the democratically elected Parliament.
It is not up to us to make the change in Egypt, it is up to the Egyptians.
But I think we Europeans will have to be on the side of all the changes that propose the restoration of what is democratic legitimacy and a democratically elected Parliament. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Madam President, dear colleagues, Madam Commissioner. I would like to start by congratulating the fellow rapporteur, Lara Come, for the excellent work done on this report, which is of vital importance for the future of Europe.
In a world and in a society in rapid transformation, Europe needs a comprehensive, inclusive, effective and updated standardization system.
A system that guarantees the proper functioning of the internal market, improves consumer protection and their lives, but also protects the environment, is essential.

It is also very important to have more innovation and social inclusion, and the interaction and communication of networks and systems, especially in the field, as has already been emphasized here, of new information and communication technologies.
As Professor Monti mentioned in his report, a new strategy for the single market, European standardization is essential for the governance of the internal market, highlighted in the report.
The need for a review of the European standardization process that maintains the advantages of the current system and finds the right balance between the European and national dimensions.

In this sense, the report we are discussing now follows and defends these objectives, which are the right and appropriate ones. Ending the slowness and fragmentation that exists and that makes companies incur costs

to increase transaction costs and unit costs, to strengthen the participation of SMEs in standardization activities, particularly at the national level, as well as to facilitate their access to these standards, and to strengthen

On the other hand, the participation of parties that represent the interests of society, such as consumers, environmentalists, workers, people with disabilities, maintaining financial support to European organizations created to represent public interests.

I conclude by saying that the approval of this report will contribute to the relaunch of the European project, to European innovation, to the strengthening and competitiveness of our companies. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Commissioner. The future common fisheries policy should prioritize its environmental, economic and social sectors.
In a synergistic and non-hierarchized manner, in favor of sustainable development and in line with the objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth of the EU 2020 Strategy.
As rapporteur of the Regi opinion, I would like to highlight the particularity of some regions, such as the outermost regions, whose economies are heavily dependent on the sector.

In these regions, the reform of the common fisheries policy should seek to ensure the survival and future prosperity of their artisanal and small-scale fishing fleets, safeguarding and defending the employment that depends on them.

I agree with the European Commission's position on the need for an adjustment of this policy and specific measures that should take into account the disparate realities of the fishing and aquaculture sector in the various coastal regions.

I argue that this policy should focus on regionalization as a form of governance, through a reinforcement of the participation of the various stakeholders, so that in the future it is possible to respond more adequately to the demands and sensitivities of each maritime basin.
We are reaching the decisive moments when we will shape the new fisheries policy in Europe and we cannot fail.

The need and urgency to achieve sustainable rebalancing in our heliotic resources, but also in the revitalization of our fishing and coastal communities and in the promotion of their socio-economic level, in the modernization of the sector and in the supply of quality food, require, as never before, courageous measures and courageous actions.
Therefore, we have to make choices and prioritize goals.

I proposed protection for the fragility of my region, proposing that the exploitation of its resources be done taking into account scientific data and giving priority to our coastal communities in their exploitation and restricting external access beyond the 100 miles to the fishing banks there.
I proposed to safeguard the fishing capacity of our important fishing communities, rejecting the proposals for transferable coasts.

I proposed that our communities should have better intervention in the management of their fishing affairs with the creation of their own Regional Advisory Council, more suitable for the outermost regions. I hope that we can have a better future.

Considering what we know about the application of the third package, and part of this issue has already been discussed today, with regard to the delay in the transposition of its directives, it seems that the latest information I have is that.

18 member states have been notified, probably this information is already outdated due to lack of transposition. The question I ask you is how you see the possibility of, in the legislation that is being prepared, namely the networks.
Trans-European, if it includes a device, an incentive that conditions, a conditionality for the presentation of PCIs, of projects of common interest.

It conditions the compliance of the member states with the obligations arising from the third package or, on the contrary, it understands that this is an extravagant mechanism and that it should be left only to the regular competition mechanisms, article 101.
101 and their substitutes, all intervention in this matter. Thank you very much.
The Commission's will and tolerance, the spirit of tolerance that has existed in this matter. But the question is whether, while preparing legislation that can.
To introduce an additional and much stronger conditionality, do you think that this conditionality is an abusive instrument or do you think that this conditionality would be acceptable?
I confess that I share a lot of the concern that was initially presented here about the democratic legitimacy and democratic control that are related to this proposal.

Banking Union and Banking Supervision, because it remains to clarify and resolve an essential issue, which is the role of Parliament, the only institution democratically elected by citizens, directly.

But there is another concern that I also have, which is a fundamental concern and has to do with the following. Monetary policy instruments are controlled by the European Union. Monetary policy is the responsibility of the European Union.

Banking supervision also becomes the responsibility of the European Union. And yet, if everything goes wrong, if the banks go bankrupt, the responsibility for paying for that bankruptcy remains with the taxpayers of the National States, it remains a national responsibility.

This is not a problem of the utmost importance, it is a fundamental problem that is not solved. And, finally, I just want to mention that it is also not solved that we continue to tie monetary policy to what is a secondary issue in the context in which we live, which is inflation, and not to job creation and growth, as it should be. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. European leaders continue to insist on budgetary discipline and I ask about budgetary discipline, so let's get to it. Because what exactly do we mean when we talk about budgetary discipline?

In my opinion, budgetary discipline is about respecting contracts with pensioners and not abandoning the commitments of the State in the middle. In my opinion, budgetary discipline is about respecting the contracts of those who work and not inventing extraordinary taxes or cuts in subsidies.

Budget discipline is to respect commitments in health, education, and culture, and not to close services or close and cancel projects in the middle. Discipline is to put the banks in order and not to go and take from taxpayers to put them in the hands of speculators to save their banks.
This is the budgetary discipline that I would like to see implemented in the European Union and not continue in this market party.

If an example is needed, the budget being discussed in Portugal by the Troika is a perfect example. It violates all the commitments that any state should have with its citizens in order not to violate the agreements made behind closed doors that are bringing together Europe and its countries.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission. First of all, I would like to congratulate the Council on its results, although it seems to me that it is a bit delayed, the final decision comes a bit late.
The truth is that there is progress.
Now, precisely because I see myself in everything that my colleague Cassoulides said, I would like to ask just one question to the President of the Council. The countries that are under assistance.
Countries that are in difficulties have fought hard for the retroactive application of bank debts in their separation from the state debt.
This was apparently not accepted.
But yesterday we heard statements from the highest German and French authorities saying that they would treat Ireland as a special situation.
What I ask is if the Council has approved any decision on discriminatory treatment for Ireland, different from the one reserved for countries such as Portugal, Greece, Spain and others.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, it is a privilege to present the report on the 20 concerns of citizens and businesses.
Regarding the functioning of the single market, precisely in this debate with Commissioner Barnier, where the twentieth anniversary of this market is marked.

A first word to thank my colleagues from all the political groups, and in particular the rapporteurs and the shadow rapporteurs, for their very constructive contributions and their very positive attitude.
It was a pleasure to work with everyone and the report was very beneficial with our combined effort.

We are well aware and proud that, over the past 20 years, the single market has been the driving force behind great economic and labor opportunities in Europe, which have transformed the lives of European citizens and European companies.
Traveling, residing and working in the Union area are freedoms that are within the reach of all citizens of the 27 member states.
For European consumers, the single market means more freedom of choice and lower prices.
For our companies, the single market means more business opportunities with access to 500 million consumers, which means more economic growth and more job creation.
To illustrate the progress that the single market has made in Europe since its creation in 1992 until the beginning of the crisis.
2008, just look at the 2.7 million jobs that were created and the 2.13% additional growth of the GDP.
Today, making a phone call or receiving a phone call while traveling in Europe is 13% cheaper than in 2005.
The freedom of movement of people has its most eloquent expression in the Erasmus program.
More than 2.5 million students have benefited from this European Education and Mobility Exchange Program.
In the last five years, companies have also benefited from a 25% reduction in administrative costs due to single market legislation.
But one question arises. Is everything going well in the single market?
No, not everything works well.
The economic and financial crisis that affects us has had negative repercussions on the functioning of this market.
Our citizens, in some countries living with the drama of unemployment and being confronted with austerity measures, have become skeptical about Europe and a negative view of the internal market.
People still do not know or understand their rights sufficiently, nor do they know where to find information or help.
On the other hand, many member states are unjustifiably slow in transposing European directives and legislation on the single market, thus harming its full potential.

In certain areas of citizens'day lives, simple things such as, for example, reimbursement of medical expenses after a temporary stay in another country of the Union, opening a bank account for a student of the program.
Erasmus, changing energy suppliers, transferring retirement pensions, recognizing qualifications and registering a vehicle in another member state are still very complex, difficult or costly acts.
Important to respond to these problems.
That was my concern as rapporteur.
Therefore, the message written in the report is very clear: more political will is needed, much more political will from the member states and the European institutions
Council, especially Council and Commission, to govern better and together. It is necessary to regain the trust of people and companies and it is necessary to facilitate the exercise of their rights.

Finally, I would like to welcome the European Commission, in the person of Commissioner Barnier, for presenting the Market Act 2, 12 priority actions for new growth, which marks, I am sure, a new stage for the future. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner Barnier, dear colleague Regina Bastos, congratulations on your already successful efforts.
When Jacques Delors chaired the European Commission, the Single Market of the Union was created in 1992.
Delors then summarized the three basic principles of the single market: competition that stimulates, cooperation that strengthens and solidarity that unites.
Twenty years have passed, the economic and financial crisis has reignited the threat of national protectionism and it has become clear that the internal market is not a finished work.

And the celebration of these 20 years must be used for a relaunch of the single market, with the concern of putting the market at the service of the citizen and not the citizen at the service of the market.
To do this, priorities must be defined, and I would like to talk about one priority in particular.
A common policy for producing and distributing energy at affordable prices for the consumer, with a high level of energy efficiency, is essential.
Through the European energy market, served by cross-border infrastructures, with the possibility of community leverage of investment that represents European added value.
Madam President, you will also subjugate the common market in the energy sector.
One of the greatest achievements of the European Union, which certainly represents one of the strongest pillars of the development of the Union, its member states and its regions.
However, for it to be effective and fair, it is necessary to emphasize its policies in the sense of equal opportunities for citizens and all regions, promoting the internal cohesion of the Union.

In this context, it is essential to recognize that we can only achieve greater development in our most remote regions, such as the outermost regions, through their greater integration into the single market.

Regions like the Azores need to continue to increase their competitiveness, improving their competitive conditions. But we will never be able to do this if we do not better solve our accessibility problems in the area of transportation.
We can achieve this through specific instruments that better respond to the problems raised by our distance.
We therefore argue that the Commission should consider a specific program of the type POSEI Transport as an essential instrument for the introduction of this type of regions in the internal market.
Thank you very much, Madam President. I would like to start by saying thank you for this excellent debate.
It was a very constructive debate and it was a debate that demonstrated that the single market is really a great achievement of the European project.
I welcome the presence of Minister Mavroianis and his participation in this debate. I thank all my colleagues for their constructive attitude, some of them skeptical, which is understandable.
And I would like to thank Commissioner Barnier for the commitment and enthusiasm he puts into discussing these issues, these problems of the internal market and the political will to solve them.
We still have a lot to answer to the citizens.
Citizens are dissatisfied, they are disappointed and they expect more from us, they expect more from the Council, they expect more from the Commission, they expect more from the member states.
This balance is very useful, this balance of 20 years is important, but, as many have said here, it is important to open the door to looking to the future.
And looking to the future goes through many issues that have been raised here and many measures that have already been announced by the European Commission.
The digital single market, the mobility of citizens, the reform of the EURES portal, the European energy market are examples.
eloquent that we still have an important path to take in the future and that this path is very important and vital to respond to this time of crisis that we are living.
Citizens are suffering, citizens expect a lot from politicians and the answers that politicians can give to the adverse conditions they are suffering.
Therefore, it is important that the single market is one of the answers to the great challenge of competitiveness, employment and economic growth.
I am sure that after this 20th anniversary, we are all better equipped to give the answers our citizens need. Thank you very much.

The Gozés report, together with the report we are going to prepare on the Union's annual growth prospects at the end of this year and which will precede the Spring Council, are two essential pieces of the so-called European semester.
This report addresses the recommendations made to each of the member countries by the Council on the proposal of the Commission. And these recommendations frame, as has just been said, with.
The Six-Pack and the future Two-Pack, an extraordinarily strong body that reinforces European control over the economic and budgetary policy of the member countries.

The balance between this control and autonomy and legitimacy at the national level is not easy to find and it has fallen to a level of imposition, above all of discipline, and ultimately can even lead to a serious package of sanctions.

Regarding the Tupac, I would like to briefly comment that it is important that the Council, which is absent today, gives its negotiators a negotiating mandate compatible with the ambition to quickly finish this package, this Tupac.

But more European coordination, returning to the topic, means less control of countries over their own destiny, which requires a subtle balance, but also an increased requirement with the quality of the recommendations made to countries in at least three or four dimensions.

First, it is important to ensure coherence between the medium and long-term objectives, which include growth, employment and real convergence, and the short-term recommendations, focused mainly on discipline and nominal convergence. Secondly, there must be coherence.

with the conclusions that should be drawn from the analysis of macroeconomic imbalances, in particular on the asymmetric impact of common policies and the negative externalities, the spillover effects of some national policies on other countries.

Thirdly, we need to agree that there is a minimum threshold of social, economic and labor rights that cannot be exceeded by these recommendations. And, lastly, it is important that the quality of the recommendations is assessed based on the results achieved, which is far from the case so far.

I will conclude now, Mr. President. I would just like to thank Mr. Gozés for his spirit of collaboration and hope that he will take another step in this spirit, in order to broaden the basis of consensus around his report and that this spirit will also remain with regard to the next one.
It is true, and it has been mentioned many times here, that there are many things we do not know about shale gas extraction.
But there are also many that we already know and it is worth noting.
For example, we know that each shale gas extraction operation uses more than 19 million liters of drinking water, which can supply a thousand European citizens in terms of their needs in a year.

We also know that every shale gas extraction that is done, in each of the operations, 300 tons are pumped into the ground, it can go up to 300 tons of chemicals and about 80% of which remain in the ground and do not leave there.

We also know that in every extraction of shale gas, radioactive elements and heavy metals are released into the subsoil, which, together with the evaporation of the toxic waste resulting from the process, constitute a real threat to public health.
This is a danger of contamination of drinking water resources and it is a contamination that is real and imminent.

Knowing this, we know that shale gas extraction is also an answer that seems easy, that only thinks about the immediate, the industry and profit, ignores the populations, the future and the environment.

But this is also the Europe that knows, in this house, that water is an essential, vital and important resource, that knows how to protect the health of citizens and that must protect it, that seeks to make agreements to avoid emissions and to propose energy efficiency, because we know that environmental standards are important, environmental and health standards.
Therefore, when you don't know everything, being prudent is the minimum.
And they may even want to do it, but don't do it on our behalf or on behalf of the citizens who are here to represent us.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Dear colleagues, in fact, the last years have shown us how the Economic and Monetary Union has not resisted the crisis.
They also showed us that we had a European institutional architecture full of holes, particularly the institutional architecture of the euro.
And that is why the report presented here and the proposal presented are so far above in terms of ambition compared to what is presented by the governments.

But, as the rapporteur said, we are also in a field of making political choices and that is why I would like to clarify the reasons why we have some problems and we will not be able to support this report.
The first one has to do with issues related to conditionalities.

What we see, and we continue to have a narrative, is that there can only be solidarity between the different countries when everything is fulfilled in terms of the Stability and Growth Plan, in terms of the Intergovernmental Agreement, the Pact for.
Euro plus and a set of measures that require nothing but massive doses of austerity in the peripheries and also a set of recessive measures that, as we have already seen, are not working.
A second reason has to do with the banking union.
The rapporteur is right to present the banking supervision mechanism, but it is so necessary that we cannot escape the essential. And the essential here is escaping as we continue to add.

The national systems are clustered, which means that we are all together in banking policy, we are all together in banking supervision, but we are all separated when something goes wrong and, therefore, taxpayers will continue to pay.
And a third note has to do with the issue of common debt and the issuance of Eurobonds.
Here, once again, the possibility of issuing a common debt is considered, but only when it is too late.

Because we need the debt as it is now, it is not just when the deficits and excessive debts have been corrected, because with these policies we are following they will never be corrected, on the contrary, they will be increasingly aggravated for the desperation of an entire set of populations.

Therefore, I want to end, Mr. President, by saying that, despite all the efforts, I think we have here a very clear example that we could all still stand together, but divided we will surely fall. And that is why it was important to have gone even further.
Ms. Ferreira, please. There is always room for progress, but for Portugal, the support of the European Union has been fundamental in recent years.
Portugal has transformed from a country whose competitiveness was based on cheap labor into a country of highly prepared and highly sophisticated labor.
But when the country exports, there must be conditions for where.

And that is why it is important that some countries that have surpluses open their doors to requalified exports from countries that started from a profile of specialization that was absolutely unsustainable.

One last note to say that it is not possible for immigration to be the solution, that the requalified workforce, where European Union support was used, is now lost through a massive export of the most qualified to countries that have room to welcome them.
This is dramatic and completely makes our future impossible. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President. Small-scale fishing deserves special protection from the common fisheries policy, not only because it promotes socio-economic cohesion and ensures the livelihood of many families, but also because it is a factor of fixation for these communities along the coastal areas.
Its economic and social sustainability should be an objective, ensuring a differentiated fishing regime that gives priority to access to resources
It allows proximity management and protects the fishing rights that fishing professionals in these communities know against transferable fishing rights.
It is equally important for its sustainability to take into account the access regime to water, especially in waters or regions with biogeographical basins.
marine areas with a reduced continental shelf and scarce resources concentrated in underwater mountains and fishing banks that should have protected access.
In a context of liberalization and crisis that weighs on fragile regions, it must also be ensured that products from international trade meet the same requirements as products that the Union imports.
Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. Commissioner, I will be very brief because I believe that what is at stake here is essentially a political point.
A financial point. And the question that arises is whether we want the European Union to make a difference in the context of the crisis or whether we want to aggravate the crisis.
Most European countries are making a huge effort today, from the point of view of their public finances, to be able to overcome the crisis in a competitive way, in a way that can put their countries.
The European Union is globally in a great capacity for competition, but it is obvious that without investment, there can be no growth and this crisis cannot be overcome.
If the European Union insists on these radical cuts, particularly in the cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy, what this will mean is that the countries that are making a huge.
Without effort, they will not be able to grow and this plan that we have accepted in all countries for the European Union will fail. Good accounts with growth and competitiveness prospects.

The only and great instrument for this is precisely this multiannual financial framework. And, therefore, if we want the European Union to be successful and for this policy to be an exemplary policy for other countries, we have to bet on the budget for the financial perspectives.
